My computer speakers dont work?



the light on the speakers is on, the volume is the highest it goes. i am sure of this. no headphones are plugged in. i am sure of this. when the headphones are plugged in, i can hear through them. i cannot hear though the speakers if headphones are plugged in or not. my sound card is working correctly. i am sure of this. please help...

<answer>



Friend see to that whether your speaker is working properly, i think there may be problem in your speaker. Better connect another speaker and see, whether that is working or not.

</answer>



<answer from>



rann_geo...
Member since: 12 March 2007
Total points: 24927 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Could be a loose connection, maybe a short in the wiring, speaker connection to the wrong plug, mute accidentally clicked in the task bar.  Or if the speakers are old, an intenal switch is stuck not allowing it to go from speaker to headphone.



Try plugging the speaker into a stereo or another speaker into the computer to see if that works.



Or, the sound card isn't configured properly.



Doubtful on this last one, but if all else fails...



</answer>

<answer>

</category>



<question from>



M L
Member since: 24 June 2008
Total points: 290 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



The things in my recycle bin?



when i empty the recycle bin, where do those things go? i know they're still on my computer somewhere, but where and how do i permanently remove them? thanks for all answers.  ps. things like songs and videos.



</question>



<answer from>



joe.atta...
Member since: 28 June 2008
Total points: 6209 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The space that the files take up is (mostly) overwritten by the system, and the records of the file in the system's file allocation tables are also overwritten. You're partially right: there is data left behind in those files. But the space it takes up is marked as "available" and can be written over by new files.



There are tools out there that are supposed to "scrub" old data from the drive. But the only real way to really, really get rid of old data is to clean the disk with something like DBAN. Which will wipe the disk clean, so that may not be an option.



Once you've used the system for a while, those old file will disappear more and more. It's difficult to put together even the remaining chunks of a file after a while.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks, now i understand. thanks for explaining it in simple terms for me.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Colinc
Member since: 15 March 2007
Total points: 74980 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Their current space on the disk is marked as free. This allows the machine to save temporary system files (many) and anything you save over that space. Within about 2 hours if you are using the machine a lot (temp internet files use a lot of free space) they normally become so corrupted as to be unreadable. Within maybe a day or two they would almost certainly be unreadable in any part.



</answer>



<answer from>



Brandon
Member since: 29 February 2008
Total points: 515 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The above poster is incorrect.  You don't have to format your drive to delete files for good.  In OSX this functionality it built in by default, by on the PC it is not.  Here are a few programs that can recover deleted files, as well as permanently delete them:
http://www.pcworld.com/downloads/collect...



</answer>



<answer from>

</answer>

<question from>



Dave
Member since: 21 July 2006
Total points: 722 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How do you replace a key on a computer keyboard. How do they snap in?



Dell laptop



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Laptops are very tricky to replace the keys on.
It's hard to explain without being able to show you but here goes..



Under the key there is usually 2 small plastic clips which fit together in like a 'scissor' way (they join in the middle and pivot). Once they are joined in the middle, there should be 2 small clips on the keyboard itself and one side of the plastic clip will join onto the clips on the keyboard. Once that is done, if you carefully align the key on top of that and press it gently it should click into place, you may have to press it at an angle to make one side of the key click on before the other side will go on.



Be careful though, the 2 small clips can break very easily and as the key has come off, there may be a possibility that it could have broken when that happens in which case you would probably need to get a new keyboard. If this is the case, it's probably best to return your laptop to Dell if it is still under warranty, or if you are confident about taking the laptop apart, you should be able to find a replacement keyboard on ebay which you could fit yourself.



Sorry I can't really help more but it's a hard one to explain.



Source(s):



My own knowledge



</answer>

<question>



I just added another 1 GB stick of ram and my vista score went from a 5.5 to a 5.0 in the RAM area.  Why?



</question>



<answer from>



Rob F
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 154 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Check that you have fitted the correct speed RAM. If the new RAM you have purchased was a lower speed than what was already in your system, it will run at the slower speed which may bring your score down.

<answer from>



joe
Member since: 28 April 2007
Total points: 1262 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



neither of these machines will do very well on the limited RAM .  Both have extremely small amounts of data storage.  The processor speed is not nearly as important as the amount of RAM.  XP requires a minimum of 1 gb.  Vista minimum is really 2.  I would shy away from only 8 gigs of data storage (Asus).  If you need to expand the 40 gigs in the emachines you could always use an 8 gig stick.  Most programs nowadays require at least a gigabyte for the program alone.  A good photograph taken with a decent digital camera will consume 20 - 30 megabytes a piece (i.e max 50 photos per gigabyte).  You can always add a usb wireless port to the emachine.



</answer>

<question>



How do I add bluetooth to my Acer Aspire 3680 laptop?



My laptop has the bluetooth button so I know its bluetooth worthy. But what do I have to buy or add to it to get it to work?



</question>



<additional details>



The laptop came with the ability to use bluetooth, but its just a button. It does not work at all. I need to know what parts for the laptop do I need to purchase so that I can get it to work? For example: What are the internal parts that I need to purchase for the laptop to get the bluetooth ability up and running.



</additional details>



<answer from>



joe.atta...
Member since: 28 June 2008
Total points: 6219 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, first you need to attach something that works with bluetooth. Like a mouse. Or a BT-capable cell phone. Bluetooth is used for close-range attachment of devices. That's it.



</answer>



<answer from>



Melissa O
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 125 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



How have you confirmed that it does not work?  What are you trying to do with it?  If when you press the button there's not a light or an icon in your system tray indicating that it's activated then it's broken internally probably, and if that's the case just go buy yourself a USB Bluetooth adapter...it will likely be cheaper than diagnosing and replacing whatever it is that broke on the integrated one.
However as the prior poster said, unless you try to connect something to it and you receive the error that the Bluetooth is unavailable, don't be convinced it's actually broken.



</answer>

<question>



Dell laptop Inspiron- the middle green light (hard drive light) blinks on and off- is this a problem?- ?



Computer runs great- wonder if I need to call Dell to "fix" blinking green light- is it normal?  Is trouble ahead if I do nothing?



</question>



<answer from>



kaliman_...
Member since: 21 February 2007
Total points: 3679 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



thats perfectly normal. That lights just indicates your hard drive is working. It usually happens as your hard drive searches for the file it needs when your using it.



</answer>



<answer from>



dewcoons
Member since: 25 April 2006
Total points: 66546 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Dell uses the three lights to display different error messages.  You did not give the exact model (the errors vary with models) but on many of the Dell laptops the middle light indicates that there is a problem charging the battery.  It may mean that the battery is nearing the end of its life (they are good for about 2-3 years) and may soon fail to charge.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ian C
Member since: 20 February 2008
Total points: 8858 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



it just means that the hard drive is running now if the light changes to an amber or red then there is a problem though most hard drive lights don't change.



</answer>



<answer from>



James M
Member since: 15 December 2006
Total points: 7461 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its Ok. The blinking light simply indicates that the system is accessing the Hard disc.

<question from>



Dane E

</question from>



<question>



What is a TV Tuner on an HP laptop (or desktop) and how do i use it?



i want to know what a TV Tuner on a HP laptop is and how you set it up and use it. ( i have cable T.V. btw and no hp laptop yet, but geting one with a TV Tuner of some kind.)



:)



</question>



<answer from>



Karnage
Member since: 05 October 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>

<question>



What is Compatibility Mode?



How do I turn off Compatibility Mode in Windows?
Please Help



</question>



<answer from>



Rob F
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 154 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Compatibility mode is what is used to enable some older programs to run on operating systems that they were not designed for. For example you may have a Windows 95 program that you wanted to run on XP, then you could enable compatibility mode which would make it run.



Compatibility mode is enabled on a 'per-program' basis so you will need to right click on the icon for the program you want, then click properties and there should be a tab along the top for compatibility and from there you can change the options (this is for Windows XP, the settings for it may be in a different place in Vista but I haven't tried it so I don't know about Vista)



Source(s):



My own knowledge



</answer>



<answer from>



jibs91
Member since: 30 January 2007
Total points: 969 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well your probably talking about Microsoft Office 2007. So click on the Office Bubble Button and click on the options button on the bottom next to exit. Click on the "Save" tab on the side panel. Find where it says Save files in this format. Click on the drop down menu and click on "Word Document(*.docx). and press OK when your done. That should be it



</answer>



<answer from>



Greg B
Member since: 19 January 2008
Total points: 2115 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Right click the program,open properties, then compatability mode, make adjustments,click ok, you're done!



</answer>



<answer from>



sumyoung...
Member since: 20 February 2008

<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



amberazu...
Member since: 08 October 2008
Total points: 156 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How much does a CPU (central processing unit) and server weigh on average?



I must estimate the weight for an e-waste event and have no idea how much the average CPU weighs. While we're on it, how much does the average server weigh?



I would be incredibly grateful for any help on this!



</question>



<answer from>



colanth
Member since: 22 July 2006
Total points: 89043 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Programming & Design



Other - Computers



Computer Networking



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The typical 32 bit or 64 bit CPU weighs a couple of ounces.  (A CPU is an integrated circuit - it plugs into a socket on the motherboard.)  A small 8 bit CPU can weigh well under an ounce (like the one in your cellphone).



A server (or desktop - they're the same computer, just being used for different purposes) can weigh anywhere from a couple of pounds to many pounds, depending on the weight of the power supply, how many drives are in it, what other cards are in it, etc.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you, this was very helpful!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Lol G
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 508 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



CPU is indeed very light. A server (a normal one) is probably the same weight as a normal computer. (around 10kg)



</answer>



<answer from>



Fox
Member since: 24 February 2008
Total points: 8724 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



CPU's are very light weight, like less than 1/4 lb. Servers range greatly since there are several different makes and models so there really isn't an average.



</answer>

<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



whatisth...
Member since: 28 August 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Vibration vs Force Feedback?



I am thinking of buying a racing wheel for my PC but do not know what is the differnece between Vibration Feedback and Force Feedback (other than the fact that VF wheels are cheaper than FF wheels).



Please help / advise!



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Vibration is just what the name implies.  It's used usually as a general indication of a rough ride, or being hit by something.



Force feedback means physical resistance against your movement of the controller.  If you're against a wall on your left side and you try to turn left, you can't, so force feedback keeps the wheel from turning any more to the left until you're clear of that wall.  It's a much more realistic feeling of being in the game.



Vibration is typically done with a motor with an unbalanced weight on the shaft.  Force feedback is a lot more complicated than that, hence the price difference.



</answer>

<question>



What can you teach me about zip disks?



I've never used or even seen a zip drive (w zip disks) until about 10 minutes ago.  Help me out.  What do I need to know?



</question>



<additional details>



I need to use one to get files off a computer that's so old it's only operable from DOS.



</additional details>



<answer from>



frank211...
Member since: 06 March 2007
Total points: 9735 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



They are just like floppy disks only bigger



</answer>



<answer from>



Jag
Member since: 29 June 2007
Total points: 18131 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Desktops



Laptops & Notebooks



Computer Networking



</answer from>



<answer>



They are tempramental.  They are obsolete.  A DVD or CD burner with RW Disks is a much more economical, faster solution.



They were awesome from 1995 - 1999 or so.



Why use a Zip drive for DOS when you could use a network to copy the files instead?  Or even move the drive to a new system.  Then you can access it normally.



</answer>



<answer from>



joe.atta...
Member since: 28 June 2008
Total points: 6231 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Nothing.



They use small storage units and you copy files to an from them like any other disk drive.



I can't believe someone still uses one. You can fit about 100x the data on a small USB stick. It's a really obsolete technology at this stage, unless you just need to store small amounts of data.



</answer>



<answer from>



schizoju...
Member since: 12 June 2006
Total points: 250 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Are they still around? =)



I hated them. They broke so easily.



</answer>



<answer from>



mermeliz
Member since: 11 March 2007
Total points: 5397 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



They used to be very popular for data storage and file transfers. I have over 40 zip disks with backed up data on them, however I rarely use them anymore. With the advent of cd burning and now dvd burning, the zip disk appears to be following the same path of extinction that the floppy disk is heading.
There are 250 meg disks and 100 meg disks. you can use an internal ide drive to read and wrtie or you can go mobile and use a usb drive which is also available.



Contrary to some of the other comments I've read here, I've actually never had any problems with them other than if you want to share any of the files that are on them, then the other person also has to have a zip drive. (but the usb drive helps).



</answer>



<answer from>



Pete
Member since: 21 June 2006
Total points: 10867 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Programming & Design



</answer from>



<answer>



What you really need to know is the name of a good electronics recycler.



You can go out and fetch yourself a USB jump drive for about 20 bucks that will have a (minimum) 10 times the storage of a Zip disk.



The technology is not only obsolete, it is a dangerous way to store data. Hopefully, you aren't storing anything important on one of those relics. One reason they aren't around was because they were essentially junk.



</answer>

<answer from>



Melissa O
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



While yes, it's nearly impossible to rid a laptop entirely of fingerprints, the cleaning/polishing cloth that should have come with your MacBook does a good job at removing them.  Also, Monster makes a product that is basically like a baby wipe for electronics (you can find them at BestBuy, Circuit City, probably WalMart and such).  These work well for removing fingerprints and do a decent job at preventing them for a bit too...I think the cleaning solution is an electronic specialized type of Windex formula.  But word to the wise...don't try Windex, it can create this weird gummy film if you're not careful that is very difficult to get off and in other places it mattes the machine case in a weird way that never goes away.



</answer>

<answer from>



Abdul N

<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



What do you mean by saying, "because of my integrated microphone"? If you mean that you want to record using the integrated microphone, there are many ways to do so.

<answer from>



marie z

<answer>



when  we  had  highspeed  over  phone  line  yeesh  it  was  CRAP  allways  gooin  out  tho  we  re;late  it  to  ther  isp  tds  lol  still  well  itd  go  out  during  bad  weather  they  never  seemed  ta  get  people  out  fast  enough  an  yea  sence  weve  switched  to  cable  aka  roadrunner  like  no  issues  occasionally  the  modem  needs  re-booting



"for  you"  depends  on  what  youll  be  dooing  me?  few  games  mostly  jus  surf  an  listen  ta  net  music  youtube  loads  FASTER  then  it  plays  soo  awesomeness  there  lol  works  great  fer  uo  too  lol



</answer>



<answer from>



Melissa O
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 135 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Tough call if both are available.  I have always and will only use cable (until I can afford to have a partial T run into my house!).  You get better speed and a more reliable signal (in my experience).  DSL's biggest selling point is that you don't have to split bandwidth from the trunk with other area subscribers.  While I live in a huge neighborhood where most people use cable Internet, I have lightning speeds that impress even the most skeptical of users.  DSL is quick and the speed they sell you is all yours (never fluctuates)...but the last thing you want to have to do is run (and pay for) a dedicated landline specifically for a DSL connection, have the garbage truck back into the box where the line terminates and kill your connection, then wait in the long service line the provider puts you in to have a tech come out and repair the trunk...it's a pain (this happened to my client a few years back and cost his company several hundred thousand dollars in lost sales).  Cable is buried, marked and fast...and doesn't require a separate line.



</answer>



<answer from>



Justin W
Member since: 28 May 2008
Total points: 3886 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Cable has the potential for faster speeds.  It's a bigger piece of wire.  But you'll pay more for those speeds.  It also gives you the advantage to completely remove your phone from your home.  Thus no more phone bill (put that money to the internet cost).  You can use a voip program like skype for your home phone. It's not very secure though.  Everyone connects to 1 satellite, and that satellite connects to the hub.  So someone just needs to introduce a sniffer to the satellite and they can track all of your traffic.



DSL is more secure at lower speeds. (it's not noticeable unless you're an active torrent user)  It's your connection to the switch board.  However the further you live from the hub (Next door compared to 2 blocks away) will affect your download rate.  (Further from the hub, further for the information to travel, more people in front of you connecting.)



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



What is the best laptop for gaming under £500?



I'm on a budget of £500 and i want a laptop that can play games such as Bioshock. thx 4 anyones help.



</question>



<answer from>



Jag
Member since: 29 June 2007
Total points: 18137 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Desktops



Laptops & Notebooks



Computer Networking



</answer from>



<answer>



Laptops suck for gaming.



You can not upgrade the video card.



The exact same hardware specifications operate 20-35% slower in a laptop.



Few laptops have video cards that are capable of reasonable frame rates.



Do a search here for all of the poor smucks that didn't listen to this advice and got a laptop anyway.  Most are complaining about poor frame rates or low quality graphics.  Many ask how to upgrade their laptop's video card.



</answer>



<answer from>



Chris C
Member since: 10 September 2008
Total points: 194 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You will not find a gaming laptop for under $500. A desktop that will play most games okay is possible. If you want a laptop get one WITHOUT an onboard chipset. That way you can upgrade the graphics card. You also might have to upgrade RAM if you buy one under $500. You should measure cost of upgrades and laptop versus cost of more expensive laptops.



</answer>



<answer from>



Simon C
Member since: 05 December 2007
Total points: 3726 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You won't be able to play it with good graphics or anything because the recommended requirements are an nvidia 7900 which is very high spec for a laptop, but I am sure you can customise a dell for about 500 quid that will run it acceptably.



You want something that meets this spec:



Minimum System Requirements:



CPU: Pentium 4 2.4GHz Single Core processor



System RAM: 1GB



Video Card: Direct X 9.0c compliant video card with 128MB RAM (NVIDIA 6600 or better/ATI X1300 or better, excluding ATI X1550).



http://www1.euro.dell.com/content/produc...



Probably the second one from the left is your best bet, but it exceeds your budget slightly.



</answer>

<original file>3613.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk116773.txt</current file name>




<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



cavanaug...
Member since: 21 April 2006
Total points: 148 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How can I load a game on a second harddrive?



Our computer has two seperate hard drives to load games on.  My daughter would like to move her sims and itunes onto one of them so our other programs will go faster.  How can I get the computer to switch harddrives  so she can be able to load her games on the other?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



To install a program to the second drive of your computer, you will have to reinstall the program.  When you go through the install, you will need to select either the custom or advanced install.  That will give you the option to select which hard drive to install it on.



Since the program is already installed, you will want to UNINSTALL it first so that you do not end up with two copies (one on each drive) of the program.



</answer>




<original file>3614.html</original file>

<question from>



tauheed k
Member since: 04 November 2008

</question from>



<question>



What is cache memory?



types of cache memory,how its work how it looks



</question>



<answer from>



yo yo yo
Member since: 26 May 2008
Total points: 115 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The Cache Memory is the memory that is saved for important purposes like accessing your Hard Drive



</answer>



<answer from>



barbara....
Member since: 01 October 2007
Total points: 122 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



temporary folders



</answer>



<answer from>



Chelse Michelle-Mae
Member since: 17 September 2007
Total points: 228 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Cache memory is random access memory (RAM) that a computer microprocessor can access more quickly than it can access regular RAM. As the microprocessor processes data, it looks first in the cache memory and if it finds the data there (from a previous reading of data), it does not have to do the more time-consuming reading of data from larger memory.



Source(s):



=]



</answer>



<answer from>



Crehl
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 146 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is when programs, such as browsers, download/produce a file, and save it to your hard drive temporarily. If you're streaming music, you can re-play the same track while only downloading it once.



There's also hardware cache on CPUs, this is small but fast memory that it uses to improve speed.



</answer>



<answer from>



E P
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 239 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



On board dedicated temporary storeage for a device. Think of it as a device's personal RAM.



</answer>



<answer from>



Biplab
Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 670 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



cache memory is a small amount of memory situated in the processor itself. It works as a buffer for most frequently used data or execution code so that processor do not have to look into RAM each time when something is required. Since cache is pretty much faster than RAM it is desirable to have the required data and codes to be in cache as much time as possible. This improves speed of the computer as a whole.!! Then some one might say why not increase cache and remove RAM altogether ? Actually cache memory is very expensive, usually a present day processor has 16 kb of level 1 cache and 1 or 2 mb of level2 cache.



Level1 and level2 are types of cache. level1 is faster and of lesser amount while level2 is relatively slower. There may be even level3 cache memory as well.



Source(s):



I am a computer engineer.



</answer>



<answer from>



dewcoons
Member since: 25 April 2006
Total points: 66552 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Cache memory is used as temporary storage used to hold data for a hardware device until the hardware is ready for it. to allow the device to run faster.  For example, a processor will have a small cache so that when it loads a program, it can hold the next few commands in the cache and have them ready for processing, as that is faster than have to go back to the hard drive for each command.



It is also used on hard drives, CD drives, and floppies when writing to them. Often the computer can send the information faster that it can be written to the disk, so the computer will "cache" the additional information until it is ready to write it.



</answer>

<answer from>



reapo
Member since: 21 June 2008

<answer>



You can't do it with just a USB cable, you need a crossover cable, cheap enough and available at most  pc stores.



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethernet_cr...



http://www.comms-express.com/products/cr...



</answer>



<answer from>



Good Daddy
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 222 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



you can do this with a cross-over cable, but the network settings may be a little complicated.



your best bet is to go to walmart (just cuz they're the cheapest) and get a USB pen/flash drive. A 2GB flash drive will only cost about $15.



plug it into your desktop, copy all the data you wanna move over too the flash drive, then plug it into your laptop and copy over again. use it just like a floppy disk to move data, its that simple.



</answer>

<question>



Should I get XP 32-BIT or XP 64-BIT?



I currently have a vista laptop and is currently 64-bit. I'm a bit of a gamer so whenever I play games on my laptop it tends to lag.. video card is Geforce 7150m. I've heard that XP gives more FPS than Vista. I'm just wondering what would make me have more FPS;XP 32-bit or XP 64-bit.



ps:I have around 200gb of hardrive and 4.00gig ram



</question>



<answer from>



jamorama...
Member since: 08 February 2008
Total points: 929 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I have heard of people having problems downgrading to xp, but i htink there are tuts out there.



Here is the problem:



The FPS difference from Vista to XP will not be worth the price. You have a Nvidia 7150m. That is a "piece of sh*t" if you're talking about gaming... You'll should be happy playing most games at low or medium settings...



also... if you really think you will benefit from it, you should get 64 bit bcause 32 bit only recognizes around 3.2 gb of ram.



~You have to get a new computer... since you cannot upgrade laptop gpus very easily.



EDIT: In response to Gijoe or w/e... he is WRONG. 32 bit will not recognize 4 gb of ram. PERIOD.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks you very much



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



gijoe170...
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 268 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



32-bit version.



When they deploy 64 bit games that you intend to buy then make the move over.  The processor will spend it's time as well as your memory to drive 32-bit emulators to support all the applications and games you use now.



If ever you feel the real need to use more than 4 GB of RAM then you will also need to transistion over to 64 bit (or buy a motherboard that supports extensible addressing to make use of more than 4 BG of RAM).



XP does not use as much resources as Vista so I believe that your 4 GB will work out fine.



</answer>



<answer from>



Gemini
Member since: 25 October 2007
Total points: 295 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



32-bit is more compatible with applications, drivers.
Vista is better at least because XP doesn't support DirectX 10 and Vista has more features (Ultimate version) and it is more secure. But I feel more comfortable with XP because the GUI works smooth.



</answer>



<answer from>



theother...
Member since: 27 August 2007
Total points: 2041 (Level 3)

xp won't improve frame rates by a noticeable amount, in fact, modern games tend to run better on vista
your limiting factor is the video card

<question>



How do i make my Internal 3.5" HDD to an External Hard Drive ?



how do i turn my Internal 3.5" HDD into an External Hard Drive ?



I want to change it into an external hard drive which doesnt need a power cable....and runs on USB.
Do i just need to buy an external hdd enclosure? and how do i change the jumper settings?



Is it possible to get an 3.5" external hdd enclosure that doesnt need a power cable?



</question>



<answer from>



Biplab
Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 678 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Buy a hard disk casing. Costs from 500 rs to 1000 rs in india.



</answer>



<answer from>



Rusty S
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 342 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, you need an enclosure. Make sure the enclosure works with either pata/sata depending on the type of drive you have. A lot of enclosures can now fit both types as well.



Typically you set the jumper to master unless otherwise noted.



</answer>



<answer from>



mnid007
Member since: 07 October 2006
Total points: 3094 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can't turn your internal hard drive into an external harddrive without the cables sticking out of the tower.



You will need an actual "external harddrive" and yes, those will run off of a USB cable.



Source(s):



A+ Certified
A.S. Computer Science
B.S. Information Technology



</answer>

<question>



I want to empty my computer of everything but windows?



how can i take all my pics, software, music etc away without deleting windows xp from my system?



</question>



<answer from>



sunnygir...
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 107 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



create a new user when it ask if you want to save or import stuff click "no"
or use your restore discs



and reinstall windows if it's been awhile it's a good idea



</answer>



<answer from>



E P
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 243 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Assuming you stored all your of these types of files in "My Documents", just go to "My Documents" and delete everything. This will have the same effect as making a new user, and deleting the old user without saving any user info.
Creating a new user option will also delete all preferences and usage data.



Depending on how "deleted" you want everything to be there are additional steps to take to completely clean your system of person files/data.



A complete wipe of your hard drive and rewriting 64 time with 32 random codes overwrite is very time consuming, but cheaper than replacing the hard drive and doing a fresh install of windows.



</answer>



<answer from>

<question from>



Blaine H
Member since: 19 April 2007
Total points: 285 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



My pc screen is tilted?



Its real messed up. i was playing a game on my pc and now my screen is completeley tilted. the start button is on the right side and the top of the browser is on the left. i had this happen before but i didnt fix it.



</question>



<answer from>



matthew
Member since: 01 November 2008
Total points: 421 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Your screen is rotated 90 degrees counter clockwise.



You can right click on the desktop and chose properties (personalise in Vista) and correct it from there or:



if you are using an Nvidia based graphics card correct it in the Nvidia Control Panel,



If you are using an ATi based graphics card correct it in Catalyst Control Centre.



It's very easy, you are looking for screen rotation and to set it to zero. .



Best wishes



Matthew



</answer>



<asker's comment>



really helped me fix my screen! sounds so simple now.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



eglosker...

<question>



My computer runs really slow on start up, help please?

<question>



How do i clean a keyboard cover?



i have a clear plastic laptop keyboard cover... how do i clean it.?



</question>



<answer from>



David R
Member since: 17 December 2006
Total points: 14253 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Software



Laptops & Notebooks



</answer from>



<answer>



Keyboard Protectors are durable and can be cleaned quickly and easily with soap, bleach, most popular health care cleaning products, and a damp sponge to help stop the spread of germs.



</answer>



<answer from>



7th Sign
Member since: 04 February 2008
Total points: 136 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



soap and water



Source(s):



infomercials



</answer>

<question>



Can anybody recommend me a good laptop?



well my mum and dad are gonna get me one for this christmas and i dont really know aout which make is the best or what not. so i am looking to you for help. what i would like is a decently fast laptop that can run many programs well and has a decent amount of memory and i think thtas about it for my specifications and the price rangfe is about £300.

</question>



<answer from>



MidgetGe...
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 269 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



In an article I read in a magazine,
it said that Sony and Toshiba
are the most reliable makes of laptop
and far more unlikely to break down.



I have a Sony VAIO and is very, very good.
It has never given me any problems.
It's very quick an reliable.



My sister has a Toshiba.
She's had it for years, and it's stayed the same.
It's still as good as it was when she first bought it.



So I would highly recommend one of those.



I used to have a Dell and didn't last very long.
It randomly broke and started going really slowly,
not long after i bought it.



I hope this helped. (:



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



Keeping the laptop on stand by is a better idea.
When you start the laptop from switch off, it consumes 3X power .
Standby uses lesser power.



Also have you tried hibernating your laptop? that will give you a 10 times faster start up.



</answer>

Yeah I have it in stand by all the time but if you wont to shut it down go do a Hibernate is shuts down your laptop but allows a quick start up. But shutting down is better for battery life because you battery doesn't live forever and even if is charging it can mess up your charger.

Benny-Moo

Jeremy T
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 2654 (Level 4)

<answer>



I'd recommend the hd4850, I thinks it a little more expensive then the ones your looking at (maybe $10, it depends on what deals you find)



9600GT is the budget card of Nvidia's 9000 series.  the 8800GT is the average/slightly high end card of Nvidia's older 8000 series.  Its hard to say which is the better card.  I haven't used either of them and haven't been able to find good benchmarks.



the HD4850 is the cheaper of the two cards in ATI's current generation (4000 series).



</answer>

however, the second digit, 6, indicates it is a 'budget' chip. whereas the 8800 might be more robust, but in similar pricerange cause its older.



but who knows, maybe the 9K has some added features.

<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



anthonyl...
Member since: 30 December 2007
Total points: 68 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Is the ATI Radeon HD 3200 integrated?



If so how can i get another graphics card if it is integrated? Would i have to get another motherboard?



</question>



<additional details>



So for instance if i bought a top of da line graphics card and put it in i could still use my new graphics card right or will it use both.



</additional details>



<answer from>



winD
Member since: 22 October 2006
Total points: 483 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Usually, there is a slot, called AGP, or PCI-E for newer graphic card, in your motherboard, so you can upgrade your integrated graphic card using an add-on graphic card.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks man :)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



ljason8e...
Member since: 30 June 2007
Total points: 5291 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes that's integrated. If its a laptop, you're out of luck, but if it's a desktop, it'll have a PCi-e slot for a video card.



If you buy another video card, you'll have to disable the integrated one, but it's easy to do in the BIOS. Just make sure your power supply has enough amps on the 12v rail to get enough power to the new card.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mercuri
Member since: 06 May 2008
Total points: 4551 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Software



Laptops & Notebooks



</answer from>



<answer>



It is integrated.  Is this a laptop?  Because you cannot upgrade the motherboard/video cards on laptops.



</answer>

<question>



Need help with using both audio ports...?



I have 2 audio ports...one in the front and other at the back...but i can use only one at time if i plug in head phones in both of them the sound shifts to only the one at the back....
So is there any thing i can do to use both of them to listen audio at the same time.?

</answer from>



<answer>

<question from>



babypock...

<question>



Why can’t I get ALL pictures onto my 2GB memory card with an external card reader?



I’m trying to load a couple hundred pictures onto a 2GB SD card.  About half of them will transfer then I can’t get anymore on.  An error message of ‘Can’t create a directory for file “Named Picture”’ comes up and then the transfer stops.  Even after removing the supposedly offending file, no other files will go on.  However, ‘Properties’ shows that about 2% of my card’s space is used by these pictures and there’s still lots of space left on the card.



I am trying to transfer them all at once.

<additional details>

</additional details>



<answer from>



ac07039
Member since: 31 January 2006
Total points: 295 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



Anonymou...
Member since: 18 August 2008
Total points: 111 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Try Scanning The File (your images) For Viruses and errors and format the Memory card To a NTFS if it cant or a FAT

<answer from>



michael
Member since: 09 February 2008
Total points: 149 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

Try creating a new directory on the card, and then copy the files into that.



</answer>



<answer from>



ELfaGeek
Member since: 18 February 2007
Total points: 49804 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Software



</answer from>



<answer>



‘Can’t create a directory for file “Named Picture”’



Is this a folder?  If so, it may be a protected Windows System Folder and can't be copied.



Open the folder and then copy (not Move) all the files within, to your USB drive.



</answer>

<original file>11933.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk22151.txt</current file name>




<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



Justdont...
Member since: 17 January 2007
Total points: 59 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



A few questions about SLI Technology?



1. Do I need a motherboard with SLI tech enabled to use a SLI graphics card? Do I need it to use 2 or more together?



Can two different graphics cards which both have SLI enabled be used together?



</question>



<answer from>



JC
Member since: 31 May 2006
Total points: 3720 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



A) Cards with SLI will function on their own in non-sli motherboards. SLI cards can still function on their own in SLI motherboards. Obviously you can't do SLI if you don't have an SLI mobo though.



B) Not unless they have the same core (G70, G80, etc) which usually has to do with being in the same series. For instance, the 9800M GTX and 9800M GT both use the G92 core. You could use those two together, as long as they both support SLI. This applies whether or not they have the same GPU and memory clock speeds, memory size, or are even made by the same manufacturer.



But you couldn't use the 9800M GT and the 9800M GTS together in SLI. The former is based on the G92 core, while the latter is based on the G94 core.



Hope this helps!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Mercuri
Member since: 06 May 2008
Total points: 4551 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Software



Laptops & Notebooks



</answer from>



<answer>



You need an SLI motherboard to use SLI.  You can use a single video card that's SLI capable in just about any board.  SLI only works with 2 or more video cards, otherwise it's not SLI.



If both video cards are compatible and from the same manufacturer, it is possible to SLI enable them.  However, the best results are achieved when you use two identical video cards.



</answer>



<answer from>



winD
Member since: 22 October 2006
Total points: 483 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



1. Yes, you need a motherboard with SLI enabled to use SLI graphic card



2. It depends on what will you do with your computer. If you use it just for typing, then you do not need more than one graphic card. It is a different case if you use your pc for gaming, which takes much resource.



3. SLI is a combination between 2 or more NVidia graphic cards. In ATI graphic card, it is called CrossFire. It is better to use the same NVidia graphic card to run SLI.



</answer>



<answer from>



Fox
Member since: 24 February 2008
Total points: 6515 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can use a video card that is SLI capable without actually utilizing SLI or having a second PCI-E slot. You need to have a mobo capable of SLI and the same graphics cards in order to use SLI.



</answer>



<answer from>



johnkutz...
Member since: 15 September 2008
Total points: 930 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



1. yes you need a motherboard with sli tech.
2. no the graphics cards have to be the same for example 2 8800gt will work together but a 8800 gt and a 8800 gtx will not..



</answer>



<answer from>



ham
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 90 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



do your own research



</answer>

<question>



Can you fit more than 6GB RAM in a computer ?



have you heard of a computer with more than 6GB RAM ?



-i was born Nov.12 1989



</question>



<answer from>



oni-kun ^^
Member since: 27 July 2008
Total points: 9120 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Programming & Design



Software



Other - Computers



Laptops & Notebooks



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Yes but the motherboard has to be compatible and there has to be a 64-bit OS running on the system for it to read. Usually this is rare and it'll truncate the number to 5-4-3.2GBs even depending on how it was made.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



ok



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



John D
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 454 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Many motherboards are able to support 16GB of ram, and often more. But the difficulty of getting 16GB of ram is complicated because you need to find 4x4gb and a windows OS that runs x64bit. Is it worth it? No. If you use a home computer 2-4 GB is enough. Servers need more to support everything, so they usually use 8GB.



</answer>



<answer from>



airdogsp...
Member since: 22 September 2008
Total points: 214 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Servers are made for that much RAM (and more)  but normal home Computers don't have that much.  I guess if you bought 2gb Rams and put 4 in  you could get 8gb but thats probably the highest.



</answer>

<question>



Are MSI motherboards good?



MSI P6NGM-L Motherboard CPU Bundle - Intel Core 2 Quad Q6600 Processor 2.40GHz OEM-----Is this a good bundle?



</question>



<answer from>



Gzus
Member since: 12 June 2008
Total points: 4277 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Computer Networking



</answer from>



<answer>



Depends, how much? MSI boards aren't bad, but that Quad is not exactly up to date anymore.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kitty
Member since: 31 May 2008
Total points: 107 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on your application. If you don't want to play games, or run graphically intensive applications, it will be fine. MSI motherboards on the whole are average, and do have a risk of being poor quality in their lower end models. This board will be obsolete for most things within 8 months.



I generally advise against micro-ATX boards, primarily due to the expense involved of memory, lack of space, and reduced functionality to fit in a smaller space.



If I were you, I'd pass on this and wait until I could afford to drop a few hundred more on a 780i or 790i.



http://www.tigerdirect.com/applications/...



</answer>

a) I can't tell any difference in speed or anything like that.



b) the crucial.com scan I did beforehand said that my computer has a maximum of 2GB RAM with 2 slots. But it said both slots were empty and that no memory was installed (when there was 512MB installed and occupying the rear slot) and at the very top of the results it said that my system currently had the maximum memory installed. All very confusing.



c) the crucial.com scan that I did after putting in the new RAM had EXACTLY the same scan results as the one I did prior to installing the upgrades. It also still made no sense whatsoever, claiming that my system simultaniously had the maximum memory installed and also no memory installed and both slots empty.



Can someone explain what is happening? Do I have to acctivate the upgrades somehow? <answer from>



Mercuri
Member since: 06 May 2008
Total points: 4540 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Software



Laptops & Notebooks



</answer from>



<answer>



Right-click my computer and select properties to see how much RAM you currently have installed on your computer.  You must have SOME ram working if you're computer's booting up as it won't run at all without RAM.  More RAM is NOT equal to more speed.  You'll only notice a difference in memory intensive applications or if your computer was always low on ram before.



</answer>



<answer from>



John P
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 124 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



right click on your task bar (the itty-bitty icons next to the time in the bottom right corner of your monitor) then click on task manager, then when it opens click on the tab that says "Performance" it will graphically show you your CPU Usage and your Page File history, basically if your using up a lot of ram it will demonstrate that in the bottom graph, and it will demonstrate how hard your processor is working in the top graph, if the top one is under 75% your computer is just fine, if the PF usage, depending on your available RAM, is around 500-650 MB your computer is fine, if it's over you have too many things running that you dont know about, if it's under, your at like lightning speed.



</answer>

<answer>



Hi Friend, As you say that your usb port din't recognize your phone and it start charging your phone. so I request you to try connecting other device such as card reader, usb mouse or keyboard see whether it is working properly or not.

Or some phone has the function that when you connect your phone to the pc at that time the phone display the option such as PC SUITE, MASS STORAGE etc.
Check for that setting also on your phone



I hope this information is useful for you

<question>



8800GTX (768Mb) V's ATI 4870 (1Gb) which is better?



Add as much detail as you can please.

</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Without a doubt, the more modern ATI 4870 is the best.
The Nvidia 8800 series is growing old and is now superceded by the 9XXX series. The 9800 GT on up is a better comparison and, quite frankly, it is a toss up. The avid gamers I know prefer the ATI cards.



</answer>

<question from>



html_dns

</question from>



<question>



Advanced computer science question, the acrynym invloving DDR3 RAM and DRAM?



I am reading a book on memory management and stumbled across something interesting and decided to do some investigation. The four presets of ram include
DRAM (Dynamic RAM)
SDRAM (Synchronous Dynamic RAM)
SRAM (Static RAM)
VRAM (Video Ram)
these presets have been extended with optimisation through various manufacturers that in return have slightly added new acronyms to the original presets. I did a google search for RAM and came up with:
--------------------------------------...
Kingston 4 GB PC3-10666 DDR3 RAM (KVR1333D3N9K2/4G)
Price Range: $242-440



--------------------------------------...
If u look carefully the description specifies "DDR3 RAM", my question is; Is this type of ram a branch from the DRAM preset but instead of using DDR3 DRAM they use DDR3 RAM because DRAM is considered by default?



sorry if my wording doesn't make sense, i will try and explain it with an analogy. Like for example instead of expressing 10 m as 10.00 m the .00 is allready assumed. is this the same with DRAM and RAM?



</question>

Yashwanth N

<answer>



Hey,



*



Connect DVD Drive into either HDD connector(HDd Header) or to Floppy Connector(Floopy Header) through bus..(see pic in link)



*  Then install DVD software to PC...



* Enjoy



Source(s):



http://www.techiwarehouse.com/i/Motherbo...



</answer>



<answer from>



waldo_mc...
Member since: 16 December 2007
Total points: 8067 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I should be fairly straightforward.Switch the PC off .Open the case.The existing CD burner sits in a bay and is connected to the PC by a power (red & black wires) and a flat grey data lead.The data lead connects to the PC by plugging it into a slot on the motherboard but you will not need to touch that.



So swapping the CD for a DVD burner should be a simple as unplugging power & data lead from the CD burner and taking it out of the bay it's screwed into.You then fit the DVD device and reconnect power and data leads.Replace the PC cover.Switch the PC back on and reconfigure the BIOS to recognise the new device.Windows should then recognise it and install any new drivers it mi9ght require.



</answer>



<answer from>



bljzzgrl
Member since: 26 January 2008
Total points: 20931 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Desktops



Laptops & Notebooks



Printers



</answer from>



<answer>



1.  Determine what type of CD burner you currently have inside your tower (IDE or SATA)?



If this is a laptop please let us know.



This is pretty easy, if there is a flat gray ribbon like cable it is IDE.  If it is narrow red ribbon, it is a SATA cable.



2.  Decide if you want to replace the CD Burner all together or just add the DVD burner to the system (some people like to have both).  If you already have 3 other drivers in the system you will have to replace it.



3.  Find a DVD burner based on the information above in #1.



4.  Once you get the drive.  Turn off the computer.  Un-plug everything from the back of the computer and move the tower to a location that is easy to work on (usually a flat service, preferably a table.



5.  Remove the side of the case and locate the current drive.



If you are replacing the drive:



Unplug the current drive from both the power and data transfer cable (IDE or SATA).  Unscrew the  drive and slide it out the front of the case.



Replace the old one with the new one, screw it back into place and connect the wires back up to the drive. -- Your done.



If you are adding the drive:



Change the jumper setting on the back of the drive (I would suggest Cable select if this is an IDE drive.  If SATA just leave jumper as set)



Put the drive in empty slot in the case and screw in place.



Hook up power cable.



If IDE hook 2nd connector of the IDE cable to the back of the drive.
If SATA, plug into open SATA port on motherboard with the cable that came with the drive.



You are done.



Replace side of case, hook back up and let the system boot up.



-- Will watch for any additonal details and will update.  BTW it is always helpful to know the make and model of the computer (if it is a HP, Dell,etc) or the make and model of the motherboard so that we can give you the best information.



</answer>



<answer from>



ebox1349
Member since: 31 January 2007
Total points: 3171 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Other - Computers



Laptops & Notebooks



Monitors



</answer from>



<answer>



Do you need both drives?
With the mains cable unplugged from the PC to avoid the risk of electric shock, take off the side panel and look inside your PC.
If you do not need both drives then simply look at which way round the connecting cables go and replace the CD-RW with the DVD-RW. All you really need to check is that the jumper switch on the new drive is in the same place as the old one. This switch determines if the device is M (Master) or S (Slave) or CS (Cable Select)as long as it is the same as the drive you remove there will be no problems.
If you want to keep both drives you most likely need a new Data Ribbon cable to connect it to unless the HD and CD-RW are on different cables. Again just copy the way the cables fit on the drive in place and add the new DVD-RW as the slave drive to the old CD-RW, check the jumper switch on the back is set to S before you put in.
If you have to add it as a new drive because the HD and CD are on one cable, you need a new cable (IDE data ribbon unless its a SATA DVD drive) and set the jumper to master and connect one end of the cable to the drive the other to the motherboard next to or just behind the one for the HD. Connect the power cables and reboot.



Source(s):



Experience - Senior Technician - Electronbox Spain



</answer>



<answer from>



Cute
Member since: 12 September 2008

<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



hi mate



allthough by getting two 8800 ultras would seriously improve the performance of games like crysis and up and coming games however allthough the 8 series cards are pretty good why not buy a single gtx260(http://www.aria.co.uk/Products/Component... which would cost around the same as a single 8800ultra however with improved specs in the gtx260 you will be able to run games without any problems



also taking into consideration the excellent processor and low latency ddr2 memory this will also combine well with the next generation nvidia gtx series



however you may also consider the excellent range of 9 series cards,especially the amazing 9800gtx(http://www.aria.co.uk/Products/Component... from being around £20 cheaper than what you were going to pay for the 8800ultra,its specs are also superior aswell



these include a 738mhz core clock and 512mb of ddr3 memory running at 1836mhz,along with the sizable 256bit memory bus and Microsoft DirectX 10 and Shader Model 4.0 support the 9800gtx also has a "physX" processor aswell,these were once only avalible when you purchased a ageia physx pci card costing around £150 however when nvidia purchased "ageia" late last year they decided to include the physx processor on their high-end cards



the 9800gtx pound for pound is a bettter card than the 8800gtx and taking into consideration the cost of the 8800gtx on release the 9800gtx is around £150 cheaper,making it possible for gamers on a budget to keep up there with the hard core gamers



for example 2 x Asus GeForce 9800 GTX+ (http://www.aria.co.uk/Products/Component... would set you back around £260,this is still significantly cheaper than a single 8800gtx,and much faster



even the mid-range 9 series cards like the BFG GeForce 9600 GT OC 512MB(http://www.aria.co.uk/Products/Component... are excellent purchases,and have some strong specs including a 675mhz core and 512mb of ddr3 memory running at 1800mhz,these are strong specs and a excellent card to be used in a sli configuration



in respect to the graphic cards memory,  2 512mb cards would be more enough and wouldnt affect the overall gaming performance,and with 4gb of system memory and the QX6850 you will have one hell of a p.c



any problems let me know



good luck mate !

Hello,



If you really looking to kick those games in the bucket, I would consider one card. Sli and Crossfire are not 100% transferrable. You're looking at 75-90%. Plus with two cards, more glitches, bugs, and other problems. The best option is one super card.



You can choose the latest nvidia card or ati card.



Right now it seems ATI has the best card out. But you're looking at $550+ dollars for 2gb card.

<question>



Who's driver do you install for a VGA controller?



After looking threw this site I'm a bit confused. Hopefully this will help other people like me. I know what my PC's  make , model, and that I can get down loads from the manufacture, But a video card was add'ed after (to run some Pc games) for my PC. I also know that I can get download's from the video card maker.



Going into device manager I have a  yellow "?"  in OTHER DEVICES with VGA controller( VGA comptible) in a sub. cat.



"New Hardware found" runs each time I reboot, yet everytime it's unable to find anything.



My question is this who's down load do I download to install so that my VGA controller (driver?) works with the vidoe card , works with the  PC.



I  have : compaq presario Mod# s6300nx, running windows XP, using geforce fx5200 agp card.



If the controller (driver) is to follow the video card maker then does this download I retrieve need to be the latest download for this card or a download from the year that I purchased the card?



Lastly, (trouble shooting note) within the last 4 days I tried downloading from nvida for my geforce fx5200. I saved the download to a CD. later after I  install the information the color on my screen went from the maney colors I had to only like 8 color's It looked like a film neg. I'm at a lost as to what went wrong.



</question>



<answer from>



henry w
Member since: 29 February 2008
Total points: 144 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It does sound a bit like your PC is still running from the onboard video card. If you look at the back of your case, does it have one VGA/DVI port, or two? If there are two, one near where you plug your keyboard and mouse in, then it's likely running from onboard graphics. If you hit "delete" on startup, then you should be able to access the bios and turn off the onboard graphics. Make sure you save the BIOS on exiting by pressing F10.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jeff C
Member since: 01 March 2007
Total points: 962 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You should be able to download the latest drivers from NVidia and have them work for your gforce fx5200. You shouldnt have to use the drivers from a year ago when you bought the card. (when you bought it, it should have came with a driver and software cd)



Second, I would advise against saving the download to your cd. I would save it to your hard drive and install it from there. During the installation, it may try to extract files from where the install is running from. It may have issues trying to extract and save files to your cd. That could also be the issue with your display looking bad.



(note: i created a download folder on my hard drive, then everytime i download something, i put it in its own folder for easy access)



</answer>

<question>



Coverters/ Adapters? What can I use it for?



I am visiting Ireland and France. I bought a converter and adapter. The only thing is that the converter says not to use laptops on it. Is there one you can use laptops with? Or has anyone used it against their suggestion? Help me out!



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



You need the proper power adapter for your Laptop.  You need to find out what the input requirements are for your Laptop.  Your user's manual should spell that out.  Your Laptop manufacturer should have one on the website that you may be able to purchase.  Don't just use any adapter.  Again, it has to meet the power input requirements of your Laptop.  Then on top of that, it has to be for 220V as it's input for foreign travel.



</answer>

<question from>



Abyss Of My Mind

<question>



Can a Sandisk memory stick pro duo corrupt instantly?



It is an official 512 mb memory card that came with the phone (W800i), all of a sudden the phone froze and would not respond until I removed the memory card - then my PC wouldn't read the card either!



Is it possible that the card is corrupted?
Or
Would it be the phone?
As I say the PC and the phone cannot detect the card.



Can a card like this just all of a sudden wipe all the data on it and stop working?



The card is about 5 years old though.



It is an official 512 mb memory card that came with the phone (W800i), all of a sudden the phone froze and would not respond until I removed the memory card - then my PC wouldn't read the card either!



Is it possible that the card is corrupted?
Or
Would it be the phone?
As I say the PC and the phone cannot detect the card.



Can a card like this just all of a sudden wipe all the data on it and stop working?



The card is about 5 years old though.



</question>



<answer from>



Aziz
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 151 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I encountered a similar problem with a micro SD that came with one of  Nokia's cell-phones.



What happened is we took out the card and when we put it back in the phone would not recognize the card, but the PC did and the card was fine, so we took it in to see what the problem was and it turned out that one of the copper pins were out of place or bent.



but your saying both the phone and the pc don't recognize it, then;



1. it could be old
2. damage (magnetized, cracked, bent, etc.)
2. the phone and the pc pins are out of place (unlikely)



5 years is a long time my friend...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I bet your right, it is a very old card.



I'll buy a new one.



</asker's comment>

<question from>



stustoki...
Member since: 22 February 2008
Total points: 105 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What type of hardware and software would be needed for an IT Support help desk?



Thanks



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Hardware:
*A decent computer : urgent calls require fluent computers, HP COMPAQ computers are ideal for business laptops
*Wireless headset + phone, vOIP = a plus, try helping a client with the phone in one hand and operating the computer with the other
*An extra monitor, so dual monitors can be used



Software:
*A call registerring program/ticketing system/... There's many free online php packages that do this, but this mostly depends on how your helpdesk will work. Can customers report problems via phone, email or website altogether, or one exclusively? You will need to track open calls, submit calls, add comments and perhaps establish a knowledge base for future reference AND for employees that might be hired in the future.
I would reccomend NOT using email exclusively, but a ticketing system. If you'd like to know why, I would gladly elaborate about this via mail (IM_geek@ymail.com).
*A screensharing program, if you're offering some kind of IT tech support. Teamviewer (www.teamviewer.com) is perfect! IT can be used freely or you can buy a license. Commercial (=multiple) use requires a paid license. Fantastic piece of software. I've used LogMeIn, Go2Assist, kVNC, Radmin viewer, etc, but Teamviewer takes the cake
*A program to keep track of remote connection (again, if you plan to offer IT TECH support and need to log into remote servers).
VisionApp Remote Desktop is good, free alternative for this (http://www.visionapp.com/resources/downl...



IT Support is underestimated and extremely, extremely important. Implementing a solution with a client is only half the work.



Source(s):



Experienced, Microsoft Business Solutions certified support engineer for an IT Solution center.



</answer>

<question>



Need help deciding on new computer?



I am buying a new desktop and i'm having trouble understanding what i need. There's a lot of new stuff out there since i last bought. I mainly use my computer for watching videos on itunes and web surfing. I want this to be like a media center. blue ray player, hi-def, tv tuner w/ pvr. Not sure if i need a really good video card, expensive ram (ex corsair dominator) etc. or is that stuff just for gaming. will a quad vs duo make a difference? Please help with some advice. Thinking of buying from ibuypower cause they seem to have more options.



</question>



<answer from>



Mr.Volta...
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 121 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



you don't need high RAM / Graphic card if you don't play computer games



1 GB RAM and any video card would do the work.
I'd even say don't buy a branded PC cause they're expensive
get yourself a custom assembled one.
You can get great stuff under 200$ by that method.



</answer>



<answer from>



SelenaK
Member since: 05 September 2007
Total points: 526 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you plan to use it as a media center, it would be best if you had the dual core and a good video card. In particular, be sure that the card has its own onboard memory (and will not be using the computer's memory).



Also important, make sure that the computer has all of the media ports you'll need to hook up to the various entertainment center equipment you plan to use.



You might want to go to your nearest Best Buy or Circuit City and take a look at the options on the computers in their home entertainment sections. Write down the options and then compare with what's available at iBuyPower



</answer>

<original file>index;_ylt=AgMIIY3Y7OQaXvuUEyyO1.7UMBV0346.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk33988.txt</current file name>



<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



Mike Bellew
Member since: 25 September 2006
Total points: 601 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What do i do about about a virus that causes my laptop to shutdown every time i open the cd drive?



a virus or not?
i just dont know
i run avast but it doesnt find anything
what do i do



</question>



<additional details>



funny thing screw was loose and the drive wasnt connected completly and must have shorted and cause pc to shutdown to not damage it so my pc is okay and i just have to push the drive back in as in frustration i pulled it too hard which led to me finding out that it came way out and wasnt connected



</additional details>



<answer from>



mike
Member since: 14 May 2008
Total points: 515 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



To me, it sounds like you have a short in your wiring.



No virus can instantly shut down a computer the second you hit a button. If the computer starts to shutdown (in the standard process), then you may have a virus.

However, my guess is that the drive is damaged in some way, and the computer shutsdown as a failsafe to prevent damage to it.



Test:

Start the computer and go into the BIOS (normally by hitting like F12 during the bootup sequence). Once inside, press the eject button on the drive. If the computer shuts down then, you know it is a hardware problem because a virus will not be running in the BIOS stage of the computer's startup. Remember, a virus is a program. Any program can be found and halted.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



as i said in details



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



crazykam...
Member since: 13 March 2007
Total points: 1063 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



get McAffee. its the best, if there is something on your computer- it'll find it. if not..
Your drive could be bad?



</answer>



<answer from>



Jon
Member since: 04 June 2007
Total points: 1102 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



First of all, you scan it with other software. There aren't any antivirus programs that catch 100% of all the viruses on your PC.

Or try HijackThis! which can be downloaded at download.com. Let HijackThis scan your computer, then post your results on their communtiy forum, and let a supernerd tell you what to do.



</answer>

<answer from>



vsrumpel
Member since: 13 January 2007
Total points: 130 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Carefully turn your keyboard upside down over an old newspaper, then shake it and give it a few firm but careful taps, still holding it upside down get a soft brush like 1 of the previous answers said and brush between the keys. You could also buy a can of 'Air Duster' they are available from office supplies shops, & do the upside down thing again but spraying the pressurised air into the keyboard at the same time. Of course you could  buy a new keyboard, they are really cheap these days.



</answer>



<answer from>



MoishePi...
Member since: 31 January 2007
Total points: 2671 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



A new paintbrush is a good answer already given, but some additional steps:
o  With the PC off or locked, turn the keyboard upside-down and bag it (not too hard) on the desk, rapping the four edges, as opposed to the keys.
o  If a few keys are particularly dirty, or dirt's gone behind them, popping them off is easy (other than the space bar, which has a pivot and is a bit trickier to replace). A fine-tip screwdriver or a piece of strong thread are helpful. Just press them back in place when done.
o  A new keyboard may be less than $10 US; if you get another few years out of it, that's not a bad investment.
Thanks for reminding me to clean my own keyboard...
BTW, don't eat or drink by the PC to keep it cleaner and to help it to last longer.



</answer>

<category>

<question from>



nadeemma...
