</question from>



<question>



3Dfx Interactive Super Video 3D Accelerator board 45 million pixels/sec EV-3DFX-4 EV970327?



what is this and what does it do  3Dfx Interactive Super Video 3D Accelerator board 45 million pixels/sec EV-3DFX-4 EV970327;  COULD SOME1 PLZ HELP



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



It is an old PCI graphics card. 3DFX used to be used on the best graphic games, but a long time ago! http://www.trilogicuk.co.uk



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



It's a video accelerator card - a very old one!
Around ten to fifteen years ago, if you wanted to play games as well as do work on your computer, you'd plug this card into your computer, connect it to your video card with a cable & then plug your monitor into it.
For 3D gaming, this card would take over & run your games.

It's actually a 4Mb PCI Gullemot Maxi Gamer 3D using the 3dfx chipset - virtually an antique, but no use otherwise!



</answer>

Computers & Internet

</category>



<question from>



carl w
Member since: 20 July 2006
Total points: 112 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Laptop problems?



the light comes on to say that its on but it isnt workin.. wats wrong?



</question>



<additional details>



i need to keep all files on my hard drive so i cant clean start. what next?



</additional details>



<answer from>



DKHM
Member since: 22 January 2008
Total points: 3325 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Desktops



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



Try this:

1.  Unplug it from AC power, disconnect the cord from the PC.

2.  Remove the battery.

3.  Hold down the power button for 30 seconds to discharge all the capacitors.

4.*  Reinsert the battery.

5.  Reconnect AC power.

Try starting it now.



*If that doesn't work the first time, try holding the power button down for 60 seconds, and/or skipping step 4.



This is called a clean start, but if there are other problems such as the memory in it went bad, then it won't work.

Good luck.



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You shouldn't be using IE8 yet. It's still in beta, and is not considered stable.

To erase it, go to Add and Remove Programs in your control panel. On the left, click Windows Components. There you can uninstall IE8.

Where did you get IE8? If you didn't download it directly from Microsoft's website, you were most likely infected with some kind of malware.

insane_m...

<answer>



you havnt opened the case and taken anythink off and put it back?? if you have i would look there to begin with, CPU heatsink could have not been put back on proporly and overheat cut out on mobo kicking in.

dose anythink come on screen?? are there any beeps?? need more info!!

EDIT_

this sounds like a power supply issue, check the cables, disconnect anythink you dont really need to be connected. especially IPOD or MP3 players.

take all connections off from the back except for Keyboard, Mouse monitor and Power cable. then boot and see if it works.

<answer from>



Nick T
Member since: 03 August 2008
Total points: 269 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



When you power on your computer, tap the F8 key. Once your on the boot menu, scroll (using the arrow keys) down to the line which reads "boot with the latest known good configuration".



Another way....

When you computer is at the boot screen, tap the F2 key which will take you into the computer setup. At this screen you wil be able to disable "BIOS".



Once you have done this, save you changes, then re-boot your pc normally again.

Hope this helps.
Best regards,
Nick~



</answer>

<answer>



Yes he should be able to find some hot-spot to connect. But he must be careful as it is easy for someone with the equipment and knowledge to hijack his connect by posing as a host. It has been done many times at airports and coffee bars. Once that happens, all his passwords and details will be compromised. Better to use a secure connection at a hotel and avoid sensitive transactions and stick to emails.

<question from>

<question>



When i try to install my brother dcp-115c printer,when it comes to a page where it says plug in the usb  ?



cable to the pc and the machine and then it tells me to switch the machine on and wait for the installation process to continue.i did plug in the usb cable as stated but the installation does not continue,i tried several times but nothing happens
any suggestions to what this might be 
any help will be appreciated



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Try rebooting machine with USB cable out and printer off
When rebooted plug USB cable in and turn machine on
Windows should then come up with new hardware found and proceed to set it up. If it does not uninstall driver "Control Panel / device drivers \.
Right click printer and uninstall 
then try again with printer disconnected



</answer>

<question from>



Wrighty

Total points: 320 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How much ram is recommended for running Windows XP Service Pack 3?



I've just updated my old computer as I'm intending on donating it to a local charity, a friend of mine says that I need to update the ram but I have no clue about anything like that. He has written down the specifications of my old computer, so I'd be grateful if you could tell me how much ram I need to put in, or if there is enough in there already. I can't seem to be able to buy RAM for this system which is pretty annoying, as one of the shop attendants stated it was "SD RAM".

AMD Athlon XP 1600+
256MB RAM  (Capacity is 2048MB)

Cheers for your help.



</question>



<answer from>



brianthe...
Member since: 28 April 2006
Total points: 24667 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Add-ons



Desktops



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



hi jason



windows xp service pack 3 is just a enhanced version of service pack 2,the main aspect is the hotfixes and updates have been compressed into smaller installations



however as for memory theres no extra memory required for windows xp sp3,and your current configuration is more than enough



as for upgrading your memory i personally think you need "ddr ram" however go to http://www.crucial.com/ and use the crucial online memory tool



this will scan your system and give you a precise report on what memory you need for your p.c,and since this information is produced from scanning your p.c its information you can trust



as for pc shop attendants they are a law unto themselves,you go into a shop with a faulty fan and next thing you know your motherboard is shot and you need a new processor



save your money and contact me whenever you have any problems,hopefully i can save you a few quid ,as i have been in the same situation myself



as for how much to install,well i allways say double your current memory,so 512mb would be a decent amount,however if you can afford the full 2048mb then go for it,the increase in performance will be amazing,and for 2 x 1gb pc3200 modules you are only looking at around £52(http://www.aria.co.uk/Products/Component... thats for the Corsair 2GB PC3200 Value Select (2x1GB)



and thats another reason why it cannot use sd-ram,because sd-ram only comes in modules up to 512mb so 2048mb would need 4 modules



any problems let me know



good luck jason !



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Fantastic help thanks.



</asker's comment>

If you put in another 512MB, it'll be 768MB and therefore it'll be pretty quick.

jav

Total points: 252 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Hi everyone, i've got a problem with my new laptop and old printer?



its a new Advent laptop pre-installed with windows vista home premium. i was hoping to run my old hp deskjet f380 (2006 model) printer using a usb cable. i tried installing the software however and error message came up stating that i would need windows xp/98/version 7 etc.  In windows vista network options it does provide an option to connect any printer using a usb cable and windows would 'recognise' the printer - again this didnt work. all that happens is a message appears 'printing in progress' . I've also tried the hp website but couldn't make heads or tails of it- please help.



</question>



<answer from>



Jamie W
Member since: 06 May 2008
Total points: 2975 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



First uninstall any of the drivers that you installed with the disk. Do this by right clicking on Computer, selecting properites and hardware manager.  Find your printer, double click on it and uninstall the driver.  If you loaded any other programs uninstall them too.  Now, unplug the printer usb cable and reboot your computer.



Next go here: http://h10025.www1.hp.com/ewfrf/wc/softw... download the package and install it.  Alsoo on the top of the page it has a button to check if your drivers are correct, you might want to try this before you unisntall the drivers.  It might tell you to plug in your printer, if it doesnt, when it finishes plug in your printer.  It should detect it and have the right drivers installed.  This should work, good luck.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



many thanks everyone. The vista/hp f380 driver download from the hp website worked fine. many thanks. J



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



CAiiTLii...
Member since: 13 July 2008
Total points: 202 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



.



</answer>

<question>



Laptop problems again?



will a clean start wipe all my memory?



</question>



<answer from>



galoku
Member since: 17 January 2008
Total points: 2615 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



so a little light turns on , but nothing on the screen?

Try this little trick

Hold the Function key (Fn) and press the key with the picture of a screen/monitor
Tap it once, or twice see if it turns back on

Looks like this 
http://resources.online.nwtc.edu/mediase...

Might not work, but its worth a try

A clean start (ie windows reinstallation) will wipe ALL the files in your laptop



Hope that helps



</answer>

<question from>



Will K
Member since: 23 May 2008
Total points: 268 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Processor Help Please !



When people say a 2.4Ghz Dual Core Processor, does it mean that it is 2 x 2.4Ghz single processors or does it mean 2 x 1.2Ghz processors. Same with Quad Core. Also, What is FSB and Cache? What do they do?



</question>



<answer from>



Jung
Member since: 09 July 2008
Total points: 3578 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Horoscopes



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Hi Will

Dual core means just that &gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;. 2 x 2.4 GHz....Hyper-threading technology

FSB means front side bus and determines the speed of the computer . The Ram should match it as close as possible. Otherwise, what's the use of having this speed if you don't buy the Ram to push it.

Here is a good link to explain this...

http://www.directron.com/fsbguide.html



Source(s):



Computer Analyst / Programmer



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks man, that helped me alot ! Especially the guide that you posted.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



emperorh...
Member since: 02 August 2008
Total points: 131 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



hello .....  iwish my answer help you so



2.4ghz is asingle processor but with dual jobs  ......



fsb is front side bus  ........  cache is the cache memory and it is part of the processor bu it is untouchable



and they all about speed of the processor



</answer>



<answer from>



probably...
Member since: 05 June 2007
Total points: 6073 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Just to add to the above - the idea of cache is all about keeping things in fast memory so that when you need them again you don't have to go off and read them from somewhere else (which is slower).
There are different kinds of cache but it all follows the same principle.



</answer>



<answer from>



Cueball
Member since: 24 February 2008
Total points: 240 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



a 2.4ghz Dual Core Processor is two cores running at 2.4ghz each. If it was a quad, then you will have four processors running at 2.4ghz each. Your FSB (front side bus) is how fast the connection is from your CPU to you motherboard. Cache is memory. So it can retreive data qiucker and helps the cpu function better. The same in principle with hard drives. The more cache the better and quicker.



</answer>

<question>



Should i refill my ink cartridge or buy a new one.?



</question>



<answer from>



thoughts...
Member since: 06 August 2008
Total points: 1050 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>

<asker's comment>



Thank you



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Richard
Member since: 25 July 2008
Total points: 303 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you want accurate colors, buy new one. If you want to save money, then refill it. Or buy a CIS (continuous Ink System), this can save a lot of money in the long run



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_...



</answer>



<answer from>



homerunn...
Member since: 09 December 2007
Total points: 65 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Buy a new one it may cost more but you get better prints



</answer>



<answer from>



Brian F
Member since: 29 March 2008
Total points: 11295 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Laptops & Notebooks



</answer from>



<answer>



It really depends on the ink cartridges... Some are easily refilled, with others it is hit-and-miss how well they refill.



I have used inks from http://www.inksupply.com on both Cannon and Epson printers with great success.  Personally, if they don't sell "generic replacement cartridges" (Designed to be refilled) for your printer, I've found it to be very messy and has a high incidence of "air bubbles" during refills.

Unless you are using a lot of ink (several sets of cartridges per year, I'd suggest buying them already filled.



</answer>



<answer from>



yisgood
Member since: 22 February 2008
Total points: 3850 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Printers



</answer from>



<answer>



Refilling is a risky proposition. Yes it can work for a while, but there is the risk of damage to your printer which is not covered under warranty. Read http://ccs-digital.com/refills.html for more info. If you want to save money, get new compatible cartridges. For Epson try http://ccs-digital.com/ink.asp



For other brands try ebay but make sure they are new cartridges, not refilled or remanufactured, that they include the chip (some dealers expect you to take the chip off your old cartridges. This often doesnt work) and that there is a money back guarantee if they dont work.



</answer>



<answer from>



AMTI
Member since: 09 August 2008
Total points: 144 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



A new one, refilling will damage nozzles of the printer.



</answer>

Member since: 13 May 2007

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I'm in the business and have bought 100s of case fans and never got any without screws. I went to Cooler Guys and it appears they want 36 cents for 4 screws thou. Guess those fans dont come with screws. Geez. Try this guy:
http://cgi.ebay.com/Set-of-4-CASE-FAN-GR...
You can buy 2 sets of 4 and shipping will still be 1.50. That's 3.50 total for 8 screws. Also has black for 1.25 a set. Probably spend more than that on gas and sales tax if you go looking for them.

<question>



How do I find out what sound care I have??!?! HELP!!!!!!?



Okay it's kind of an emergency. I have the opportunity to get a free pair of Medusa headphones and I wanna know if my laptop's sound care is 5.1 surround sound. How do I find that out? It says I have a Sigmatel High Definition Audio CODEC, Bluetooth stereo audio, and Bluetooth hands-free audio. I got all that info from the System Information thing in my computer. If I brought up the wrong info, please give me directions and I will find the right info and post it, because I will be checking this question every few minutes for new answers. THANKS SO MUCH!!1

10 points to whoever gives me an answer!



</question>



<answer from>



Misery's company
Member since: 17 August 2008
Total points: 150 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



hit start, run, and type "dxdiag" then hit the "sound" tab and it should tell you the audio card your laptop has.  You can then take this info and go to the card manufacturer's site and look up your model.



Good luck!



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>

Kesava

<answer>



Neither is necessarily better, but I prefer Nvidia.

Right now, in my opinion, the 8800GT is an excellent card for most gamers, however Ati have just released the HD4850, which is only a little more expensive, and quite a bit better then the 8800GT.

What I'm trying to say is that its not like one brand is better then the other, they both compete with each other and are a better choice at one time or another. So you need to just make your decision off the cards and their performance, not the manufacturer.

Its the same with AMD and Intel, right now Intel is ahead in the cpu market, but not too long ago AMD was beating them.

So yeah, just check out the benchmarks on each card and judge by performance.

If you want my help in choosing the perfect card then please email me at kesava23@gmail.com



</answer>

countdwn...
Member since: 11 January 2007

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



They are NOT ram cards!  They are memory modules.  If your PC has two slots and you want 1GB total,  you should purchase (2) 512MB Modules.



I would recommend either Corsair or Kinston brand memory for compatiblity and reliablity.  You didn't specify what type of memory you have like SDRAM, DDR, DDR2, so you will first have to identify what type of memory you need before you can get a price.



Check the site below if you need help selecting memory or purchasing memory from.



Source(s):



http://www.crucial.com/



</answer>

<original file>index;_ylt=ArUNdRwWUfbeec9lk_I3wP_UMBV41cd.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk40461.txt</current file name>



<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



Joseph
Member since: 15 January 2007
Total points: 267 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



My laptop battery isn't registering on the computer, help?



I went on holiday for 3 weeks, and now my battery isn't working properly. It won't charge, and if I unplug the laptop with the battery in, the whole thing turns off. what's going on? how can i fix it? Looking for options other than "buy new battery"



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



It sounds like one of your battery cells might have died over the 3 weeks. If that isn't the case, one of the 3 pins that connect the battery to the laptop might be loose, which won't provide the necessary power to power up your computer.

There aren't really ways of fixing this, unless you open up the laptop battery (recommended you don't). And if you do buy a laptop battery, you might want to know that a battery is left best in a room temperature of around 20-25 degrees celsius, at a 40% charge. That's right, don't leave a laptop alone on full charge, otherwise it WILL stuff up.



</answer>

<category>

<question from>



michaelr...
Member since: 26 July 2008
Total points: 1296 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Lets see who is good with computers?



10101100= how many bytes
00010000=how many bytes
11111110=how many bytes
00000001=how many bytes

The answers are 172, 16, 1, 254, but which ones which



</question>



<answer from>



isl247
Member since: 23 February 2007
Total points: 4838 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Desktops



Laptops & Notebooks



Monitors



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I'd say you're all wrong. Those numbers may mean 172, 16, 1, 254 in binary, but that doesn't necessarily mean "172 bytes". It just means "172" that could be bananas or square feet of carpet or feet of detal floss...

I believe the correct answers would be 1, 1, 1, and 1. Each of those strings is made up of 8 bits (a 1 or a 0) and those 8 bits together each equal 1 byte. It doesn't matter what that 1 byte is.

Dang. Mr. lci types faster than me ;)

And to the guy who said there are 1000 bytes in a kilobyte, well, THERE'S a question to pose to find out "who is good with computers". The answer is actually 1024.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Very interesting answer, do you know if bits are magnetic



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Steve B
Member since: 02 June 2007
Total points: 2875 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



And what problem does this involve? Your binary or hexadecimal homework? Don't waste our time, please.



</answer>



<answer from>



mag3dot1...
Member since: 08 January 2007
Total points: 3297 (Level 4)



</answer from>

now give it to me in octal and hexadecimal.....



</answer>

Xyso

Mr. Ici
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 1027 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You've got this all wrong. There are 8 bits in a byte so here are your answers:

10101100= 1 byte
00010000= 1 byte
11111110= 1 byte
00000001= 1 byte

Don't forget if the last bit (on the right) is a 1 then it's an odd number.
Do you know how to convert bin to hex?



1010 1100 = 10dec  12dec = AC



</answer>



<answer from>



Kenny Gates
Member since: 09 March 2008
Total points: 2221 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



1st - 172
2nd - 16
3rd - 254
4rth - 1

though, i dont see what this has to do with computers.!



</answer>

<question>



How do I convert video files so that they will play on my DVD player?



I have just changed my CD-Rom drive for a DVD-Ram on my IBM notebook:  how do I change .avi, .rm, etc. files so that they will play on my TV's player and use my new hardware to burn it?  Will I need a new programme?



</question>



<answer from>



markunit...
Member since: 23 August 2006
Total points: 147 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



WinAVI Video converter is fast, but I've just had probs with it and submitted a question myself. Video DVD Maker FREE is, incredibly, free (unlike most) and you can download it from their homepage videodvdmaker.com. It's slow and simple but I've had good results before with it. Once you convert the avi file you need a burner like Nero to make a dvd that will work on any normal player. Hope you get it sorted, I've been driven daft trying to work this out before myself. Hope this helps!



</answer>

<answer from>



cdabexx
Member since: 13 January 2007
Total points: 7769 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Go to Start, then control panel, then display. Increase the resolution; this should make everything smaller.



</answer>



<answer from>



davec112...
Member since: 08 August 2008
Total points: 256 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



ok sounds like your screen resolution needs to be adjusted right click on an empty area of your desktop and select properties ....go to the settings tab at top right of the display properties window that will pop up and look for a slider that's called screen resolution slide it to the right until it fits your needs (i recommend 1024 x 768 for most people) also check your color quality make sure its set at least 16 bit then click ok at the bottom and your all set.

If you cant adjust any of these settings or they just keep reverting back you will need to reload your video driver you can find one at the manufactures website.

Hope this helps



Later Days



</answer>

<question from>



robinson...
Member since: 12 May 2008
Total points: 71 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Question about RAM for my laptop?



my laptop had 1gb of ram and i added another gb. they are both DDR2 pc2-5300 but now my computer seems to be running slower than it did without the extra ram. I did a scan of my system on www.crucial.com and it said that my computer recognizes the extra ram but my computer runs slower??? does anyone know why this is? is there something i have to do?



</question>



<answer from>



jzimmerm...
Member since: 07 October 2006
Total points: 1041 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The extra module you added may not be be compatible with your motherboard or with the other stick. This will cause your computer to run slower, and may even cause hard drive corruption. I would do a memory test scan with memtest '86, or some other memory testing program, and if you get a lot of errors, its a compatibility issue.. Usually when i buy ram for anything, I write down the part number of the ram that's in the computer already and then look that up online. This way you know its compatible.



Source(s):



Me. Computer Technician 10+ years.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks, but i checked and it is the exact same as my other stick of ram. and a did a test and it said that both sticks are working fine. but my computer still seems to be slower



</asker's comment>

<question from>



bunny
Member since: 14 June 2008
Total points: 90 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is the best cheapest printer to purchase (with ink costs that are low)?



I have a dell 940A and it costs a fortune for ink.  Any suggestions?
Need to print coupons and ect..



</question>



<answer from>



yisgood
Member since: 22 February 2008
Total points: 3850 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Printers



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Usually if the printer is cheap they make it up by ripping you off on the ink. Dell gives away their printers because they get you on the $40 cartridges. Lexmark has $29 printers which use $40 cartridges. So if you spend a little more on the printer, you'll more than make it up in ink savings.
 As someone who was in the computer hardware business for years (though I rarely sold printers since I couldn't compete with the crazy rebates) I have always recommended Epson. The print quality is excellent, even on plain paper. I have photos I printed on a 640 about ten years ago hanging in my office which still look good, though not as good as the ones from the CX8400 on glossy paper. The warranty is excellent. For a year, Epson will express-ship a replacement and pick up the old one. I had one customer who needed this. He called one afternoon and had the replacement two days later. Another client bought a Canon. It needed two repairs within a few months. Each time it was taken to the repair center, then picked up a few days later. This client runs a specialty printing business and this really hurt. They have since bought an Epson CX5000 and have had no down time since.
All name brand ink is expensive, but you can get cheap new replacement cartridges for Epson (not refills which I never recommend) for under $5 at http://ccs-digital.com/ink.asp



I have been using these for years.
The CX8400 scanner/copier/printer was on sale at circuitcity.com for $60 with free shipping. It uses 3 colors plus black.
The NX400 which uses the same cartridges is on sale at Staples for $75.
The RX595 scanner/copier/printer also prints on DVDs. It uses 5 colors plus black and has even higher photo quality. It's on sale for $80 after $55 instant rebate.
http://www.cheapstingybargains.com/54342...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Very informational for someone who does not know much about computer printers.
Thank you.

<question>



Anyone recommend a decent laptop



I am buying a new laptop to replace my desktop. I just have not got the room for my desktop pc now we've moved so came to the awful decision to get rid

Anyone out there recommend a good laptop for around £450 - £500??

Hopefully the laptop will be able to do just as much as the desktop but with a lot less room. Any ideas??

Thanks in advance

J



</question>



<answer from>



Dixons.c...
Member since: 19 May 2008



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Hi J,

Laptops have been coming down in price steadily recently, which means you can get some great spec machines for a lot less than you would have done in the past. Around your budget of £500 you can get some very decent machines which would easily replace a traditional PC.

The one thing you lose with laptops however is the ability to upgrade the components after purchase as this can either be very difficult or very costly. While many would consider this a disadvantage, a laptop has so many advantages, such as size and weight, that can easily be overlooked.

As an example here is a very good laptop at £449.00:

The Toshiba A300D-13X is a powerful machine, it comes with the superb AMD Dual Core processor that has a 2.0GHz clock speed. It also has a massive 200GB Hard Drive and 2GB of memory making it perfect for a whole host of activities. This machine will happily perform the day to day tasks while giving you the ability to use high demand applications if needed.

It is one of the best sellers in its range and price.  Toshiba laptops are very highly rated and are great value for money.

Hope this helps you to find a laptop.  Let us know what you choose!



Source(s):



http://www.dixons.co.uk/martprd/product/...



</answer>

<question>



If i use a jumper to clear my cmos, do I lose Bios software or informations?



I find problems with my pc after upgrading the cpu. and i guess if i clear my cmos it can be helpful. does it make any problems?



</question>



<answer from>



oni-kun ^^
Member since: 27 July 2008
Total points: 4843 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It just resets your BIOS to factory settings. FSB speeds etc. You'll notice no difference if you never played with it.

It won't impede on anything really.



</answer>



<answer from>



joelrive...
Member since: 01 June 2007
Total points: 187 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



you can remove the battery on the pc to reset the bios this could help

aurelian...
Member since: 02 December 2007

<answer>

<answer from>



edmund.m
Member since: 19 May 2008
Total points: 3260 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



mentioning the brand and model of printer will definitely help!!!
2 things
1. did you remove the transparent plastic protector? delete all documents currently in queue and try printing again. if the same result, do #2 below then try again.
2. you may need the latest software/driver downloaded and installed. get it from printer manufacturer's website and make sure it's the version for your MacBook operating system. if you can't find the one for your MacBook then it's going to be tough but still doable. (let us know)

good luck!!!

<question>



Help with resetting ink cartridges on Canon Pixma MP210!!?



I have just replaced my cartridges on my Canon Pixma MP210 Printer and have followed instructions to the letter... yet the printer will not recognise the new cartridges. I have reset the printer by taking out the power lead then plugging it back in while pressing the power button at the same time. Any help please?



</question>



<answer from>



sewrobb
Member since: 15 February 2008
Total points: 28082 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Other - Internet



Software



Other - Computers



</answer from>



<answer>



Have you reset the ink levels in maintenance and sent them to the printer. If not the printer still thinks the catridges are still empty therefore it will not recognise the new ones.



Source(s):



Experienced1



</answer>



<answer from>



Michael B
Member since: 20 August 2008
Total points: 517 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



On my printer (which is a different one from yours), the printer will not recognise the cartridge unless it has been pressed firmly until it clicks into place, for which I have to push quite hard.  Hope this helps



</answer>



<answer from>



Paddingt...
Member since: 05 January 2007
Total points: 6377 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I've answered your other question as well but having seen this one it is clear that you did NOT reset your printer -unplugging it is not resting it.



Try this:
1 Put the cartridge in again.  You will need to really force them in until they click - this takes a bit of force. You have to sort of put them in at an angle then straighten them up. It should then take the carage over so close the lid of it. It should then make loads of noises and stuff but should then stop and this can take a few minutes. If the cartridge is accepted it will be ready to work, If not, then start with step 2.

2 If step 1 did not work you will need to reset it.  Resetting is NOT unplugging it or turning it off.  If it needs resetting then there will be an orange light on over under the B button on the right.  The on/off light should also be on and this is green.

3 If this orange light is on then you need to reset the printer by pressing the SMALL button on the bottom row of  3 buttons. The resert button is smaller of the 3 and this has a red circle with a triangle in it and 2 black slash lines up above it.  Hold this button down until the orange light goes off.  Your printer WILL then be reset as that button IS the reset button.



4 If that does not work you either have a faulty cartridge or a faulty printer and if new or under a year old you will have to take it back to where bought for either a repair or a refund.



Source(s):



Done it loads of times with mine.



</answer>

<question>



How many fps makes a good webcam?



</question>



<answer from>



brianthe...
Member since: 28 April 2006
Total points: 25572 (Level 7)



Contributing In:

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



hi eric



not being a expert on webcams but on graphic cards the benchmark for seamless gaming or in other words when you cannot see the frame change is 50fps,so taking that into consideration i would imagine its about the same with a webcam



however in reality the human eye can really only handle around 35fps,thats alot of frames to get into one second,and is planty good enough for most webcams



so i would say between 35fps to 50fps



good luck eric

<question from>



Lurgess

Total points: 185 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Dell Dimension 3100 Desktop PC?



My little brother is starting his BA Computer Game Programming after summer and am thinking of getting him a desktop PC.

Got my eyes on a mint Dell Dimension 3100 on ebay but not sure if it's good enough for the course. Can any experts out there give me some advise? Is this a very old model? With a 15" flat screen + mouse + keyboard, how much should it be sold?

Infos:
Intel Pentium 4 Processor 521 with HT Technology.
2Gb memory (2 x 1Gb Crucial cards).
a Philips 16x DVD+/- drive.
SigmaTel Audio soundcard
Comes with graphic card but only basic

If I am to use this as a base & upgrade different parts to an acceptable lvl (better graphic card + hard-drive etc.. any more?) about how much will I need to spend?

a million thanksssss!!!!!!!



</question>



<additional details>



thanks for the answers so far =] no ebay for me it is. but how's the pc itself? good enough for programming?



</additional details>



<answer from>



louscann...
Member since: 30 April 2006
Total points: 9003 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



Avoid anything with a slimline case, as you would then be restricted to half-height/low profile graphics cards, should you choose to upgrade...
The link below (Dell 3100 manual) reveals on page 65 that the motherboard does not have an expansion slot for a  graphics card.  Normally, you would expect to find a PCI Express x16 slot (possibly even two, three or four) or an AGP slot on an older machine.  The Dell 3100 appears to have only a PCI Express x1 slot plus two PCI slots.  This will be a substantial obstacle to a graphics upgrade - although PCI and PCI-Ex1 graphics cards are available, they will not provide performance on a par with x16 cards, and their scarcity will make them disproportionately expensive.

A purchase direct from Dell is likely to include a 19" monitor and not mentioned in your description - an operating system.
I'm only guessing, but I should expect that a current degree course would require Vista rather than XP.



I appreciate that it would feel good to spring a surprise present on your sibling, but I recommend that you canvas his views on the proposed purchase.



There may be some requirement imposed by the course which might otherwise be missed, and which might prove expensive to resolve after purchase...

Dell might be a good one-stop shop in the event that there is a requirement for a printer and/or scanner - but don't forget to compare prices immediately before purchase.



And avoid slimline cases - wherever you shop!



Source(s):



http://support.dell.com/support/edocs/sy...



s



</answer>

<question from>



150 IQ
Member since: 02 August 2008
Total points: 1513 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Can anyone explain the difference between, Virtual RAM,VIDEO MEMORY, AND GRAPHICS MEMORY PLEASE.?



CHEERS!



</question>



<answer from>



QQQ
Member since: 11 May 2008
Total points: 11793 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Software



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



RAM is also called primary memory. It's primary because on the motherboard, it sits right next to the CPU (the brains of the computer).
When you open a program, the program instructions are fed from your hard disk into the RAM modules. These instructions are then queued up, like customers in a Macdonals restaurant, waiting to be processed by the CPU.



Video memory, or VRAM as it's also called, is memory that is allocated for rendering graphics and images (stuff you see on the screen, durr). Some computers don't actually have VRAM (VRAM modules are seen on Video cards), so they use part of RAM to compensate.
You may see some cheap budget computers that are advertised with "Shared Graphic Memory" or "Shared VRAM". This means that the some of its primary RAM is being used as VRAM.

Virtual memory is a computer system technique which gives an application program the impression that it has contiguous/continous working memory, while in fact it may be physically fragmented and may even overflow from the RAM on to disk storage.



Let's suppose you only had 25 megabytes of free RAM available. If you opened a program and it requires 50 megabytes of RAM, and you only had 25 left, the remainder 25 megabytes is queued on the hard disk. Thus Virtual memory 'fools' the program into thinking there is more RAM than there actually is.

You can see a picture of it here http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/co...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



.



</asker's comment>






<original file>index;_ylt=AirxA1aYyMvsxwpmdtZVepDTMBV2449.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk43686.txt</current file name>

Computers & Internet

</category>



<question from>



Matt S
Member since: 03 May 2008
Total points: 1251 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Computer turn on and turn off?



How many times a day can I turn off and turn on computer? Should I just leave it on the whole day?



</question>



<answer from>



snimm
Member since: 01 July 2008
Total points: 425 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Preferably not.
It probably wont effect you too much but the general rule is that the longer the computer is running, the more crap is shoved into the memory and it will slowly get slower (especially if you are playing games). If you turn it off at least once a day you will get a nice clean start.

Personally, if you are leaving it for more than an hour turn it off. It only takes 2 minutes to turn it back on.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks for answering.



</asker's comment>

Shadow the hedgehog

</question from>



<question>



MacBook internet tabs?



I just got a MacBook!!! Can you open tabs or something like that on the internet? Like on windows internet explorer 7? When I'm on Y!A I like to open a bunch of tabs that are questions and answer them all at the same time so I don't waste so much time. lol



</question>



<answer from>



Shannon F
Member since: 21 June 2008
Total points: 3243 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



YouTube



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



To open a new window in Safari, you can either do [apple symbol] N (for a brand new window) or [apple symbol] T (for a new tab).



The [apple symbol] may not be on a new Mac; it's the square sign with circles on the corners.



To maximize the Safari browser window, you can resize it with the corner sizer (lower right), or just click the green button in the upper left.

Any window you click will come to the front. This is a nice trick: You can slightly minimize all open browser windows with function (fn button) and F9. Then click the one you want to look at.



Source(s):



This is only if you are using Safari, so if you don't have it you may want to download it: http://www.apple.com/safari/download/

If you want, you can download Internet Explorer for your Mac, and it will make it easier on you for internet tabs:

http://www.microsoft.com/windows/interne...

A lot of people ask me this, and YES Internet Explorer works on Mac. I used to have a Macbook and it worked fine for me.



</answer>

<question>



Help with cartridge changing on a Canon Pixma MP210 Printer?



I have just changed my ink cartridges on my above printer for the first time and the printer is not recognising that there are new ones installed. I have performed a printer reset to no avail. Any suggestions? I'd appreciate it.... Thanks



</question>



<additional details>



Thanks for your replies, can I add..
1. There is no official reset button on the MP210
2. Unlike my old Canon printer, there isn't an option in maintenance to reset the ink levels.
Thanks to both for the advice below anyway..



</additional details>



<answer from>



Paddingt...
Member since: 05 January 2007
Total points: 6377 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have this with my Canon MP 220.  Turn off the printer and then turn it back on again.  If the little orange light comes on, this on your make will be above the B button, press the reset button until it goes off. If that does not work take the cartridge out and put it back in and then repeat. If that does not work call Canon who I found very helpful when I spoke to them.
Edit
Yes there is a reset button or something equivalent to it - on mine it is a little circle with a red triangle inside a circle! See the link below as it might help if not I will try to find more!http://printer1.blogspot.com/2008/04/res...

2nd Edit
This YouTube shows someone changing the cartridges and if you look on the right hand side panel at the bottom there are 3 buttons.  Two are bigger and are the buttons to specify what color you want to print in and the little button next to it is the reset button.  It is this button that you press for a moment until the orange light goes out.  That is how to reset them as I have done it.  If the taking the cartridge out and putting it back does not work Canon will be your best hope of solving this problem.http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XyT6JsD0o...



</answer>

Member since: 15 February 2008

<original file>index;_ylt=AjssmxfP_siT0AEuFptlEM0gBgxc0a3.html</original file>

<question from>



Matt (uk & Ireland)
Member since: 09 September 2007
Total points: 4934 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Whats the diffrence betweek 90nm 65nm and 45nm on processers?



</question>



<additional details>



I mean, i have an amd athlon 6000+ x2 and its 90nm, bu i mean whats the diffrence between them all. So whats it all about?

Thanks



</additional details>



<answer from>



david_m_...
Member since: 07 March 2007
Total points: 1584 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



i got the same cpu the lower the number the newer the cpu...basically its down to miniaturization

45nm is half the size of 90mn so it stand to reason there is twice as many microswitches in the 45nm cpu as there is in the 90nm cpu

hence twice the power.... typically 90nm cpus are dual core 65nm are high end dual/treble core & 45nm are quad core



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Levi F
Member since: 07 August 2008
Total points: 320 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Physical size and thus heat production!! :)



</answer>



<answer from>



cnauta70
Member since: 18 May 2008
Total points: 895 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



These are the width of the circuits or highway lanes for traffic that Intels and AMD CPU's are. 45 nanometer width circuitry is the thinnest one available today and is used on Intel's newest and best processors. The reason Intel has moved from 90 nm to 65nm to now 45 nm is because if they still used 90 nm circuitry they could not fit all the processors inside their microprocessors in such a small area.



</answer>



<answer from>



Afsal A
Member since: 31 December 2007
Total points: 118 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Processor is made up of millions of small transistors.90 nm means this transistors size. Nm means nanometer.Now intel are using 45 nm, so in a processor there will be large amount of transistors ,so processor will be faster.



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It depends on the spec of your laptop and printer.  If they both have blue tooth or wifi, then you can do it already.

If not, you can get a USB wifi module for your laptop then a wireless print server for your printer.

<answer>



By DS I suppose you mean Nintendo DS - first off, this device wasn't really built as an MP3 player so you can't just put music on it without first buying some sort of peripheral. There is such a thing as a Nintendo MP3 player but judging by the reviews at Amazon, it isn't the greatest bit of kit around.
http://www.amazon.co.uk/Nintendo-MP3-Pla...
The alternative is to get some sort of R4 card as they are known (google Nintendo R4 for this one). This allows some level of customization including playing music if you have the right software installed. 
Personally I think you may be better off with a small MP3 player - they don't cost too much and will probably give you better quality sound.

<question>



I see flashes of light on screens that others don't?



Sometimes when I watch something on any type of screen (Desktop PC LCD, Laptop, Plasma TV, Car Screens) at certain times I see flashes of light. The colors are different every time and it lasts for less than a second but nobody else notices it. Is there something I should be worried about?



</question>



<additional details>



I haven't experienced any headaches or any other side effects. I think it might be the refresh rate because I only see it on certain screens and not on all screens that I use daily.



</additional details>



<answer from>



oni-kun ^^
Member since: 27 July 2008
Total points: 4853 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You may want to see an optometrist very soon because this could mean a defect in your eyes ( form cataracts to minor tumers ).

Generally TV's have a refresh rate, they flash at 60-120 times per second. If you look away from the screen then you can easily see it ( flickering ) in most monitors/tv's. It could be a minor issue in how your eyes perceive the image as well.



</answer>



<answer from>



mike H
Member since: 10 August 2008
Total points: 3004 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



hi it sounds as though your seeing the screen refreshing, if you look or focus on something behind the screen then you'll notice the flashing or screen refreshing is more prominent, this usually indicates the screens refresh rate is set too low and can cause eye strain and headaches, and needs to be changed, more below on this



Source(s):



http://www.computer-adviser.com/headache...

mightymo...

<answer>



Inkjet printers use ink cartridges while laser printers have a whole bunch of different parts and basically burn the image to the paper.  Laser printers are more expensive to buy, and the replacement cartrigdes are as well, but they last much longer than ink jets.  What type of printer you buy depends on what kind of quality of printing you need or want, how much you are willing to spend up front.  The higher cost of the laser jet will pay for itself over time, depending on how much you use it.



</answer>

<answer from>



ryan_xj
Member since: 07 September 2007
Total points: 562 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



INKJET:

Inkjet printers work by spraying small amounts of quick-drying ink through a nozzle onto a sheet of paper; tiny deflective plates alter the ink's path to create the desired shapes.

Ink is stored in disposable ink cartridges. Low-end inkjet printers use three ink colours (cyan, magenta, and yellow), and usually black as a fourth, compared to a "photo printer" that will have anywhere from a 5- to 12-colour ink system (e.g. light magenta, red, blue, or light cyan). Because a business user may print certain colours more frequently, single-colour cartridges have become more common, as you only need to replace these individual tanks as needed.

Pros and cons:

"Inkjet printers offer outstanding photo and document quality at a great value," says Justin Joseph, spokesman for Canon's printer division. "With features such as automatic double-sided printing and individual ink tanks to limit wasted ink, inkjet technology has really grown for the business consumer."

Another advantage to inkjet over laser is they can be used on all types of paper and enjoy quality that rivals your local photo mat; this is why inkjet printers are more ideal for photos than laser printers.

While inkjet printers are relatively inexpensive (as low as $50), be aware replacing ink may become costly as you'll burn through these cartridges faster than laser printers.



LASER:

Laser printers apply lasers to an area of a photoconductive drum. The electrical charge causes toner particles to cling to the rotating cylinder, forming a shape that will be transferred over to the printed page through heat and pressure.

Multi-pass colour laser printers use one imaging drum repeatedly for each CMYK colour (cyan, magenta, yellow and black). A faster solution, however, is single-pass (a.k.a. inline) colour laser printers that contain four imaging drums, allowing the page to be printed in just one pass.

Pros and cons:

Laser printers are ideal for producing high volumes thanks to the high-yield inks, plus they are faster at spitting out documents than inkjet printers. If you only need black-and-white printing, consider a monochrome laser printer over an inkjet printer. Other advantages to laser printers include high-volume paper trays, multiple finishing options, and more network options than inkjet printers.

But laser printers cost more than inkjet printers. A decent monochrome laser printer typically costs about $150 on the low-end (add another hundred or two for a good colour laser printer), which is considerably more than a photo lab-quality inkjet printer. It should be noted prices for colour laser printers have dropped considerably over the years.



Source(s):



http://www.printerinkshop.net



</answer>



<answer from>



Ryan
Member since: 05 April 2008
Total points: 1318 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



An inkjet printer



Uses Ink to mark the paper, has to have ink cartridges. Is cheaper to run than Laserjet. Ink jet printers are best suited for home use.

A LaserJet printer



Uses lasers to mark the paper, has to have a toner which is alot bigger than cartridges. The toner is bigger and more expensive than cartridges but lasts longer. Laser jets are quicker at printing than ink. The paper is dry straight away. The laser jets are bigger printers and are best suited for offices.



I work in Staples and we sell many different types of printers and office Equipment. 
I would suggest Lexmark if you want it to be wireless.
If not go for the Epson DX8400 or any DX/SX series. The DX8400 can copy scan and print good quality photos.
The ink is cheap compared to HP and comes in individual cartridges meaning you can change one colour at a time. In the set there are 3 colours and 1 black all for £24. 
You also don't need to use the pc and can print Straight from a memory card.
We have had no complaints and I recommend Epson DX/SX series to all customers as it can cater to everyones needs. The DX8400 changes its price frequently due to demand, but it never goes over the £100 mark.



</answer>

<question>



Printers have stopped working. Do I change the USB hub or cable?



For a few years I have been happily printing with 2 or 3 printers connected to a 4-port powered USB 2 hub at the end of 5 metre passive cable.

Suddenly, a couple of weeks ago (actually not long after I installed Nokia PC Suite 7) the printers decided not play ball. Prints would often fail completely or print out a line of gobbledygook or even print the top inch or so of a page before giving up and spewing out the paper. But the USB system still recognised that they were there and bleeped when unplugged.

One of the printers failed completely, so it has been replaced. I now find that if I connect printers directly (i.e. by avoiding the hub) they work - even by putting an A-B cable in the end of the 5m run. Connecting through the hub, neither of the printers wants to know.

Could I expect them to work if the 5m run were an active cable? Or is there a special type of hub that I need to install?

Incidentally I have swapped out the hub and used a different 5m cable (passive; I don't have an active one). I have even connected up to a different computer. It also makes no difference. Neither is there any difference if I go through an external hub at the PC end of the 5m run or connect it straight into the Mobo USB ports.

I am doing my nut because everything I have tried fails - yet the system has worked perfectly for a long time.

Is it hub? Is it cable? Or is it something else. Grateful for your views!



</question>

<question>



What files can i delete in start up that i never use to have more memory?



computer is running slow



</question>



<answer from>



Andy
Member since: 01 September 2008
Total points: 278 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



delete  files which r from system 32 folder...
delete driver commands...
and antivirus or antispyware files



</answer>



<answer from>



oni-kun ^^
Member since: 27 July 2008
Total points: 4843 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well any programs that aren't system. You should be able to recognize any programs that you installed that are set to startup.

P.S. Don't delete things from system32..-__-



</answer>



<answer from>



You
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 146 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Start &gt; Run
In the Run dialog, type in msconfig.exe
Select the tab Startup
Uncheck the programs you don't want to start up.

CAUTION: Make sure you know what you don't want to open on boot up. Don't uncheck things you don't know what they are. It may cause system instability.



</answer>



<answer from>



L C
Member since: 04 September 2008

<question>



Where can a university student find a decent laptop?



I'm going off to university to do a computing course and I need a laptop with at least 2GB of RAM, roughly 2GHz of processor power and at least 100GB of hard disk space. An nVidia or Radeon graphics card would be a bonus too. Trying to spend less than £500. Anyone know of any?



</question>



<answer from>



Dixons.c...
Member since: 19 May 2008



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Hi Neonxiv,

I would have to disagree with some of the people that have responded so far and say for £500 you can easily get a laptop that will feature all that you want from it.  Laptops prices have fallen greatly over the past year or so, and there are some great bargains around on new and refurbished machines.

For example the HP DV9823EA, it features: 2GHz AMD Turion processor, 3GB RAM, 160GB Hard Drive, NVIDIA GeForce 7150 Graphics Card and a 17" wide screen display. It is perfect for gaming, watching movies and will suit all your university needs as well and priced at £499.99 including delivery.

Or alternatively the Dell Inspiron 1318 is also £499.99 including delivery and features a 1.86GHz Intel Core 2Duo processor, 2GB RAM, 160GB Hard Drive and Intel Integrated graphics card. It does only feature a 13.3" screen, but can used with a TFT Monitor to get a bigger screen size.  The advantage of this is that at 2.28Kg it is lighter and more compact than the HP.

Both laptops are incredibly stylish and come with Windows Vista Home Premium edition, and of course they are both wireless enabled, allowing you to get online wherever you are.

If you are looking to spend less and will consider a refurbished machine we have some great offers on these but stock is very limited!

I hope this helps you make your decision, good luck whichever laptop you choose and good luck for your time at university!

http://www.dixons.co.uk/martprd/product/...

<question>



My use of the printer is infrequent and the ink hardens involving repurchase.ideas please?



</question>



<answer from>



Mike S
Member since: 11 April 2008
Total points: 520 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Switch to laser, toner doesn't dry out.



</answer>



<answer from>



mariehac
Member since: 10 September 2008
Total points: 330 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Be best if you printed something out on draft every so often to stop it drying out



</answer>



<answer from>



RichlyCr...
Member since: 06 December 2007
Total points: 4911 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Along with ink hardening in the print heads which can really only be prevented with periodic draft prints and/or printer self head cleaning, very infrequent use can also lead to the ink hardening inside the ink cartridge as moisture escapes through the vent hole, to combat this you could try covering the vent hole(s) with a piece of tape or similar when it won't be in use for a long period.  Although I'm not sure of the ramifications of this it may be worth a shot if you'll eventually end up having to replace the cartridge anyways.



</answer>



<answer from>



archery_...
Member since: 13 December 2006
Total points: 2317 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Just run a test page every three or four weeks. You could also run the head-cleaning facility at the same time.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jim W
Member since: 24 March 2006
Total points: 6134 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Print something in BW and Color every week.  Run the head cleaning utility every other week.  You'll waste a little ink, but not as much as you waste by throwing out cartridges when they're only halfway through their normal yield.



</answer>



<answer from>



johncob

Total points: 7244 (Level 5)

http://www.specialistinks.com/cleaning-h...



</answer>



<answer from>



Roy V
Member since: 05 September 2008
Total points: 791 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you go for another inkjet printer, you need to follow the manufacturer's instructions regarding the frequency of printing or you'll end up with the same problem again. Keeping the printer in a cooler environment might help.

Also if you leave your printer on all the time, you can create a scheduled task to print a test page at pre-defined intervals in order to minimise the risk of the nozzles/jets getting blocked, potentially saving you money.



Just open Notepad and enter the three lines of text shown below. Substitute printer name with the Windows name for the printer



REM PRINTS TEST PAGE 
rundll32 printui.dll PrintUIEntry /k /n "printer name" 
EXIT



Save the file eg as testpage.bat



Next open the Scheduled Tasks folder (in the Control Panel) and Add Scheduled Task. Browse to where you saved the file and click Open. Next choose Weekly {as most manufacturers suggest that you print something at least once a week} and then click Next. Select the time you want it done and on which day of the week. Click Next and you will be asked for the password for the user it is running under. Once completed click on Finish.



[Instructions are for XPPro]



</answer>



<answer from>



John B
Member since: 24 August 2007
Total points: 468 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



All of the previous suggestions are sound, however, if you get to the stage that you forgot to print test pages etc. then pop the cartrdge out, and with preferably a lint free cloth, soaked in WD40 (yes, the oil stuff!), carefully clean the head, as WD40 "melts/disolves" the dried ink, then ensure all the ink has gone, wipe it clean of oil, pop the cartridge back in, a test page or two, then you're good to go. Well, it works for me

Good luck in whichever method you choose

JB



</answer>

<answer from>



16k-zx81
Member since: 16 March 2008
Total points: 21356 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Software



Add-ons



Desktops



</answer from>



<answer>



[holds up big red flag]

you cant put two ati cards into a sli motherboard. you need a crossfire motherboard to run two 4870's.

So you might want to  revise the motherboard or look at nvidia cards to fit it instead of the ati's.

[puts flag down]

Also a better gaming cpu would be an e8600 or an e8500. Its a common misconception that a slower clocked quad will beat a faster clocked dual, but this is not true and by using the quad you will lose a lot of fps. That quad is only a good choice if you need the machine for tasks like video encoding. Otherwise, if your priority is gaming, the dual is the better choice.



Apart from that its a fine build.



best answer please.



Source(s):



http://www.digit-life.com/articles3/vide...
http://www.guru3d.com/article/cpu-scalin...
http://arstechnica.com/guides/buyer/guid...
http://www.sharkyextreme.com/guides/EGBG...
http://www.hardware-revolution.com/a-250...



</answer>

<original file>index;_ylt=Ap.xmajQ6KQ0pb019swHdhXUMBVc3e3.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk46112.txt</current file name>



<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



SuperGir...
Member since: 25 June 2008
Total points: 113 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why is my lap top battery dead and it will no longer charge?



I noticed my laptop battery wouldn't last as long as it usually does lately and now it won't charge at all. Do I need a new battery?



</question>



<answer from>



Frank B
Member since: 20 November 2007
Total points: 5606 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Laptop batteries have a limited amount of cycles they can go thru until they start to loose progressively the amount of charge they can hold.

1 cycle = 1 discharge and 1 recharge. Laptop batteries are usually good for 1000 cycles, so depending how often you go thru cycles will determine the life of your battery.

I've heard Batteries Plus ( http://www.batteriesplus.com ) can sometimes rebuild laptop batteries. This might be an option for you. It will cost half the cost of a new one and will work like new.

Also Andrew H mention a memory issue, this is only true with Nicad batteries which you may have... However, nowadays, laptop batteries are made with Lithium Ion ( check the battery to see which kind you have ), if it's lithium ion ( should show up on the battery as Li-Ion ), there is no memory effect and you don't need to worry about it.

However just remember the cycle thing I talked about above.

If you charge your battery when it's half full all the time instead of waiting for it to be empty, your battery will die twice faster.

Also, one good advice to expand the life of your battery, when it's full and you intend to work for a long period of time, just plug your laptop to the wall and TAKE OFF the battery so it doesn't overcharge and die prematurely



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Great! Thank you very much for all the excellent info!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Cjac
Member since: 04 December 2007
Total points: 2213 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sounds quite likely, make sure to find a suitable battery for your laptop make.



</answer>

<question from>



Nick
Member since: 14 September 2008
Total points: 336 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



4gb of RAM to run 64 bit version of Vista?



Hello,
I was wondering if I really needed 4gb of RAM to run a 64 bit version of Vista.
I checked the Microsoft website & it said you needed to have 4gb of RAM, I mean this is a little over the top, anyone have personal experience with 64 bit Vista & less RAM?
The computer I'm getting has 2gb of RAM & I want a 64 bit version of Vista, will this cause some sort of conflict or make it run slow?
Also what are so advantages & disadvantages of having a 64 bit Vista compared to a 32 bit Vista? Is there really a difference at all?
Thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



Dave
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Having a 64-bit OS will let you access the full 4GB of RAM.  If you only have 32-Bits, you can't actually use 4GB of RAM.  You can buy it and install it, but your computer can never store anything in it.  How much you can use depends on a number of factors but can be as low as 2 GB.

Also, if you want to use a 64-bit OS, you need to make sure your computer really supports it.  Most computers with Vista 32 on them will actually not be able to run the 64-bit version due to having only 32-bit chipsets on them (this doesn't mean the CPU which is likely to be 64-bit).

Microsoft lists 1GB as the required RAM for 64-bit Vista.



Source(s):



http://www.appleinsider.com/articles/08/...
http://support.microsoft.com/kb/919183



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you, very thorough answer.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Python
Member since: 18 March 2008
Total points: 2906 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have run 64-bit Vista Ultimate on 2Gb of Ram.  What I think the site is trying to tell you is your bes to get 64-bit edition if the computer comes installed with more than 4Gb of Ram, because 32-bit is only supposed to read up to 4GB of Ram.

It will work fine though.



Source(s):



Used to run Vista Ultimate 64-bit



</answer>



<answer from>



Mercuri
Member since: 06 May 2008
Total points: 1698 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You incorrectly read the specs.  You do not need 4GBs of RAM to run 64-bit Vista.  However, 4GBs of RAM will only show up as 4GBs (instead of 3GBs or so) if you're running a 64-bit operating system.

Currently there really is not advantage to having 64-bit Vista unless you have 4GBs of RAM or more so you can use all the RAM.  There are just no mainstream 64-bit applications out that can take advantage of 64-bit computing so you're going to see all the 32-bit applications running in 32-bit emulation on a 64-bit OS.  When 64-bit applications become more widespread, then you'll see a difference but right now the two are virtually the same.



</answer>

navaran1

Total points: 151 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



regardless of brand, make, model, type of computer, leave it on for as little time as possible. Use it when you need to and power down when you don't. In so doing you save energy, prolong life of components, and extend the period for which you don't have to maintain (clean) certain components (from dust, hair, fur, etc.). Also if your laptop is not protected from surges/spikes, turning it off and unplugging it from the outlet will decrease its chances of going to the grave sooner than designed.So if I were you I would not abuse it too much for trivial tasks as seeding, etc...get a desktop for that. Laptops are expensive so I recommend you take care of yours very well.



Source(s):



Myself



</answer>

<question from>



gemhak

</question from>



<question>



Every damn time I switch on my HP C3180 All-in-One printer it automatically prints a test page!?



How do I fix this annoying problem? It waists paper and ink.

Would appreciate some help!



</question>



<additional details>



I'm sick of getting a print test page every time I switch the printer on.

How to fix this problem!



</additional details>



<answer from>



Richard J
Member since: 31 December 2007
Total points: 9405 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Printers



External Mail (POP)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



This will surely fix your problem

Please follow exactly and IN ORDER.

1. Turn off the printer and wait 10 seconds. Turn it on again

2. Let the printer print the test page.

3. After the test page is printed, disconnect the USB cable connecting the printer to your computer. DO NOT turn off the printer while disconnecting the USB cable.

4. Place the test page on the scanner glass and press the SCAN button on the printer. The ON light will flash as the page is being scanned.



5. Remove the test page when the ON light is steady.

6. Finally, turn off the printer and wait another 10 seconds. Then turn it on again. No more printing test pages! Yay!

(You may now reconnect the printer to your computer via the USB cable.)



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks so much for your informative response .. and sorry about 'waist' instead of 'waste'.

Regards

Rob



</asker's comment>



<answer from>

Member since: 14 March 2008
Total points: 2746 (Level 4)



</answer from>

<question>



Has this LCD monitor blown?



Hi,

A few days ago I was around my sisters house with my nephew and without anybody realizing, he was playing with the plugs, turning them on and off. My sister went to turn her computer on and the Asus LCD monitor doesn't work. Could this be that it's blown or just a fuse has gone? If the monitor has blown, is there a way to fix it or would it be too expensive and be easier to buy a new monitor?

Thanks for any help.



</question>



<additional details>



Fixed the monitor now. I opened up the plug and noticed the fuse wasn't pushed in properly, did that and connected it to my MBP to test to see if it worked and it was fine.

Thanks for all the help ^_^



</additional details>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Check the fuse first and put the monitor on another computer. If it still doesn't work then I would say you owe your sister a new monitor and the nephew grounded for a week!

Any monitor doesn't like it electrics turn on and off rapidly. It's the quickest way to blow them. And no it's too expensive to repair. Cheaper to buy a new one.



Source(s):



Experienced1



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



This may sound like a daft question but have you checked the plugs?
The Screen is probably connected from the mains plug to an adaptor, then from the adaptor to the monitor, then there is the VGA cable from the PC and the monitor to check as well.
don't just look at them, unplug them and replug them back in again, as daft as it sounds it sometimes works. what looks like a good connection is not actually good at all.
If it is not plugs then if it has an adaptor is there a green light on it? If yes and it is not lit you can get a new one, if no then you can test it with a multimeter if you have one. 
Set the Multimeter to 20V, plug in the adaptor. You put the live test terminal inside the mains adaptor pin (Red cable) and the Negative terminal (black one) on the outside and you should get a voltage reading of whatever the adaptor label says it should be. It maybe 12v, 15v, 18v they are all different.
Warning do not allow the two test terminals to touch each other when the live is inside the pin, you may get a shock, you will damage the adaptor and possibly short the house electrics as well.
you need to teach the rug-rat that playing with electricity will do more than just make his hair curl!



Source(s):



Experience - Senior Technician - Electronbox España



</answer>

saka1337
