</answer from>



<answer>



Well, I'm the same way as you. I generally hide myself away from the computing world then come back and do a marathon of research to find the parts I want.

To be honest, if you generally don't game, anything not extreme will suit you just fine if you don't want to pay a fortune. "Extreme" processors usually are the ones that give you an extra 5-10% performance boost in video games for an extra $100-300. Celerons are notoriously bad for gaming, but for most applications are fine. Duos are in between. Most of them should be dual-core, but for anything that doesn't involve gaming, you don't even need that either.



Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



DevTech
Member since: 13 September 2008
Total points: 285 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Any dual core CPU will do fine so ignore all those processor names...

A 7200 rpm hard drive will be the largest factor in making you laptop seem decent.

RAM is ultra cheap these days so 4 gig should be easy to find

What might be harder to find is a dedicated graphics chip but it's the next most useful thing after making sure you have a 7200 rpm hard drive. Run away screaming from any laptop with an Intel 3100 in it or an ATI 1250 or NVidia 7150 etc - they are all old and slow and use "shared memory" which steals RAM from windows to create a double whammy of a slowdown.

4 to 6 years is a bit optimistic I think for a budget unit. Batteries have a limited lifetime too. Some brands have a more solid construction to last that time such as Dell XPS line and Alienware and with the Dell Lattitude E6400 ATG being extra rugged...

4 to 6 years is also an eternity (like doggie years) in terms of computer specs. Laptops are already much slower and less performant in 2008 compared to desktop units so you are starting off that 6 year clock with hardware that is maybe 2 years behind current desktops. It's probably easier just to figure on 2 to 3 years but you could get more into the 6 year ballpark with a fully upgraded Alienware unit that would be a leap past your budget.



On the other hand they will still probably be trying to get you to buy 1998 graphics perormance 6 years from now in the form of an Intel 3100-Super-X-Extreme-Turbo that steals even more system RAM...



</answer>



<answer from>



brianthe...
Member since: 28 April 2006
Total points: 25572 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Add-ons



Desktops



</answer from>



<answer>



hi phil



there are two catergorys to consider when looking for a laptop,there is portable and desktop replacement



portable concentrate more on portability and uses less powerful components to extend battery life,however modern portable laptops still use intel core 2 duo processors but normally at lower clock speeds(1.6-1.8ghz)



desktop replacement laptops are a different story,they are designed as the name implies to replace your current desktop pc



so since a desktop replacement will be hooked up to the power supply most of the time manufacturers can afford to use more powerful processors and decent graphic chips,plus desktop replacements have desktop sized displays with 17" screens



however from your personal requirements you really need something inbetween these two catergorys,and a excellent example is the mesh ASUS F5SL (http://www.meshcomputers.com/Default.asp... is a allround capable laptop with the following specs :
 Asus F5SL-AP016C 
Genuine Windows Vista™ Home Premium 
15.4" WXGA TFT with ColourShine (1280x800) 
Intel® Core™ 2 Duo T5550 Dual Core Processor (1.83GHz, 2MB L2 Cache, 667MHz FSB) 
1024MB ATI Mobility™ Radeon® HD 3470 Hyper Memory Graphics (External 256MB VRAM) 
2GB DDR2 667MHz Memory (2x1GB) 
250GB Serial ATA Hard Drive (NB) 
DVD Super Format Dual Layer DVD Re-Writer +R/-R/RW/RAM 
Built in Multi-Format Memory Card Reader 
Wireless LAN - 802.11b/g (on-board) 
Built in WebCam 
Built-in Intel HD Audio with 3D Stereo Sound + Dual Internal Stereo Speakers 
4 x USB2, DVI, Line-in, Mic, Headphone, VGA, S/PDIF (F5SL) 
Free Carrying Case & USB Mouse 
2 Years Worldwide Warranty Parts & Labour - (Collect & Return in UK Mainland)



as you can see with a Intel® Core™ 2 Duo T5550 Dual Core Processor and 2GB of DDR2 667MHz Memory this is more than enough for the everyday tasks you will be doing



also you may consider the Gamer Xplorer X5-2900 Notebook(http://www.cyberpowersystem.co.uk/system... and as the name indicates this is in essence a gaming laptop



however i have recommended it more for its specifications such as the GeForce Go 8600GT 256MB graphics adapter and the : Intel® Core™ 2 Duo Mobile T5450 Dual-Core Processor



check the rest of the specs:
 DISPLAY LCD: 15.4" WXGA TFT LCD Display Max: 1280x800 Pixels
CPU: Intel® Core™ 2 Duo Mobile T5450 Dual-Core Processor @ 1.66GHz 667FSB 2MB L2 Cache 64-bit
MOTHERBOARD: Intel PM965 + ICH-8M Chipset Mainboard
MEMORY: 2GB (2x1GB) PC5300 DDR2-667 SODIMM Memory (Corsair Value Select or Major Brand)
VIDEO CARD: Built-in NVIDIA GeForce Go 8600GT 256MB Video
HARD DRIVE: 160GB 5400RPM SATA150 HARD DRIVE
OPTICAL DRIVE: 8X DVD REWRITABLE DRIVE
SOUND: BUILT-IN AC 97 SOUND



so which is better?
 i personally think the Gamer Xplorer X5-2900 Notebook has the edge however check out the links and do some research before deciding which you like



any problems or advice let me know



good luck phil !



</answer>

Gizzo

</answer from>



<answer>



Just a little pointer for you - if you get a vista machine, make sure it has at-least 4GB of RAM. What I mean is get a 4GB Dual Core. A 2GB has 1GB on each side which is not enough. A 4GB Dual Core has 2GB on each side which is the recommended minimum for running vista at a good speed.



</answer>

<question from>



TRACEY S
Member since: 06 December 2007
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>

<question>



What pc do I buy to play high definition games & email & internet?



Would like simple explanations please as I don't understand any of the Rad-eon or Nvidea things also how does the power supply effect what you can do? We are looking for a pc that will be ok for a few years. Thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



Jacacaca
Member since: 28 May 2008
Total points: 1888 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Well, what you're asking is complicated so unfortuntely you have to look into some of the 'nerd' stuff that comes with buying a computer.

Any computer nowadays is fine for email and surfing the web.  You can do that with any Pentium system currently sold.



Where you've taken the BIG leap into nerd territory is gaming.  Current games require insanely high-end PCs (especially to run in Hi-Def as you stated).

Here's a basic PC that will handle all your day to day needs (surfing, email, word processing):  http://www.tigerdirect.com/applications/...

But HERE's the most entry level thing you could buy for playing current games (Crysis, etc):  http://www.tigerdirect.com/applications/...

And the gaming PC I listed would still be obsolete in a few years...



</answer>

<answer from>



dat rapper
Member since: 03 May 2008

Contributing In:

<answer>



The more powerful a computer, the more power it needs. If you get a very weak PC, you only need a small power supply. If you have a top-of-the-range one, you need a more powerful PSU (power supply unit). For those purposes, get a ready-built PC:

http://configure.euro.dell.com/dellstore...

Just add it to the basket and buy it or get it over the phone. It'll be a great little thing at everything but Crysis for the next few years.



</answer>

<question from>



SUCKMYR0...
Member since: 24 January 2008
Total points: 372 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



New computer with 3Gb Ram but only 4.5 Vista Experience score?



I have a brand new Packard Bell I-Media X2415 desktop with 3Gb ram (a 1gb and a 2gb). However my vista experience rating is only 4.5, based on the number of memory operations per second.

I have seen people with scores over 5 with only 2Gb ram - does this mean the PC is just loaded with rubbish components or is there an explanation? Maybe there are problems because the two rams are of different sizes?

And how reliable is Vista Experience as a means of testing your computer's potential performance?



</question>



<answer from>



Greg D
Member since: 18 January 2008
Total points: 2856 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The reason you have such a low score is due to your configuration.  I am assuming these are DDR2 memory, well in order to get the dual channel support you have to install them in identical pairs.  In other words you would have to install 2 1GB modules and 2 512 mb modules for your 3 GB, if I were you I would just buy another identical 2GB module to pair up with your other and take out the 1GB module.  This is the configuration you should have and most companies install when they sell 3 GB systems. You never put DDR2 memory in as single modules, you have just basically halved the bandwidth and speed of your memory because you have lost the dual channel support.

I know this from personal experience since I tinkered with different configurations of memory on my Vista computer and then did some research to find out why I was having the same problem.  Older memory that didn't rely on this technology didn't require you to install in pairs of course even older technology required you to install in quads. (30 pin simm modules)



Source(s):



IT industry for over 14 years.

http://www.crucial.com/kb/answer.aspx?qi...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



good stuff mate, you sound believable anyway ;)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



iherdyou...
Member since: 14 September 2008
Total points: 157 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's not the quantity of the RAM, it's the quality. Just because you have 3 Gb of RAM doesn't mean that it's going to go super duper fast. You need to get _good_ RAM to go really fast. The clock speed and the timings have everything to do with the speed.



</answer>



<answer from>



Dr. Albert Hofmann
Member since: 11 August 2006
Total points: 6084 (Level 5)

<question>



SLI question?????????



i was wondering if it was possible to use a 3 way sli card like the gtx 280 and only use it for 2 way sli. and if so does it matter which of the two sli bridges on the card i use. Thank you



</question>



<answer from>



Michael G
Member since: 19 March 2008
Total points: 107 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



If your using 3-way SLI on the GTX 280 you need the bigger SLI bridge.
If you eventually run 3-ay SLI with GTX 280's you going to need a 1200-1500 watt power supply.

Using a GTX 280's in a 2-way SLI configuration is possible to. You would use the smaller SLI bridge



</answer>

<question>



Basic Windows XP settings re desktop icons?



I feel silly even asking this - somehow, I caused a setting to change.  The desktop icons on my PC now have a colored box around the description.  I went to control panel display to change, and i CAN change the coloring of the box around the description, but not remove the box itself. <answer from>



Lord Blackadder II
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 137 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Windows XP



* Open System Properties in Control Panel, choose the Advanced tab, and click Settings in the Performance section. Turn on the Use drop shadows for icon labels on the desktop option, and click Ok.

<question from>



dude!
Member since: 05 February 2008
Total points: 417 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



My printer stop working?! 10pt for best answer@?



My printer was working fine before. now i try to print it doesnt print and the circle near the word "toner" is lighted up orange

does it means i need to buy a toner? what is a toner?? how do i fix my printer? 10pt for best answer



</question>



<additional details>



is it ink? or what?? paper?  how much does it cost



</additional details>



<answer from>



Krzys
Member since: 06 July 2008
Total points: 859 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



A toner is a fine powder used in laser printers and copiers instead of ink. Actually it is a form of dry ink. How to buy - write down the exact model of your printer (look at the information on the back) (do not try to remember it - one letter can mean a difference) and take it to computer shop. They will help you. A bit of warning - toner can be expensive (see my first link).



You WILL need to buy the toner for your printer. Before that (it will not help for long!!!!), try the following if you have to squeeze that few pages:
1) Open your printer (should be very easy, do NOT use ANY tools to do that) to get hold of your toner cartridge (rather large, black container), take it out without using excessive force (again, should be very easy to do) and shake it vigorously for a few minutes in every imaginable directions. Do NOT touch anything that is covered with a flap of plastic. Just use the handle on the package. Toner cartridge is light, so you will not have any problems with it.

2) Put your cartridge back, close the printer. This operation should give you a few more printed pages (maybe enough to last for a day or so).



CAUTION! If some powder spills (I have never seen that happening), do NOT use anything hot to wash it. COLD water is the best.



Source(s):



Here are photos of some toner cartridges.
http://www.amazon.com/s/qid=1221598294/r...

Information about toners:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toner

Theory behind laser printers:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laser_print...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks dude!



</asker's comment>

<question>



Wireless printing at home?



Hi. I bought a new Epson printer and connected it to one of the computers in the house, in our home we have 3 computers who are all on a wireless network. I would like to make it so you can print from any computer to that printer. I have went to the control panel and chosen to share printer, gave it a name and all, but when i try to find the printer on the other computer it says i spelled the name wrong, but i didn't. can someone please help me step by step how to set this up? thxx.



</question>



<additional details>



Hi, no i did not install the drivers on all computers, and i did not understand the second part u said about choosing the printer and right clicking connect,



</additional details>



<answer from>



bljzzgrl
Member since: 26 January 2008
Total points: 19066 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Desktops



Laptops & Notebooks



Printers



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



1.  Did you install the drivers on all 3 computers?

2.  Are they all running the same version of Windows?

3.  Did you try through Network neighborhood to go to the printer and right click on it and choose "connect"?

-- Will watch for additional details and will update then.

**Update**
I'm sorry for the confusion.



Personally I have found that if you download and install the printer drivers on each computer you have less issues than using the run command to print. (especially if you are running different versions of Windows).

When you go into My Network Places and you click on View Workgroup Computers.  It should show the computers in your home network.  Double click on the one the printer is attached to and you should see the printer (with the name you gave it). Right mouse click on it and click Connect (sometimes this automatically install the drivers if you are using the same version of windows).

Also if you go to Epson's support page it may have step by step instructions on how to set up your printer on a network--that is what I did when I was setting up a Vista Notebook.



</answer>

<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware

<question from>



capt. Rachel Garret
Member since: 23 April 2008
Total points: 136 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is the top printer for under £100?



For general all round home use.  I don't expect it to produce 5,000,000 sheets a day, but I do expect it to still be working 2 to 5 years later.  There would be some photo printing, so consumables -especially ink cost- are a factor.

Cheers.



</question>



<additional details>



PS:  Specific suggestions please.  "a canon" doesn't help me too much, sorry.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Dixons.c...
Member since: 19 May 2008



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



Hi Capt. Rachel,

With £100 to spend there are literally hundreds of different printers available and sorting the wheat from the chaff can be difficult, Of course while there are some that are not as good, there are also many that are very high quality.

Printer prices have seen dramatic reductions in recent months, but the one thing that remains constant is the cost of inks. This is the same across all brands, with some manufacturers offering individual inks while others offer single multi cartridges. The outcome of this is that they all cost roughly the same, with Epson perhaps a little cheaper for colour printing.

The Epson Stylus DX7450 Printer, Scanner & Copier. This all-in-one printer saves you space and money. It has a very high print resolution (5760 x 1440 dpi) has a digital card reader integrated and is Pictbridge ready so you can print straight from your digital memory card. It uses four individual inks, 3 colours and one black. And at £79.99 it very well priced.

Another option is from Hewlett Packard. The HP Photosmart C4280 is also an all-in-one Printer, Scanner & Copier, but also has the added feature of being wireless ready, meaning that if you have any wireless ready laptops, or PC's or even a wireless network, you can connect to the printer from anywhere in the house without a cable. It prints at a resolution of 4800 x 1200 dpi and also has a integrated digital card reader and comes Pictbridge ready. The HP uses one 'tri colour' cartridge and one black. The price for this model is also £79.99.

Both these machines are ideal for general home use a will deliver high standard prints in colour and black & white, while the scanner and copier features are handy and make it nice and compact. They also both come in under £100 making both great value for money.

Hope this helps in your search, let us know what you decide to buy!



Source(s):



http://www.dixons.co.uk



s



</answer>

<question>

Joe P
Member since: 16 October 2007

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Voters</evaluation>



If you reinstalled your operating system (windows ?) you will need to reinstall your audio drivers. To see if they are installed go to control panel then sounds. select the sounds tab then highlight one of the sounds with a speaker icon. the play arrow should turn black if it doesn't your drivers arent' installed if it does turn black and you have no sound when you click it, its your hook up

<question from>



MT
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 68 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



MP510 printer scanning help!!!?



hi, just today i was scanning some photos on my canon mp510 printer and saving it to my pc, i have about 5 pictures on my pc from everything i have scanned and are very small in size, but just today i got a message saying insufficient memory when i try to scan the images. its nothing to do with my computer because i have a lot of free space!

What do i do!

Thanks



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi
Cause



Action



Output Resolution set too high.



Restart the computer, decrease the Output Resolution setting, and rescan.



For details, refer to the Scanning Guide on-screen manual.



Your computer's hard disk does not have enough available space.



When scanning large originals at a high resolution, an error may occur if there is insufficient hard disk space. Check that the hard disk has sufficient free space, and rescan.



When scanning large originals at a high resolution, the progress bar may stay at 0 % depending on your computer. Set a smaller scanning area or a lower resolution, and rescan.



You have multiple devices connected to the USB ports of the computer.



Try disconnecting all other external devices except this machine.



your output resolution may be set too high



Source(s):



from the scanning manual of the MP510



</answer>

<question>



Does it matter how old your computer if i want a new install graphic card ?



As my computer  is quite old but i want to install nvidia 8400 gs because it is cheap but my friend said my computer would be too old to install



PS my computer is a dell dimension 4550



</question>



<answer from>



Monkeypi...
Member since: 26 November 2007
Total points: 3220 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes it matters you need to consider its power needs etc but most importantly you will need to know if it will fit on to your motherboard old boards dont have the slots for new cards..

Old mother boards usualy have an AGP graphics slot
Where as the new graphics cards are going to PCI-E slots



</answer>



<answer from>



wdealers
Member since: 18 September 2008

<answer from>



daniel t
Member since: 10 January 2008
Total points: 238 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes

Your computer will need to have the right expnasion slot on your motherboard. I would assume that as the graphics card you are looking to install is quite new that it would be PCI Express, you need to make sure you have this expansion slot on your motherboard or you wont be able to plug it in

Also be ware, its a Dell!!! They would have dont everything possible to ensure that if you did ever want a new graphics card that you would have to go through them first



</answer>



<answer from>



louscann...
Member since: 30 April 2006
Total points: 9003 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your PC has an AGP 4X slot - the 8400GS is not an option.

Whilst there are AGP 4X cards still available, the graphic on the link below shows a peculiarly truncated card - it doesn't extend beyond the rear of the AGP slot.
I suspect that this is because if it did, it would foul the hard disk drive cradle. I'm basing this on the graphic in the second link, but you will be able to check this for yourself...

If there is a length restriction, then you could consider moving your HDD into the  floppy drive cradle... even if it means removing the floppy drive (who needs it?). 
IF (that was a big if) you can remove the HDD cradle AND that leaves the rear of the AGP slot unobstructed - then you can now investigate what AGP 4X cards are available...

[Edit]: OcUK have a 256Mb GeForce 6200 at £27.01
and a 512Mb Radeon 2600 Pro at £58.74
Performance-wise, these cards bracket the 8400GS, but the 6200 will make less demands on power - Dell's PSU (in keeping with the rest of the system) does not allow much scope for upgrading...



Source(s):



http://support.dell.com/support/edocs/sy...
http://support.dell.com/support/edocs/sy...

http://www.overclockers.co.uk/showproduc...
http://www.overclockers.co.uk/showproduc...



</answer>

Kevin

</answer from>



<answer>



That sort of depends on your operating system. If your using Windows XP, 1-2 gb of ram is usually enough (unless being used for intensive gaming).



If using Windows Vista you could use 2-4 gb of ram to get it to run smoother.
Keep in mind, if your version of windows is a 32 bit version it will only run a maximum of 4gb combined ram (shared between video card, ram, etc) where as a 64 bit version will be able to utilize more than 4 gb.



</answer>



<answer from>



L C
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 226 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You should have as much ram as your pc can accept. It is the single most cost effective way to improve the performance of your pc



</answer>



<answer from>



Tim W
Member since: 22 May 2007
Total points: 8560 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Military



Security



</answer from>



<answer>



Run the programs you normally have running (Outlook, IE, FF, Word, etc) or load your favorite game that may be having performance problems.



Click CTRL+ALT+Delete. Go to Task Manager. Click on Performance.

You want to make sure that you do not use more than 60 percent of your Physical Memory. So for me, I have 1.5GB of physical memory. I do not want to use more than .94GB used. Right now I am using .38GB so I am good to go!

If you go above the 60 percent, you will start queuing programs. Basically information will be standing in line to be processed by the CPU. Additionally, the program will start trying to push information to your page file (on your hard drive) which is 1000s of times slower than physical memory.

What are you doing when the computer is running slowly?



Surfing the Internet delays usually have NOTHING to do with your computer, they have to do with your ISP.

If you configured Norton wrong, it could be running a Full Scan while your trying to use the computer.  You should schedule the Full Scan to run late at night, right after you schedule Symantec/Norton to download new definitions.

By the way, Symantec/Norton is an EXCELLENT choice to use as your AV.  You want to use a Paid For product.  The reason why people think AVG and AVAST are because they are VERY poor at Real Time scanning!



</answer>



<answer from>



FRAGGER
Member since: 02 June 2008
Total points: 856 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



1 GB is best for XP,  2GB for Vista. You can check your RAM by right clicking My Computer icon on the desktop, then choose Properties. That's how you can do it on XP. Look closely at the list.



</answer>

<question>



Dell Inspiron 5100 Laptop turning on problem?



I was downloading  wireless software and I got an error and I shut off the laptop and try to restart it but since then I am having problem turning on the laptop. I turn it on and I hear noise and see green light but after 15 seconds I see a flash on screen and laptop shuts off. I have checked battery and AC adapter. They are ok..

Few days ago on someone's advise to check memory module at the back of laptop I just opend the cover of Memory module and I was trying to take them out but I could n't but when I press there I guess the chip and power on the laptop the same time ,my laptop turns on. Since then if I have to turn on the my laptop, I have to open it back and press memory module and turn on power it works.

I don't know much about the computers. Can I fix this problem without spending too much money?

Can someone help me with that?

Thanks



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



That sounds odd, double check the memory modules are in properly and if there are any loose screws tighten them LIGHTLY. and avoid touching metal against circutry.

You can take it in for an inspection, they take maybe an hour or two and cost anywhere from $20-80 depending on the store.



</answer>

epidavro...
Member since: 30 July 2006
Total points: 26115 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Its simply not true that Macs don't get viruses. They are also about twice the price on a price per performance basis, and only have about 0.5% of the amount of software available for them that Windows and Linux do. Indeed if you use OPne Source, then they have almost no software available for them. Hopeless.

Which? consumer reviews rated all major brands and of the non Apple ones (Apple were indeed reliable)  IBM/Lenovo was the most reliable, followed by Sony, Dell, Toshiba, Compaq and HP in that order.

In fact HPand Compaq are the same company.



I have heard horror stories about Dell (from Dell employees). Most IT companies I have worked for will only use Toshiba or HP/Compaq.

The main thing with a laptop is to remember they are much less reliable than desktops, are vey expensive to repair - so it can make sense to buy an extended warranty. But buy it from the manufacturer, not the shop - its about 1/3 the price.



</answer>

<answer from>



Tyrus
Member since: 28 October 2007
Total points: 8023 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Laptops & Notebooks



</answer from>



<answer>



Most Laptops will last 4 years.  At that point the Motherboard goes. On a Mac, because the components are selected to run faster and cooler, it is not unusual for laptops to least 7-10 years

A lot of people make the mistake of when comparing  PC to a Mac of not comparing the correct hardware.  In truth, it you compare the quality of the parts and a PC (not a lot of people understand the difference in RAM for instance), you will find equal pricing.  If you couple that with superior performance, better Matte Screen and 64 bit OS that can use all 4 GB RAM if needed as opposed o 3 for Vista or XP.I think you have a winner with a Mac.  The most popular model is, by far the MacBook.  The top of the line is the MacBook Pro. Mac can run leopard and XP or Vista if you want.



Vista and XP run quite a bit better on a Mac than on PC with the OS pre-loaded.  It also runs multi-media much clearer than Window



</answer>

<question from>



honey

</question from>



<question>



Problem with printing straight?



i have a MP 220 CANON PIXMA printer (from argos), ive been trying to copy and print but all my documents are not printing out properly, the writing isn't coming out straight, ive performed print head alignment on both the laptop and printer but now the paper is getting jammed in the printer!
can anyone help? am thinking of returning the product...
thanks in advanced



</question>



<answer from>



T M
Member since: 08 December 2007
Total points: 412 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



HI Make sure you have set the paper guides each side of the paper .And there is nothing been dropped inside.



Regards Mac



</answer>



<answer from>



Paddingt...
Member since: 05 January 2007
Total points: 6377 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



That's Argos for you!  I had trouble with printers from there.  I have this same model and mine works great but sometimes it gets slanted as I have loaded the paper in wrong.



Have you  taken the paper out, tapped it together and put it back in and made sure you have not overloaded it? If overloaded then sometimes the printer grabs more than one sheet and this then jams it.  So, tap it together, then fan out and re-tap it and put it back in, and, as the person above said, make sure that the page gauge is up close to the paper as this keeps it straight and stops it sliding about.  If it still does it take it back and tell them it is not fit for purpose and they have to either give you another one or a refund.



</answer>

</answer>

i had one like that, i removed the ball and cleaned with a baby wipe and used a cotton bud inside the mouse, it is surprising how much dust and fluff collects

<question>



Can I copy my old hardrive onto an external hardrive?



I put my old hardrive into an enclosure, but I can't open it on my computer. A message keeps popping up saying there's an error with I/O device. So, is it possible for me to copy my entire old hardrive to my external hardrive if I plug them both into the computer at the same time?



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I/O (in out) error can be anything.



try plugging the enclosure to another usb port, also the enclosure your using may be a dud.



if this drive is ATA you can install it inside your pc (providing its no longer under warranty) and set it as slave.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



yes



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



If the new one is an external (USB) hard drive plug it into your usb port.
copy the contents of your old hard drive directly into your new one plugged into usb port.
If the new one is an ATA device connect it into secondary ATA port or connect as slave in primary port itself.
After O.S is booted you can see the new device in MY COMPUTER
copy the content



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes you can do it easily.
If the new one is an external (USB) hard drive plug it into your usb port.
copy the contents of your old hard drive directly into your new one plugged into usb port.
If the new one is an ATA device connect it into secondary ATA port or connect as slave in primary port itself.
After  O.S is booted you can see the new device in MY COMPUTER
copy the content



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



yes  both maxtor and seagate provide free utilities for download that will make it very easy to do.



</answer>



<answer from>

<original file>429.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk52980.txt</current file name>




<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



Nov.12.1...
Member since: 06 July 2008
Total points: 65 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Do  RAM of the same family and storage space usually come with the same frecuency ?



i mean, do most of the DDR 512 come with the same frecuency among DDR 512?



and so on?
or can speed vary in between 512



-i was born Nov.12 1989



</question>



<answer from>



John W
Member since: 23 December 2006
Total points: 6853 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



If it was November 12, I would wish you a happy birthday. What's that go to do with anything?  Anyway, if you are thinking of upgrading your RAM, I would recommend looking at the RAM sticks that are already in your computer. Be sure you shut the computer down and unplug everything from it before you open it though.  Also, buy an antistatic wrist strap from Radio Shack, Best Buy or some computer store and wear it before you touch anything inside your computer. Don't want to fry any parts by shocking it with static charges you know.  Then, push down on the little white or black levers on both sides of the RAM stick and it will pop up.  Now you can see it better.  It should say the PC number, storage and frequency on the stick.  If it doesn't, write down the make and model of the stick and look that up on the maker's website.  It will tell you there what the specs of the RAM are.  Then, find RAM that matches the PC number and frequency.  You may find that you can get RAM sticks that are compatible with multiple frequencies.  These sticks will "downclock" to lower frequencies depending on what motherboard they are plugged into.  For example, some 3333 sticks are compatible with motherboards running RAM at 2700.  If you get Kingston brand, it will say right on the package what other frequencies it is compatible with.  With some other brands, you will have to check the website BEFORE you open the RAM package to see if they will downclock to the frequency you need.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



great answer



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



CanadaRA...
Member since: 26 August 2008
Total points: 6493 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Software



Laptops & Notebooks



Security



</answer from>



<answer>



No, there are many variations --  for DDR RAM there are 266 MHz, 333 MHz, 400 MHz and more 'overclocked' speeds.



There are also differences in physical size -- DIMM, SODIMM, MicroDIMM -- and in configuration of the memory on the module -- Non-ECC, ECC Registered, ECC Unbuffered, density: 4 chip vs 8 chip vs 16 chip, and other parameters.



</answer>



<answer from>



RaffiThe...
Member since: 29 July 2008
Total points: 4456 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think they come in different..



</answer>



<answer from>



chiara
Member since: 14 August 2008
Total points: 0 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



not always



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Whats the difference between ???...?



DIMM, SODIMM, MicroDIMM



-i was born Nov.12 1989



</question>



<answer from>



idontkno...
Member since: 16 September 2008
Total points: 1022 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



DIMM is for desktop,



SODIMM is for laptop,



MicroDIMM is smaller than SODIMM and is for laptop, sub-laptop system also.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Best answer



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



RaffiThe...
Member since: 29 July 2008
Total points: 4456 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



DIMM is used for desktop computers, SODIMM and Microdimm I believe is used to notebook Pc's or laptop, that I am not sure, but the DIMM I know is used for Desktop PC's.
DIMM Stand for Dual Inline Memory Module, And then there was SIMM, (which was the older generation of DIMM) which stand for Single Inline Memory Module.



</answer>



<answer from>



Derran G
Member since: 12 August 2008
Total points: 1370 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DIMM



</answer>

<question>



My computer has suddenly stopped playing DVD's properly. Help!?



I've only had my comp about 2 years, all DVDs I've tried playing on it have played fine so far. I bought a brand new DVD recently, after not having played a DVD on my comp in about 2/3 months, I tried it out, I used about 5 different programes to try and play the same DVD but it started and than it stopped, flickered, smudged/smeared across the screen, paused for ages. I tried with some other old DVD's (that used to work on my comp) and a similar sort of thing happened. I thought the lense might be dirty/dusty so I bought a lens cleaner and tried it out, but no change, I also exchanged my new DVDs (just incase they were faulty), but no change. Somebody told me to try this (where it says "click here" under the quick solution) http://winhlp.com/node/10 and these are my DMA results: http://img219.imageshack.us/img219/9021/...



http://img218.imageshack.us/img218/9251/...



Those pictures above are only for the 'first' IDE channels, I also checked the others, and on the second option for the Primary IDE channel it said Ultra DMA Mode 5 next to the current transfer mode and on the third option for secondary IDE channel it said Ultra DMA Mode 2 next to the current transfer mode.



After all that, I tried a DVD again, and it seems to have worsened, now they won't even start, they just load and than the screen freezes and in the task manager the progam appears as "not responding".



I don't know what to do =( Please, try and keep answers simple and easy to understand, I'm not too tech savvy. Thanks in advance for any help, I will choose a best answer for the response that helps me solve this problem.

<answer from>

why not buy a dvd player and enjoy them on your tv? just a thought

<answer from>



no answerer details

<answer>



I had the same problem. For me it got so bad that it would not detect DVDs at all.  Try to put in a different CD such as music. Then whether it plays or not, try a software CD.  If the music CD and the software CD runs,  it is likely that your DVD lens in the drive was damaged.  For me, all the places I checked said that I had to replace my CD Rom drive.



I hope this helps.



Source(s):



Experienced a similar problem.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>

no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



It has nothing to do with DMA. If you leave a DVDROM unused for sometime, it develops that tendency not to read anymore. It simply needs a lens cleaning. Go out and find a good DVDTOM lens cleaner and use it.

http://www.free-codecs.com/download/dvd_...

<question>



Can you add usb ports to a computer and if so how ?



I  have a Dell deminsion

<answer from>

<answer>



Its called a USB hub. You connect it to a single usb port on your laptop and the device gives around 4 more.



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USB_hub



</answer>



<answer from>



amarniit
Member since: 15 January 2007
Total points: 230 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



normaly my dear ............... if you can open your cabinet and watch your mother board than you may found some blank pins or nacked ping with the groups od 5+4 .....



9-9 pin and in its bottom it also write that serial or USB 1 USB2 like as you can use these pins ok
connect it via help of Usb connecter or serial cable.................
got it ok do and enjoy



Source(s):



http://admin.amarniit.co.cc



</answer>



<answer from>



DUNBAR PAPPY
Member since: 27 June 2006
Total points: 5171 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



USB 'cards' can be inserted into a motherboard slot inside the tower.  Then (after the metal plate is removed from the backside) the actual USB slots (or ports) will be accessible  in the back for plugging in the device.
The cards run about  $15 and up, with 3 or more slots.  Look in walmart for quick solution; internet for best bargains.



</answer>



<answer from>



LrT
Member since: 24 November 2007
Total points: 501 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Like the others said, a USB hub is an easy external way of adding more ports.  In addition, make sure you get one that supports USB 2.0 if you are planning to use it for a high bandwidth device, like a hard drive, or flash drive reader.  This of course matters only if your computer supports USB 2.0, which is common for computers of about 6 years old and newer to have.  USB 1.1 is much slower and should be avoided unless its just a mouse and keyboard you're plugging in.



</answer>



<answer from>



Aero
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 98 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<current file name>yqa_uk57678.txt</current file name>




<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



Daniel N
Member since: 27 September 2008
Total points: 128 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



USB Flash Drive Problem :(?



:( I recently bought an 8.0 GB High-Speed USB Flash Drive from PNY. I need to transfer a Powerpoint presentation onto it for school, but I don't know how (I'm really bad with computers).



Please help me.



</question>



<answer from>



Haruka
Member since: 12 October 2006
Total points: 1540 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



OK, so find your Powerpoint and open it. Plug in your flash drive. Then in the Powerpoint window go to File, then Click Save As. There will be a bar at the top of that little window that says where you're saving it to. Click on the drop down arrow and go to Removable Disk (and the letter of your flash drive). If you aren't sure which letter it is, just try all of them until it opens up your flash drive. Then  once it's opened and everything, click Save and you're done!



If you have any more questions feel free to email me :D



Source(s):



I'm pretty good at computers ;)



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Perfect, solved my problem :). Thank you.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Help H
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 104 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



do this



1. Save your Power point to c:My Doucments ( or just so the top bar says My documenst )



2. Insert flash drive
3 If it is a u3 flash drive then it will open and there should be a button you can click that says Explore drive
4 if 3 doesnt happen then windpws ( XP ( i'm not sure about vista ) will ask what you want to open the files in the flash drive with )
5 Click "open drive to view files ( or something like that it will have a foler object next to it )
6 if 4-5 don't work then do this



1.click start
2. Go to My computer
3. Under my computer should be 3 column/groups



1.Files Stored on This Computer



2. Hard disks



3. Devices with removable storage



4. Look under the 3rd one and there should be something that says Removable disk Slot :X ( X is a variable standing for any letter so it could say disk slot:F or something like that but that should be the only thing that says removable disk
5. open up your drive



6 MINIMIZE IT DON"T EXIT
7. go to start/my documents
8 now open both windows so you can see both
9 click and hold the powerpoint file
10 drag it to you flash drive
11 at school just open up the flash drive and double click it and it should run on the computer



Hope this helped =)



</answer>



<answer from>



limouggy
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 262 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



First, save your powerpoint presentation to a place that is accessible, such as pictures, videos, music, etc.



Then plug in your flash drive. The auto start box should pop up. Scroll to the bottom and click on "view files".



then, find your powerpoint file and drag it into the auto start box (flash drive)



</answer>



<answer from>



A W
Member since: 26 February 2008
Total points: 1113 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Do you a PC?  The USB slot is probably in the front of the CPU.  If you have a laptop, it'll probably be on the side. Slide the Flash drive into the slot and when you open up "My Computer", you should see an addition drive (usully F:).  Just transfer or save the file to that drive, just like you would transfer or save it to a folder.



Source(s):



http://www.wellesley.edu/Computing/Flash...  and experience



</answer>



<answer from>



Kurtis D
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 101 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



if you plug it into a usb port, it should show up in your "My Computer" section. Then you can copy the files and paste them in there.

personal experience

<answer from>



wade2k8
Member since: 23 July 2008
Total points: 905 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



well you cant just buy these random parts in the hope theyll be compatible, first of all youll need a case, the size of the case will allow you to choose a motherboard, the motherboard will then allow you to choose a cpu as only certain motherboards are compatible with certain cpu's, also the RAM will have to be compatible with your motherboard (DDR DDRII and then different sizes of that!) also you will probably need a new PSU, if you want a custom built pc i would reccomend you buy some barebones from a site like novatech or ebay, these will be mainly compatible and you can begin choosing parts from their.



reccomended specs:
dual/quad core processor- 2.6ghz+
RAM 3gb (more than enough)
Graphics card 256mb ati/nvidia
PSU 500 w minimum
a couple of high grade fans
asus motherboard ( you will have to check the compatiblility code in the description of the motherboard to get a compatible CPU)



</answer>

<answer>

<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



dr_kryst...
Member since: 19 May 2007
Total points: 138 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Slow buffering! What can I do about my internet connection speed?



I went to the dslreports website to test my internet connection speed but I don't understand the results because it all sounds like martian.  But I am pretty sure my connection speed is slow and I have buffering issues when I try to watch shows online. The results from the speed show my download speed is:  1271 kbs and my upload speed is: 389 Kbs



the latency is: 110 ms my line speed is 384 k but people who have tested in my area 1336 kb. I'm really not sure what all this means. Is my connection slow and can I complain to Verizon? I'm not sure what to say to them.  Thanks in advance.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



You can always try complaining.



1271kbs stands for kilobits per second.  That's probably still martian to you.  There are 8 bits in a byte, so that 158 kilobytes per second.  Your probably familiar with kilobytes and megabytes so that should be a number that makes some sense to you.  Upload speed isn't that import since you rarely send large amounts of information out to the web (usually all you'll send it a small string telling a website which page you want to view).



the other number aren't important, at least in terms of buffering.



Your speed is fairly fast.  I'm supprised your having issues.  It could be that the site your connecting to is going slow.  Your connection speed varies a lot.  It could be that you just happened to test at a time when it was going fast.  Try testing it at at different times.



1271kbps sounds well within the range of DSL, but you could always trying complaining.  It can't hurt.



Your only option maybe be to pay more money for a faster connection.



</answer>






<original file>12358.html</original file>

Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



confusesd lad returns
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 152 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What is  IDE or EIDE and master/slave selection?



please simply detail



</question>



<answer from>



Simon Williams
Member since: 05 July 2007
Total points: 1254 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Basically, its where 2 drives are connected via the same IDE/EIDE connection, one as master, one as slave. EG you would have your HDD as Master, and then connect your CDROM on the same ribbon to the same IDE connector on your motherboard as the slave, running though your HDD



</answer>



<answer from>



Chris C
Member since: 08 June 2007
Total points: 2690 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Programming & Design



</answer from>



<answer>



IDE/EIDE
Intelligent Drive Electronics / Enhanced Intelligent Drive Electronic



Master/slave selection is due to one have the ability to take control of the system bus in order to send/receive information from either memory, or the CPU.
The master device which is connected by the same cable typically, will have the ability to take control of the bus away from the slave if necessary.



Source(s):



http://www.webopedia.com/TERM/I/IDE_inte...
http://www.webopedia.com/TERM/E/EIDE.htm...



</answer>



<answer from>



Zabee Pakistan
Member since: 02 October 2007
Total points: 2165 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



YouTube



</answer from>



<answer>



Dear Bro,
it is said:
A picture is worth a thousand words.
so we can say:
A Video is worth a billion words.
i can easily describe these things but i have a better solution for u.
you may learn about these term and complete setting by clicking on the following link (a gift for u):
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YFUDfLOxf...



Hope you will Find this answer Helpful
Wish Ya Good Luck :-)



</answer>

<question>



WINDOWS folder causing Low Disk Space Problem?



My WINDOWS folder keeps getting bigger, now it's taking up 30.9GB of my C: Drive. I already ran CCleaner to delete unnecessary files. I scanned my pc for some viruses but no malware/spyware/virus was found. I tried to defrag it but nothing changed.



I found out that WINDOWS/Installer is taking up more than 20GB of the WINDOWS folder. Is it safe to delete some files from it? I don't know what files to delete.



I really need some help about this problem , I need more disk space because I only have 250MB space left. (My drive C: only contains WINDOWS folder and some important files... My games/music/movies/etc... are in another Hard Disk)



Thanks in advance



</question>

<question>



Sound card question! Thank you?



I have an onboard soundcard (Realtek High Definition audio).
And i want buy a new one like Creative Sound Blaster X-FI Xtreme Gamer Soundcard or



Creative Labs X-Fi Soundcard Extreme Music. Now my question. Are those sound cards better than the one i have now?
And which sound card would be good for me as i produce music.



Thank you in advance



</question>



<additional details>



I have Logitech X-540 5.1 speakers



</additional details>



<answer from>



Vaibhav
Member since: 06 July 2008
Total points: 173 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think Realtek High Definition card is good..thats the one i too use



but i think creative labs x-fi soundcard xtreme music would be the better one tha creative sound blaster xtreme gamer



</answer>



<answer from>



arledget...
Member since: 29 April 2007
Total points: 3014 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Any creative sound card will be MUCH better than your onboard sound. I have a $30 Creative card and absolutely love it, especially with my Logitech speakers and subwoofer. As for producing music, I would go with the Extreme Music, as it probably has better inputs for producing than gaming, which focuses on outputs to speakers. The Extreme Music will still sound amazing though.



Good Luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Jeremy T
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 3134 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your onboard sound card is probably fine.  You'd probably be better off buying higher quality speakers.  If you already have high quality speakers, and you have very good hearing, you might be able to notice a different with a more expensive sound card.



A sound card will only affect the way sound is played on your computer.  It will not help music production.  Creating or mixing of sound on your computer is the job of your processor.  Its quality depends solely on the quality of the software you using to make/edit the music.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bob B
Member since: 17 December 2006
Total points: 1168 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



there is a third option.
http://www.geeks.com/details.asp?invtid=...
just plug into a USB port and its up and running i have 2 different ones ,one for my laptop one so when setting up a computer i have sound with out hunting down drivers for sound card,something that can be done a lot later.



the sound card will not improve the quality of what you produce only make it sound a little better on local machine.its mostly the program that you use to work the sound files.



</answer>

whitetop...
Member since: 16 May 2007

<answer>

4.0 support is for DX10 in Vista.



Yes the card will work in XP but will show 3.0.

<question from>



jeep_kid...
Member since: 05 October 2008

</question from>



<question>



How do i know if my sound card matches the drivers I'm looking for?



I have a computer that was built for me by my neighbor.  When he brought it over everything worked great except I'm getting a message that says "no audio output device is installed"  He said he installed a Realtek soundcard but I've tried downloading all the drivers and can't get it to work.



When I type dxdiag and look at the sound tab it isn't showing a card.  Is there a way to check what kind of card it is.  I'm assuming I'm not installing the right drivers.



</question>



<answer from>



archie12...
Member since: 14 September 2008
Total points: 499 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



If its realtech im guessing its onboard sound (built into your motherboard)



go into your bios settings and make sure the option for onboard sound is enabled , or if it is a seperate card make sure the option for onboard sound is disabled.



you could always try and "search for new hardware" using the "add hardware" option in windows (its in your control panel) if it finds the card brilliant , if it doesnt its either faulty or just not there , take the side off your pc and see if you can see one



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I've been trying to figure this out for 4 months now and this is the first time someone recommended checking the bios onboard selection.



</asker's comment>

<question from>



Enslaved
Member since: 12 November 2007
Total points: 92 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



From experience how does Leadtek GeForce 9500GT 512mb 128bit GDDR3 compare to the Inno3D Geforce 8500GT 512mb?



I was hoping to buy me a Leadtek GeForce 9500GT 512mb 128-bit GDDR3 card and am currently running a Inno3D GeForce 8500GT 128-bit DDR2...  However on the one site I was on it seems I'm better off now?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



You will not see any major improvements in performance. If you are on a budget and want a noticeable change you should get a 9600GSO. Now mind you that upgrading from the 8500GT is only worth it if you are gaming and have low framerates. You can find the 9600GSO for $80 without a rebate here:
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.as...
or for $60 with a rebate here:
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.as...



Source(s):



I game on a XFX overclocked 8800GTS 512MB and have a KFA2 8500GT 512MB in my home theater PC.



</answer>

<question>



I am having problem with receiving Fax.Can anyone please suggest me solution to this problem?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



1. make sure the phone line is connected to the correct port (there are 2 on the back of most facsimile machines)
2. make sure the line is working(plug a regular phone in to the jack you should receive a dial tone)



3. make sure that the number dialed is correct



Good luck



</answer>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



What video card would it be?



i have a dell xps  410



3 gb ram
intel core something 2.3 ghz



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Every dell machine is different. To find out, open up the control panel, then open up the device manager. Once the device manager is opened up, find the display/video adapter tab and expand it, your graphics card/processing chip will be listed there.



</answer>

<original file>15078.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk64967.txt</current file name>




<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



beccαThe...
Member since: 28 January 2008
Total points: 231 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



EyeToy as webcam for Windows Vista?



Does anyone know if a Namtai EyeToy will work on a computer with Windows Vista?



Also, EyeToys don't have sound hooked up, do they?
So, I'd have to buy a microphone for my computer, right?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



They work, but all the trouble to get it to work is not worth it. At least as far as I have seen.



EyeToys DO NOT have sound on them. PS2's were not able to handle sound easily in its' days, so EyeToys do not have sound.



Yes, you'd have to buy a microphone. No, it does not have to be the kind you wear around your head (although it's really useful!).
There are good quality microphones which stand on the desk, out of sight of the camera.



Source(s):



the Winamp eyetoy guide had like 10-15 steps.
I use a dang stand-on-desk microphone.



</answer>

<answer>



If you have Windows, you can back up all System files and document files by clicking My Computer Icon on Desktop ( XP ) Computer Icon on Vista. Right click where you have the Installed your OS, ex. C:/ drive, click Properties, Click on Tools, Click Backup now, All will be backup in that Volume selecting your Portable HDD where it will be save.



</answer>

itsme

</question from>



<question>



A better video card than this one?



Which video card (price included) would make a huge upgrade in my computer ????



AMD athlon 64 processor 3700+
2.2 Ghz, IMB L2 cache, 2000 mhz system bus
nvidia geforce 6100 GPU
Hard Drive 200 Gb
Memory 1024 MB DDR



</question>



<answer from>



nick6555...
Member since: 05 October 2008
Total points: 155 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you want to stick with Nvidia any of these would be a huge upgrade:



http://www.nvidia.com/page/geforce8.html



It all depends on what you need it for - will you be going on graphic-intensive games like Crysis on high settings or something liek Counter Strike 1.6?



</answer>



<answer from>



Zach T
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 119 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If it's overall performance you're looking for-start with the RAM.  Get to at least 3 gb for a fast machine.



Video card comes second.



Gaming? Go with the nvidia 8800GT, it retailed at $450 brand new, now the new 9000 series are out, so this card's price has dropped to the low $200 range.  Any of the 8000 series from nvidia can handle DirectX10 gaming when paired with Vista.



Ram first, that is where the most noticable gains will come from.



Source(s):



www.newegg.com



</answer>



<answer from>



TIM S
Member since: 19 February 2008
Total points: 198 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You're going to want to know a couple of things. First, does your computer have an AGP slot, a PCIe x16 slot, or a PCIe 2.0 slot for the new video card? Next, do you want it for gaming, or video quality?
For gaming, nVidia rules. For video quality, ATI is best.
The nVidia 8800GT is a great gaming card. I've got one in my gamer now, and it outperforms the ATI card in my HTPC. The HTPC has an ATI Radeon HD 3650, which I'd never use for gaming, but has an awesome picture on my HDTV.
The nVidia card cost me $100+ more than the ATI. Both are perfect for what they're intended for.



</answer>

<question from>



Hanna P
Member since: 01 August 2008
Total points: 59 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



My cousins has only 512mbs of ram in her computer but has no trouble with games such as The sims 2?



I don't have much Ram in my computer, so i was wondering if anyone could tell me why The game runs so fast on her computer, but so choppy and slow on mine?



</question>



<answer from>



iswd1
Member since: 08 September 2006
Total points: 6208 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ram is only one consideration of game speed. Processor speed, video card ram...etc, all make a difference. If she has a much faster processor or a lot more video ram, could be why.



Source(s):



http://www.ourworldinphotos.com &lt;-- visit my site and share your photos!



</answer>



<answer from>



cute_lov...
Member since: 28 February 2008
Total points: 190 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Most of the new games speed depends on how much better processor and graphic+3d card you have installed on your pc.... If you have a higher quality graphic card and a faster processor you can run these games faster....



</answer>



<answer from>



Leonhart
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 220 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It all depends on your computer.



1. Amount of RAM installed. (at least 256MB)
2. Processor type (should be x86) and the speed.
3. Video card compatibility (128MB+ supporting DirextX 9c and Pixel Shader - only in ATI cards and nVidia GeForce 3 - 4 Ti)



</answer>



<answer from>



Wickedpe...
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 297 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Different games use different resources on your computer. Sims 2 only requires



* 800 MHz processor



* 256 MB RAM if Windows XP



* 128 MB RAM if Windows 98, Windows ME, or Windows 2000



* At least 3.5 gigs of free hard drive space



Depending on your RAM Processor and Video Card is how well a game is going to run on your computer. Every game is going to have different requirements.



Also you might be running other applications that take up resources (internet browser, IM, iTunes, ect) This will use up some of your resources and might cause lower frame rates in your game.



Enjoy playing Sims.



</answer>

<question>



There is a message appear in the desktop ?

<answer from>



eastbear
Member since: 14 July 2008
Total points: 831 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Install your usb devices.



</answer>



<answer from>



chezzrob
Member since: 27 September 2007
Total points: 20611 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



do the usb bit below



Laptop. Desktop  Power settings
==========================
Right click on the empty space on the desktop &gt;properties &gt;screensaver tab &gt;power



set everything to never in the drop down menu.
Choose if you want to login on screensaver restore
disable hibernation
choose what you want to do when lid closes, or power button etc.
click the battery tab and set the alarm and stuff so the battery will never fully discharge..
set up a screen saver say 15 minutes is ok
apply etc



Then open device manager (see help files - click start &gt; help and support)
Or right click the my computer icon &gt;manage &gt;device manager
Look for and expand the universal serial bus
right click on each one listed underneath  &gt;properties &gt;power tab
choose so the power stays on.. Do each USB listed that has a Power tab.



This is the best set up to eliminate hassles to help trouble shooting. Only choose power saving settings if you really have to.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bharat c
Member since: 18 May 2008
Total points: 2914 (Level 4)

<question from>



Xaio

</question from>



<question>



Can you put any CPU in any Motherboard with the right slot?



i have a HP asterope 1.0, and its got a crappy P4 in it... i want to buy a Dual Core CPU and install it!



just need to know if i need to change anything first



</question>



<answer from>



cute_lov...
Member since: 28 February 2008
Total points: 182 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



comonly all new types of main boards fits in all casings. but contact a hardware expert instead of struggling here.....



</answer>



<answer from>



themaste...
Member since: 11 September 2008
Total points: 183 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



no the socket type has to be correct and even then the motherboard specs will determine what speed of CPU will be supported.  Most likely need to upgrade the MOBO as well...



</answer>



<answer from>



Fox
Member since: 24 February 2008
Total points: 6819 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on if the mobo will support a dual core. Some motherboards are upgrade friendsly like ASUS where all it takes is a BIOS update. Some computers that are designed for a single core CPU at first, are only compatible with just that. You'll want to contact HP and find out for sure.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mark
Member since: 16 March 2008
Total points: 1596 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



The motherboard in there uses a socket 775, which is an Intel socket (No AMD for you). Most of Intel's dual core processors will fit that socket type, but the online manual I found for that motherboard does not list anything above a Pentium D Dual Core as supported hardware.



Check the manual that you were provided with when you bought the system. If that's not an option, call HP, just to make sure. Or, you can take it in to a local shop and ask them if they carry any CPUs for that motherboard.



No point in buying a CPU just to find out it won't fit...



</answer>

<answer from>



Dan

</answer from>



<answer>



Make sure that the monitor's connection to the video card is good, a lot of the times this happens its because one or more of the monitor connector's pins are bent back and not making proper contact with the port on the back of the computer.



Also make sure that the video card is seated properly inside the AGP slot on the motherboard. Press it into the slot firmly, even if the card is just slightly not all the way in it could give you a ton of problems.



You could also try cleaning out the AGP slot on your motherboard with compressed air, just to make sure it is making proper contact.



Good luck! Hope this helps!



</answer>

</question from>



<question>



What is the difference between the DVI Cable types?



Alright, what I am trying to do is hook my computer up to my TV.



My computer's DVI port is 3 rows of 8 pins each.  On the end of it, it has the hole for the slightly larger connector (not quite a pin, but more square shaped), surrounded by 4 pin holes.  It also has a small slot going vertically through the horizontal slot.



My TV's DVI port is 3 rows of 8 pins each, but does not have the 4 pin holes around the larger connector on the end. It doesn't have the vertical slot, either.



Could someone please tell me which types of DVI ports these are and possibly where I could find a cable to connect them? Thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



minnesno...
Member since: 05 October 2008
Total points: 125 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



There are 4 different types of DVI connectors. It sounds like your computer has a DVI-I connector and your TV has a DVI-D connector. In some cases it's possibe to connect these together, read up about DVI connectors and formats on this page to figure out if it will work for you or not: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_Vis...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



If I understand that Wikipedia page correctly, I can just get a DVI-D to DVI-D connector to connect the 2 of them. Thanks, and I'll be sure to look into it some more before I go out and buy anything.



</asker's comment>

<question>



When i put my dvd disk in the dvd drive no files appear but ive put the files in the disk from other computer?



my disk is DVD+R



its compatible from 1x-16x
its 4.7 GB
i had put some files in the disk from other computer n reconfirm that there are files in the CD by putting the CD again in the drive and i saw that there are files in the CD
but when i put my disk in my DVD Drive no files appear in front of me in the cd

it is really important

<answer from>



ADEWALE A
Member since: 12 September 2006
Total points: 4978 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Putting the files inside your CD does not automatically copy or write the files into your CD. You have to select that option for your file to be written or burnt on the CD. If you just put the files into your CD, what you have done is to put the file into a buffer, you still need to write the file permanently into the CD. You can either use a CD burning software or you use the one that came with your CD drive.



</answer>

<answer from>



Allie
Member since: 22 August 2008
Total points: 143 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



A PCI Express card is the best way to go since on board video cards don't have the extra memory that you get when you use a separate video card. You could get a motherboard with a on board video card and a separate video card and if they are compatible you could crossfire it, I don't know the specifics, but I plan on getting a new motherboard myself with on board video so I can have something in case my video card breaks I'll still have the on board card so I am not computerless.



And also don't buy a cheap motherboard, especially don't buy from ECS. I bought my first motherboard from them and it died in 5 months, then they sent me a defective motherboard again, and it just wasn't worth it and I am under $70.00 now because of it and without my computer working, I have to use someone else's until I get the money for my new parts. So keep that in mind that sometimes paying more is far more worth it, otherwise you might get stuck with your computer not working.



</answer>

<question>



Windows Media Player Not Playing Discs Properly?

<question>



How does driver detective work?

<answer from>



drummerb...
Member since: 24 February 2007

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Hi maximus
Driver Detective will maintain your system updated and optimized with the latest drivers.



Finding the correct and current drivers to update your system the fastest and easiest way possible is now provided to you with Driver Detective. This new version of Driver Detective has been built from the ground up and is an industry first in providing manufacturer specific drivers for your computer.



For example, if you own a Dell computer Driver Detective will recommend drivers specifically for your Dell computer. The improved interface makes it simple to find which drivers are out of date on your system, and to download available updates for them.



The Driver Detective can identify devices that are without drivers and identify devices that are not plugged in (cameras, MP3 players). The program has new improved interface and it's self updating.



</answer>

<original file>810.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk73617.txt</current file name>




<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



Pete L
Member since: 05 October 2008
Total points: 90 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Is  ATI RADEON HD 4850 can use it with INTEL CHIPSET P43?



i wan to know because im not sure that this graphic card going to support intel chipset P43.
because on mother board said it don't support CrossFire X.



</question>



<answer from>



aviating...
Member since: 28 April 2008
Total points: 1436 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Monitors



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Yup, the HD4850 will indeed work just fine on the P43 chipset motherboard.



The P43 board has just one PCI Express 16x slot, so you can use only one video card.



If you want to hook up two HD4850s to improve graphics performance, you need a motherboard with two PCIe 16x slots and Crossfire support.  That means you want a board with either the X38, X48 or P45 chipsets.  (Note:  P45 supports XFire, but only at 8x speed per slot, not the full 16x speed as on the X38 and X48 boards).



Hope this helps.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



good work



</asker's comment>
