<answer from>



Todd
Member since: 01 April 2008
Total points: 577 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Best thing to do would be to simply buy a bigger (MUCH bigger :) ) hard drive and replace the 80GB with this, and reinstall Windows on this new hard drive, assuming you have the Windows installation disk. Using the new, bigger drive as an external hard drive is a pain - I recommend not doing this, least of all because of the slower speed it runs at...
If it's a new computer more than likely it supports at least 2 hard drives, probably 4 - just turn off your PC, unplug it, unscrew your hard drive and put the cables onto your new drive, exactly how it was on the previous drive. After installing Windows and checking it works fine, have a go at installing the 80GB drive again using the loose cables which should be found inside the case, then reformat it and use it as a backup or whatever you require...
640GB HDD's are probably the best value for money at the moment - try eBay for the best deal, if you have an account there already.



Hope this helps!



</answer>



<answer from>



DUNBAR PAPPY
Member since: 27 June 2006
Total points: 5728 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



If disk space is running out you can get a nice chunk back like this:
Enable  'compress contents' and 'allow index service'. These help optimize file recovery speed & save disk space.
Start&gt; my computer&gt; right click 'c' drive&gt; properties&gt; general tab: here check both boxes & OK.
Don't freak out if it says 3 days (or more) to run!  This drops dramatically as the process advances; just walk away and let 'er run for the duration: it will self close when done. Depending on the files & sizes, it may take several hours to do (maybe do it at night before bed?).
When done, run 'CCleaner' & defrag.
This should be done to any new systems or HDD's when fresh, to optimize disk space over the life of the drive.



</answer>



<answer from>



Joe W
Member since: 01 August 2008
Total points: 2725 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Why do you have more than 2 DvD drives?
Buy an additional hard drive or replace the existing one with a larger one, which is buying another one also!
d;o)



</answer>



<answer from>



ebox1349
Member since: 31 January 2007
Total points: 3627 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Other - Computers



Laptops & Notebooks



Monitors



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on what type of drive - most motherboards are restricted to four IDE devices, if you have SATA available on the board then you can often have 2, 4 or 6 ports and connect as many drives as you have ports. Often with two SATA you can still get 4 IDE devices connected, but with 4 or 6 you often only get the option to connect 2 IDE devices. you can get add in cards that will increase the number of available IDE devices you can run but these are not always reliable.
In any case as most others have already suggested the best option is an external drive, you can get a 400 or 500Gb drive these days for very little money. The external device will connect via your usb ports but will need a mains power socket.



</answer>

<question>



How do computers work?!?



Ok, so the question is very vague but what i really want to know, is, how do bits of plastic and metal (the hardware), make something so complex as a computer?! How does plastic and metal create pictures on screen? How does it store information? How can you make something lifeless, remember something? What in these chunks of metal makes it remember? I know I'm asking a lot but if someone could simply explain it to me I'd be really grateful!  I've been looking inside my computer trying to install a graphics chip and it's got me thinking about this...



</question>



<answer from>



therootl...
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 217 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The question if far to complex/time consuming for me to write up a couple hour explanation of everything. It's great you want to know though! Most people just use and abuse them without caring or thinking. Always ask questions and learn how things work and you will get far. I would suggest a book to answer your questions. Maybe:
ISBN # 978-0789736130



Or maybe a website like:
http://computer.howstuffworks.com/pc.htm



Good luck in your quest!



</answer>



<answer from>



Mike Riley
Member since: 03 October 2008
Total points: 222 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I first sat down at a computer when I was about 6 years old, I played games and mashed on the keyboard mostly at the beginning. Within two years my dad was teaching me how to program, and throughout my preteen and teen years I became obsessed with the study of logic, electronics, programming and all sorts of computer related topics.  I continued these studies throughout high school and college.



Today, 17 years later, having spent the majority of my working hours during those years studying computers and related topics, I still have more to learn about it and will continue to do so for years to come.



The question you're asking can't be answered in a paragraph on Yahoo! Answers, and in a lot of ways it couldn't even be properly answered in an entire book, at least not so that you would actually understand it.  You should probably start at Wikipedia, but I wouldn't hold out any hope that you'll have an understanding of how computers work from top to bottom any time soon.



Generally you'll want to learn about things in this order though:



1. Basic circuits / electricity
2. Logic gates
3. PCB boards
4. Microprocessors
5. Computer hardware
6. Programming fundamentals
7. Operating systems
8. Computer software



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer



</answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



arabicde...
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 269 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



instead of re-installing windows, I suggest that you log in safe mode and do a system restore to a date when you laptop was functioning normally.



if you don't know how to do a system restore, follow these steps:



1.	Click Start, point to All Programs, point to Accessories, point to System Tools, and then click System Restore. System Restore starts.
2.	On the Welcome to System Restore page, click Restore my computer to an earlier time (if it is not already selected), and then click Next.
3.	On the Select a Restore Point page, click the most recent system checkpoint in the On this list, click a restore point list, and then click Next. A System Restore message may appear that lists configuration changes that System Restore will make. Click OK.
4.	On the Confirm Restore Point Selection page, click Next. System Restore restores the previous Windows XP configuration, and then restarts the computer.
5.	Log on to the computer as Administrator. The System Restore Restoration Complete page appears.
6.	Click OK.



Source(s):



moi & Microsoft knowledge base :)



</answer>

melissa v

</question from>



<question>



I dropped my mac book like five inches. it wont start the os. what should i do?



SO IT ONLY BOOTS UP TO THE GREY screen with the apple in the middle and does nothing else. it is an older mac. its the panther os. i dont know what else to say that might be able to help. i rather try and do it myself, like if its the hard drive. i dont know, i miss my computer though.



</question>



<answer from>



Kevin M
Member since: 28 February 2008
Total points: 5907 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Is it a macBook, iBook or Powerbook? The reason I ask is that even the oldest MacBooks shipped with Tiger installed, Panther stopped shipping with the G4's. It's important because the iBooks (and older Powerbooks) didn't have sudden motion sensors that parked the hard drive heads when they sense a drop. Without these sensors the hard drive could have been accessing when it fell, making it possible for the read heads to smack into the platters, damaging the surface. This may not be repairable, but in a drop it's more likely to be physical damage than a problem with the os. Best advice is to try the startup disk first to see if disk utility can isolate the damaged sectors. If not you'll need to take it to a recovery expert.



Sorry it's not better news



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>

<question>



How can i remove computrace/lojack entirely from a laptop without it coming back?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



OK, do you see how this is not a question to be asking?



The #1 reason to ask this question is if the Asker is in possession of a stolen laptop.



The rightful owner of the laptop wouldn't have to ask the question, because they could just contact the company (LoJack or CompuTrace) and get help removing the software - for example if they were preparing to sell the machine.



</answer>

<answer>



If you have accumulated a lot of photos in a short time, take my advice and delete the ones that are no good. If you cant back up to disc, get yourself a card reader and store your pictures on the same format of card that your camera uses.  You can take both cards and flash drives into many superstore or photo outlets and print your snaps from a machine.

Jamie Smith

<answer>



Someone above my answer mentioned getting an External Hard Disk Drive (EHDD) - DON'T! The reason for this is a EHDD is fairly expensive and big to backup photos. Even though there will be high Quality photos (which take up more space) a memory stick will be able to backup ever thing up and they are cheaper than EHDD's. If you have 1000's and 1000's and 1000's of high Quality photos you should consider a 4GB memory stick, but just for Future use I would get an 8GB.



</answer>

</answer from>



<answer>



the last answer is excellent - make at least two backups - one to cd or dvd - the other to a flash or external drive - you could also backup online - windows live skydrive offers 5gb free -
http://skydrive.live.com/
this 8gb flash drive is very cheap with free delivery
http://www.amazon.co.uk/Freecom-Databar-...



just plug it into a usb slot and windows will load all the necessary drivers automatically; it will be ready to use in seconds.



</answer>

<answer from>



hamforfe...
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 105 (Level 1)

<answer>



Depends on ALOT. My main bet is drivers.



If you goto your control panel, and then get up the advanced volume control (the one with all the different dials instead of just one) that may all be greyed out and uneditable. If so, that means you have no drivers installed for it.



To find drivers for whatever you have, you need your initial disk that came with your machine, or the disk that came with your soundcard if you bought a new sound card.

<question>



Linking my laptop to tv?



I have bought this cable http://cgi.ebay.co.uk/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?V...
When i connect the cable to my laptop and tv i am getting the sound fine but no picture. When i click properties on my desktop and go to catalyst control centre it shows a box to tick that says force tv detection, i've checked the box and tried it but still no picture. I have a toshiba satellite pro A210 and a Lg 32LC56. Please help me lol.



</question>



<additional details>



I have now got it linked to my tv but it is black and white any ideas why this is? and what can i do to change it?



</additional details>



<answer from>



Migs
Member since: 07 June 2007
Total points: 1206 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Desktops



</answer from>



<answer>



First off, you want to make all connections between your notebook and TV prior to booting your notebook. Once you've done this, you need to change the output destination from your LCD screen, to the source that is interfacing with your television. Often times this can be accomplished by using the "Fn" key + "CRT/LCD/SVIDEO" key. On my notebook (Dell), it appears on the F8 key. However, this may differ on your notebook. More than likely it is also on your F - Keys..



Good Luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



omodiagb...
Member since: 30 December 2006
Total points: 4615 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi go to display settings and make the right changes. Right-click on an empty space on your desktop&gt;personalize and try extending or activating the second monitor,



</answer>



<answer from>



Mc
Member since: 22 January 2008
Total points: 4447 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



What might have happened is that you've "extended" you windows picture onto the Television, so right click Desktop go to "properties"
then across to "Settings"



you will see a picture of two squares, the one on your left being your laptop the one on the right being your television click the one on the right (number 2) and then underneath uncheck "Extend my windows desktop onto this monitor"



click OK



Good luck



Source(s):



I can't access the ebay page to have a look at that cable and im not sure where your plugging it into on your television, but sometimes with my television I get "Source FRONT: CVBS" and "Source FRONT: S-Video" and it will only work on one not the other, Have you tried switching through functions on your television to make sure there is no other?



</answer>

<original file>3242.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk78204.txt</current file name>




<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



crissysm...
Member since: 26 July 2007
Total points: 92 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Why were computers so exspensve back in the 80's back then you had to pay upwords of 7,000$ now there cheap ?



why are they cheaper now and why were they so exspensive back then



</question>



<answer from>



gijoe170...
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 183 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



From one who started up in the era before the Sinclair ZX80 I can explain a better reason why.



There were many, many, and yes, many manufacturers of computer systems in the 60s through the mid 90s.  The boom did not get off to much of a start until the early 1970s.  Most of these early systems used their own versions of operating systems to work.  Everyone did not use MS-DOS.  There was a plethora of programming languages and a lot of early computers just had a keyboard and a few led based displays (kit computers like the first Apple didn't even have a chassis, only a bare board) This is in fact where Bill Gates got rich.  He would be commissioned to take some one's computer that they wanted to market (every one was marketing computers back then, even Exxon), and he would write the code to execute BASIC, one of the most popular instructive procedural languages, on that machine.  Later on we would call this process porting.



He did this on many machines to include the Commodore line and Apple lines.  If you don't believe me, search for the Microsoft easter egg that Bill Gates integrated in all his ports.



Data storage's expense has changed due to better and newer technologies.  The first hard drives built in the fashion we know of today were the size of brief cases, hold about 10 megabytes and dim the lights of the house when it spun up.



Competition has brought down the price. How many Intel capable motherboard manufacturers are there?  How many memory chip makers? The list goes on.



But the main reason why computers have dropped in price is standardization.  All Intel based computers can operate using the most popular OS today: Windows.



A good resource is http://www.old-computers.com/news/defaul...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks for the info



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



ImrJohnn...
Member since: 11 October 2008
Total points: 122 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



AHB is right. It's supply and demand and modern production techniques.



Computer technology was brand new. Not many people had the knowledge and skills to design a computer and there weren't really any specialized companies that made specific components, aside from CPUs.



Now, everything keeps getting smaller and faster and easier to make. It's expensive at first, then is quickly made obsolete and drops in price when something better is made.



Let's say you build a powerful system using new parts right now, and you spend $5000. A year from now you could probably build the same thing for $2000. A year after that and Dell is selling systems just like it for $800.



Mid range computers are cheap now, but I could spec you a $10,000 system with very little trouble, and without the latest and greatest technology.



</answer>



<answer from>



AHB
Member since: 13 November 2006
Total points: 390 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



They were not mass produced back then so the price was high. Nowadays its in huge numbers since it has a lot of customers. This age is computer age and people can't live without one meaning that a lot of computers are being made and sold.



Demand, mass production to meet the demand and competition between Companies makes the prices cheaper.



Another thing which I will put it simple for you to understand is that computer parts are made of tiny chips and those chips are becoming tiny and tiny these days, making the components less expensive to produce among other advantages.



Plus all the advances in Technology also play its part.



</answer>

</question from>



<question>



RAM for Dell 5150 can I mix?



I have a dell 5150 and it came with the following
1GB Dual channel DDR SDRAM at 533MHz (2 x 512M).



I want to order 2 sticks of 1GB DRAM DDR ll SDRAM 533MHz (PC2-4200)



Now giving me 3GB RAM.



What is the difference between DDR and DDR ll? Will all the memory be recognized?



Thanks



</question>



<additional details>



Forgot to mention can I mix the 2 X 512M memory sticks with the two 1GB sticks



</additional details>



<answer from>



Mr Stalkington
Member since: 09 August 2008
Total points: 1300 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Nope, U can't mix DDR & DDRII. Furthermore U can't use DDRII on a computer designed for DDR and vice-versa.



You can mix 512MB sticks with 1GB sticks as long as they are both DDR, for computers designed for DDR, or DDRII for computers designed for DDRII.



</answer>



<answer from>



Kamil B
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 499 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You need to find out first how many sticks you can put in your laptop. It might be only 2 slots at all with one available. Looks like you have 2 slots used already so you will actually have to replace them. It's always best to install same amount of memory sticks so if the dual channel is available it will work with it. For ex. if you have dual channel with two slots you will have to use 2 x 2 gb ram in order to make it dual.



Oh by the way, your computer has DDR2 already so it will be the same ram. DDR2 is faster tho



</answer>



<answer from>



Adnan Sallam
Member since: 30 January 2008
Total points: 7439 (Level 5)

<answer from>



Hamm007
Member since: 01 April 2006
Total points: 137 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Seems as if this is a very common problem with no solution offered up by Microsoft (possible compatibility issues with SP2 and ATI) or ATI themselves.



The two most "common" solutions are to reinstall the ATI driver or, "Go to System Devices in My Computer &gt; Properties &gt; Hardware, and locate the option, PCI standard PCI-to-PCI bridge.  Right click, and select the “update driver” option. Manually search and install the PCI standard PCI-to-PCI bridge."



Hope this helps.



Source(s):



http://www.modernstreet.com/general/ati2...



</answer>



<answer from>



brianthe...
Member since: 28 April 2006
Total points: 27020 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Add-ons



Desktops



</answer from>



<answer>



hi bubble



the message "ati2dvag" indicates a bug that affects ati graphic cards and it causes a blue screen of death and in some cases a infinite loop error message



the usual symptoms of this problem include :
1) PC crashes without warning, sometimes the display shows weird patterns before the crash.



2)Resolution may revert to the lowest resolution settings upon restarting your PC.



3)The CPU temperature may shoot up prior to crashing.



4)PC may not be able to reboot back after the crash, unless you turn off the power supply unit of your PC and switch it back on again.



5)Your PC tells you (sometimes only) that the ati2dvag driver has failed to function.



do not worry about this problem as it happens to many thousands of p.c,s worldwide,and theres been many suggestions put forward why it happens including sp2(service pack 2) incompatibility,and hardware acceleration settings



as for solutions the two most common are :
1) Reinstall the ATI driver. You are advised to launch Windows in Safe Mode (press F8 before Windows boots), go to Windows Add/Remove programs and uninstall everything ATI. Remove the DAO/MDAC component as well. You can use the ATI removal tool utility which can be downloaded from the ATI website. The complete set of instructions on removing ATI can be found here on the ATI website.



2) Go to System Devices in My Computer &gt; Properties &gt; Hardware, and locate the option, PCI standard PCI-to-PCI bridge. This could under other names on your PC, so contact your PC vendor if you’re unsure. Right click, and select the “update driver” option. Manually search and install the PCI standard PCI-to-PCI bridge.



the annoying aspect about this problem is that neither ati or microsoft have released statements in regards to this problem and this is one of the reasons i steer clear of ati cards,their compatibility with both windows xp and vista is suspect to say the least



anyway give these a go and let me know if you have any problems



good luck bubble  !



</answer>



<answer from>



Matt, From Northern Ireland
Member since: 09 September 2007
Total points: 6857 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

<answer>



Hello well this appears to be your graphics card driver.



If you are using an USB keyboard and mouse you need to change these to a normal PS2 mouse/keyboard.The purple and green port type.



Then restart and go into last known good config or safe mode you need to uninstall the ATI graphics card driver and reinstall a new one via there website support page.



You can uninstall the driver via device manager.



I hope this helps?



JB.

<question from>



luna6887

<question>



Why does my laptop battery die so fast?



i have an HP Pavilion DV6933CL and the battery has been dying very fast these last two days! what's going on?



</question>



<answer from>



oni-kun 卍
Member since: 27 July 2008
Total points: 11635 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Programming & Design



</answer from>



<answer>



Don't run any processor intensive programs. Anyway use it until it completely runs out, then when your laptop shuts off unplug it, then take out the battery ( should be easy with a little latch etc. ). Then leave it out for a few hours and place it back in, then fully charge the battery WITHOUT turning the computer back on, by plugging the AC in when the battery is snapped back in place.



This'll reset the processor basically, since you would be charging it when it's not completely empty etc.



Should work.



</answer>



<answer from>



e.x123
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yeah same thing happens to mine also but then i found out that it was the contrast if u lower the back light it should resist more and probably will not die as fast but if its not that then it´s probably your battery came out wrong and you´re going to have to change it or sometimes is because you are doing a lot of things at the same time that takes energy away from the battery well hope this helps



</answer>



<answer from>



kierannu...
Member since: 26 August 2008
Total points: 436 (Level 2)

<answer>



First you have to know what you intend to do with it. Desktops are cheaper than laptops for the same capabilities but if you must be mobile, then you need a laptop.



You should get at least 1 gb of ram and 2 gb is better. Get a dual core processor for best performance. Intel is rated higher than AMD.



Get at least a 200 gb hard drive.



This article discusses all the details of what you need to consider when buying a computer http://www.ask-the-computer-doc.com/buy-...



Source(s):



http://www.ask-the-computer-doc.com/buy-...



</answer>

<answer>



It is s matter of preference (laptop vs desktop)...
Required spec depends on what you will be using it for:
home computer to do your homework 2GB+ RAM, 100GB+ HDD, any processor will be sufficient...
gaming computers need more RAM and better video card...
2GHz+ processor, 2GB RAM, 100GB HDD are fairly standard these days
The above configuration will suite most purposes...



</answer>



<answer from>



Kyle
Member since: 14 May 2008
Total points: 116 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends what you want to get out of your machine. If it's going to be used for gaming, you're going to want a good graphics card and CPU. If you're using it primarily for emails, youtube videos, casual internet browsing, then you'll want to focus on RAM. Maybe you're an artist, and like playing in photoshop. If that's the case, you want good RAM, a good CPU, decent graphics card.



Next, on to the Operating System. I would suggest Windows XP Pro, but most computers come standard with Vista. The unfortunate thing about Vista is it hemorrhages RAM. With Vista, you want atleast a good 2GB+ of RAM. Great graphics cards cost $100+, but are completely optional if you're willing to accept onboard video cards which generally aren't.... all that great. Most good hard drives have 200+ GB.



</answer>

<question>



Computer graphics problem?



My laptop has recently been having some troubles. While on my desktop or in mozilla firefox it is working fine, when a more graphical intense display comes on it will freeze. Example : Aurora Borealis screensaver in Vista. It doesnt do this all the time but when it does it is a real hassel. I shut it down and try to start it up and what comes to the screen is a gray and black display with strange patterns.



http://farm3.static.flickr.com/2012/1975...



Looks kinda like that. But with less white



I then try to restart it again and the same thing comes up.
Does anyone know what is going on or how to fix it and how much it would cost?



</question>



<additional details>



No I cannot update drivers, because It does that from startup automatically, no way to stop it (tried f8) and I cant leave that screen. Also for the second post, I have had vista running on my machine for about 2 months and this problem just happened today. Happened in World of Warcraft today and I have ran that on my computer for 2 years.



</additional details>



<answer from>



ronallan
Member since: 18 September 2007
Total points: 460 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Can you enter the BIOS?



If you can't enter safe mode anymore or otherwise boot to change/update the drivers, can you reinstall Windows?



What GPU does your laptop have? If it's a GPU made by Nvidia, you may have a defective GPU.



http://www.techcrunchit.com/2008/07/10/n...



Nvidia has claimed that only 8400M and 8600M GPUs are affected, but there are reports that the defect extends to 7, 6, and even 9 series mobile GPUs.



Your laptop's problem seems to be hardware based. If so, regardless of whether the GPU was made by Nvidia or any other company, considering that most mobile GPUs are integrated onto the laptop's motherboard, or worse, into the chipset itself, it may be impractical to have it serviced if your laptop isn't covered by a warranty anymore since the only quick fix is to replace the motherboard.



If it's that far gone, you may be better off buying a new one.



Hope you get it working again though.



</answer>

<answer from>



AJ
Member since: 01 May 2007
Total points: 9925 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Software

<answer>



If this is XP then right click on a blank area of the desktop, choose properties, then settings and then move the screen resolution to the right and click apply. Keep going till you are happy with the result.



If you are using Vista right click on the desktop and select personalise and then display settings and adjust the slider as with XP



AJ



</answer>



<answer from>



Jack
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 144 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



On the desktop (the big picture with all your icons on), right click, Select properties.  After that follow according to your operating system.



In Vista, click on display settings and alter your resolution.



In XP, click the settings tab at the top and adjust the screen resolution.



If it is too big, move the slider to the right or select the highest resolution.



Hope I helped - If this does not solve the problem  please e-mail me at jackdrury@blueyonder.co.uk



</answer>

<question>



Get a macbook or wait?



Recently my lap top's battery meter says about 30 minutes on a fully charged battery. I only have 20 GB left on my HD, I only have 1Gb of RAM, it takes my computer three minutes to come back from sleep mode, and I can't stand seeing that stupid windows logo one more time so I am extremely thinking about buy a new Macbook. I use my computer for only the basics like e-mail, school, and web surfing. But my problem is I'm not sure if I should go ahead and buy a macbook with my hard earned money from my summer job or wait until I go to college to buy a new computer. Any suggestions?



</question>



<additional details>



By the way I'm not worried about my programs not working. And my next computer will be a Mac not a PC. It's just a matter of when



</additional details>



<answer from>



Dan H
Member since: 23 October 2008
Total points: 191 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Don't listen to the PC fangirl, the new generation of Macbooks are out and you will have no problem running your basics on a Mac. Everything that you do on your current laptop can be done on a macbook. Here are some examples.



Internet: Firefox or Safari (Firefox is better if you like lots of addons, otherwise Safari is really easy to use.)



AIM: iChat (also does bonjour, jabber, and Gtalk)



Yahoo Messenger: Yahoo! Messenger for mac (It's the same.)



Email: Mail.app (If you switch and use Gmail or pay for Yahoo's Plus you can pop it right into your inbox. Otherwise just like normal thru a web browser.) or Mozilla Thunderbird. (Found at mozilla.org)



Microsoft Office (Word, Excel, Powerpoint): I'd reccomend to anyone on Mac, PC, or Linux to just download the OpenOffice.Org suite in a heartbeat over office (it supports the same file types.) But if you feel like shelling out cash for microsoft office then there is a version for mac at your disposal.



Windows programs (for the PC fankids.): There are a few options.
1. Anything involved in the WINE project. (WINE lets you download the dll's the programs need and the fonts to run them. WITHOUT INSTALLING WINDOWS.) This includes:
1a.Darwine (free)
1b.Crossover for Mac (little pricy, but offers more support)
1c.Crossover Games (a little cheaper, but is only for games.)
2. Virtualization software. (So installing windows in a safe virtual machine to run on top of os x) This includes:
2a.VirtualBox (free)
2b.VMWare Fusion (Pricey)
2c.Parallels Desktop (More pricey)
3. Dual-Booting (Use apple's built in program Boot Camp to boot into windows natively)



So as you can see, you'll likely enjoy your new Macbook, as ANY computer would top the one you have.



Source(s):



Mozilla.org
messenger.yahoo.com/mac/
OpenOffice.org
darwine.sourceforge.net/
www.codeweavers.com/products/cxmac/
www.codeweavers.com/products/cxgames
www.virtualbox.org/
www.vmware.com/products/fusion/
www.parallels.com/products/desktop/
www.apple.com/macosx/features/bootcamp...



</answer>

<question>



How does a laptop power cable work?



Physically, I want to know what the cable looks like around the part that plugs into the laptop. I have a kink in the cable around that point, but don't know if cutting it and soldering is an option, depending on how complicated that part of the cable is. The rest of the cable is really simple (positive and negative) but does it get complex at the end?



Note: I'm only talking about the cable, not the laptop jack itself. I'm talking about the end farthest away from the brick, that plugs into the laptop. I wanna know what that looks like, and how easy it would be to repair.



</question>



<additional details>



You guys are great, let me clarify a little more. The problem is clearly in the cable, right before the end. It's not the end itself that I would be replacing. I'd just be soldering the part right before the end piece. So should it be any different than soldering any other part of the cable?



</additional details>



<answer from>



DJ Pazze
Member since: 14 March 2008
Total points: 8594 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I have an HP and it looks like any other cable(ac adapters)  it has a hole where it connets to the laptop.



it is not complicated, it just haas the negative and positive cables.  Headphones' cables are complicated, charger cables are not.



Take a look at this picture, I am guessing you are trying to replace the damaged connector.  http://www.1powershop.com/images/product...



If that is what you are trying to do,. just make sure you get one of the same size.  =]



EDIT: hour:32 minutes:



OK!!!  Then there should be no problem.  Just cut the cable and solder it again.



ie.



lets say this is the cable:



"END__DAMAGE HERE_____Start"  Cut whre its damaged and solder it.



You shold get somethng ike this&gt;&gt;:



"END___________Start"



=]

</category>



<question from>



☆Rock☆
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 242 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Once you've permantly deleted something where does it all go...?



I was wandering because for example lets say we deleted something and went to the recycle bin then from there we 'permantly deleted it where does it go how does the computer remove and and do any traces remain btw for vista?



</question>



<answer from>



Brad E
Member since: 04 November 2007
Total points: 164 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



When you write on a hard drive for the first time, you're writing on a clean surface. However, things stay on it when you delete them, but permission to write over the item is given.



If you delete a picture, it stays on the hard drive, but next time something needs to me written, it might write on top of the picture, deleting it forever.



Just because you deleted something doesn't mean it is gone forever. It is still on the hard drive until something else writes over top of it.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks all the answers were good thanks a lot ...



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Tattoo Ted
Member since: 03 January 2007
Total points: 4423 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



All the recycle bin is is a special folder where the "deleted" items go - they're not deleted at that point.



When they're "permanently" deleted, the computer simply deletes the record of where it is on the hard drive so even though it has been deleted the actual data can still be there for some time.



You can get special software called disk cleaners which "clean" the empty areas of your hard drive by writing the same character over and over again "rubbing out" the previous data.



</answer>



<answer from>



Rodolfo R
Member since: 21 May 2008
Total points: 1331 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



when you 'delete' a file, it is not deleted, it just goes to the recycle bin. The file doesn't change a bit, just the location. When you permanently delete it from the bin, the file remains but its space is 'available' and the directory entry is deleted (not the file's content, just the entry that tells the computer where the file is).  So basically, whenever your computer needs space for anything, it considers the space where the file is located as usable.



If you need to get that file, the longer the time has passed since you permanently deleted it, the higher the chances that the OS used the space for something.  There are applications that scan the 'available areas' of the disc for content that can help you recover the file (or at least part of it).



If, on the other hand, you want to make sure the file is totally gone, there are applications that add a 'shredder' to the bin, so they overwrite the content of the file with 0s and then delete the file.  Someone suggested defragging, but this does not guarantee the file content will be erased.



</answer>



<answer from>



edward w
Member since: 10 May 2006
Total points: 3864 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



No it doesn't delete it permanently,the Windows delete function does not clear the space where the deleted file has been located but only marks an entry in the directory (folder) as deleted. All data and information about the file still remains on the disk and can be restored!
now there is a program that i use all the time to make sure my deleted files r deleted for good and it will not mess with any of your good files,it will only erase the empty space and since you deleted files and the computer sees the space as empty it will erase that empty space too on your hard drive.the link to it is below,give it a try.need more help email me.



Source(s):



http://www.cezeo.com/products/disk-redac...



</answer>

Andrew B

</answer from>



<answer>



The correct answer is that it stays exactly where it was, but the reference to it in the file allocation table is removed.



Until it gets overwritten



</answer>



<answer from>

<question>



I have a problem with my laptop battery charger.?



Hi



I bought an acer laptop the last year Aspire 5520 G, the charger of the battery was caming with it; after 6 months, the charger stopped working, so i bought another, and again after 4 months it stopped working again so I bought a third one and yesterday after 2months it stopped working again. Please help me to find a solution, or if it's a problem with my computer. I asked Jumbo, in Dubai (UAE) because there is from where i bought it and they told me that maybe is because i let it on when the laptop is off, so i started to remove it from the light when it's off, and again the 2 chargers stopped working...



Regards



</question>



<additional details>



And like one week before, it started shining the place to turn on the computer, and normally it's green but when it used to shine it was orange...



</additional details>



<answer from>



Darkest Star
Member since: 18 April 2008
Total points: 932 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I have never had this problem but then I have never had an Acer Aspire laptop, my partner did and it lasted 3 months before it failed critically and blew its own processor which I remember was an AMD one rather than the far superior Intel.  I would say that if you use your Acer for long periods of time and leave it plugged in while away from it then this probably the matter.  I think that most laptops do not enjoy this sort of treatment as they are designed to be on when used and off when not as that is their purpose.  Acer seem to have problems with building a decent mid or low end laptop at the best of times because of their high number of battery and processor problems.  Their high end laptops and desktop replacements seem to have fewer problems which is probably because they cost so much more.  I would look in to having the charger connection port looked at or even the whole powerpack as it seems to be a problem with these burning out, you could also plug your laptop in to a circuit breaker to prevent problems from power surges in your area.  I have mine plugged into a circuit breaker and the whole of this section of the house is on its own circuit breaker so that it gets isolated thus causing minimal damage to electronic devices in other parts of the house.  The whole house is also on a central circuit breaker so that if their is a power failure or a power surge the whole house is protected.  Try and get this sort of system set up in your house to protect all of your digital equipment.



Source(s):



Experience.



</answer>

Thankss



</asker's comment>

<current file name>yqa_uk81120.txt</current file name>




<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



mave
Member since: 18 January 2006
Total points: 370 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Should I get a PC or laptop?



I will be getting a computer at the end of this year.My dad wants me to get a PC, but I really want a laptop.A laptop has much greater mobility and there are more choices.So I really need your help and opinions.Is the PC or laptop better?It would be even better if you recommend me some brands/models.Thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



Eric
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 123 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Here's desktop vs laptop.
Desktop:
Desktop can be upgraded a lot more than a laptop.
Desktop can have a faster processor.
Desktop can have a better graphics card.
Desktop can have a better sound card.
Desktops can have faster memory.
Desktops run cooler usually. Giving you more life out of it.



Laptop:
Can be taken around with you.
Smaller.
Weighs less.
Great for school/office.



Also, there are not more choices for laptops. I say this because I build desktops. If you build it yourself or have someone do it for you, your options are unlimited. Plus I could build a desktop with the same specs as a laptop for less than half the price of the laptop.



All comes down to what you need. Do you really need the mobility?



Source(s):



Building and upgrading PCs and laptops for 10 years.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Hey thanks so much for listing down the pros and cons.So it actually justs boils down to cost and mobility=)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Dark Knight
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 191 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Depends on your situation:



Portability is a quality of a laptop, but if you don't have wifi it's not that good.



PCs are not portable but they are very very customizable and easier to fix.



Also if your PC dies, then you get to keep the screen and PCs can be amped up due to more room while laptops are limited in memory and RAM. ;)



I recommend Dell or HP. Both are strong competitors and offer the best choices in both laptops and PCs for the price.



</answer>



<answer from>



amrobich...
Member since: 22 June 2007
Total points: 4527 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have both desktop and laptop. I enjoy my desktop more because it give me more pleasure of sitting behind my computer desk. I can lay back in my chair and rest a bit while surfing or doing something on it.



Desktops are better than laptops performance wise, they can also be upgraded easily and at a better cost than laptops. Repair cost for laptops are very high compared to desktops. Upgrading a laptop can be extremely costly and often requires qualified repair techs and not from any average next door Pc nerd .



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Will there be a big difference between 6mb or 1mb L2 cache?



Will there be a big difference between 6mb or 1mb L2 cache? I'm thinking of builind a pc and am considering 2 different processors. <question from>



CobMan15...
Member since: 03 December 2006
Total points: 384 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



MacBook Pro graphics (gaming) capability?



I am thinking about buying a 15" MacBook Pro and I'd like to know how capable it is for gaming. It has 256MB of integrated graphics and 512MB of dedicated graphics that can be used in conjunction (I think). This would mean it could potentially have 768MB of video RAM... How well would this MacBook be at running high-end games such as Call of Duty 4? By the way, does OS X Leopard have, or support DirectX 10? And yes, I will be installing Windows STRICTLY for gaming because 90% of computer games are for Windows... Any computer gaming gurus please advise. Thanx! MacBook Pro link--&gt; http://store.apple.com/us/browse/home/sh...



</question>



<additional details>



oni-kun.............I said "I will be installing Windows to run games".... Apparently your reading comprehension is terrible.



Dark Knight, look at this, dummy... http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mP0Wd6Dde...



</additional details>



<answer from>



Kevin M
Member since: 28 February 2008
Total points: 5897 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Why do Windows users automatically jump on anything that puts Mac and Gaming in the same question? I've been gaming on Macs for years and with intel cpu's and bootcamp I can play both Mac and Windows games, in many cases faster than comparable Windows machines!



On paper the numbers look great, it doesn't quite work out to equivalent to 768MB of onboard, as shared RAM is never quite as fast, but assume &lt;roughly&gt; equivalent to 714MB or so of onboard (still pretty sweet though). Also the shared is only used by the secondary graphics processor (mmm, dual graphics processors...)



I also know that the MBPro runs Vista faster than most other laptops (I can feel a thumbs down or two coming for that comment) which implies faster gameplay too. I can't give a good answer on COD4 (I'm more into RTS so I haven't tried it) but the potential is there. COD4 is available for Leopard and even the slowest MBPro surpasses all the recommended system requirements (and the Mac version uses openGL, although you likely knew this already), what this translates to in actual gameplay I can't say without having tried it.



OS X doesn't support directx (directx is win specific, and directx 10 Vista only) but if you're installing Vista anyway it's support will make Leopard supporting it irrelevant.



Bottom line is the MBPro is a great portable gaming platform but I doubt you'll find someone on YA that's tried high end gaming on one. One option is to head over to Best Buy and ask the Mac expert to demo it (it's a $2600+ laptop, they might risk it to make the sale)



Sorry that doesn't totally answer your question but I hope it's at least helpful.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Very good answer-thank you. I'm sure this MBP will kick butt on any game. Dark Knight and that skin head don't know what they're talking about. Thanx again!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



oni-kun 卍
Member since: 27 July 2008
Total points: 11416 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Programming & Design



</answer from>

HAHAHAHHA. No DX10 only openGL.



( sorry but everyone says they're better so I am autobias and correct. )

<question>



What is the best hard drive brand?



I think my laptop's hard drive might be dieing so I've been looking at new hard drives to get in case it does. What is the best brand to get?



</question>



<additional details>



The current brand in my laptop is Seagate...but looking at Seagate hard drives alot of the comments seem to be negative....people are saying they don't last very long, and I believe them, since my own is crapping out after a year =|



</additional details>



<answer from>



TBag
Member since: 17 March 2007
Total points: 291 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I have had good luck with Western Digital.  They honor their warranty which is always a good thing.  I've had a couple of WD drives for a few years now and they have been reliable.  Maxtor is a solid brand too.



A few tips... If you're using XP, run the disk clean up utility and disk defragment utility.  That might clean up some clutter.  Before buying a new hard drive, I would suggest reinstalling your operating system.  A fresh install can do wonders for a drive that feels clunky.  New PC's come with tons of extra junk you don't need and a new OS install can help.  Stay away from registry edit programs.  Not the best value IMO.



Good luck, Your Highness...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks alot everyone :)



I think I'll go with Western Digital.



I did reformat my HD and reinstalled XP, and its running well so far except for 1 random blue screen so....huge improvement. So, I guess I'll just have to see.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Mustang Tom
Member since: 03 January 2007
Total points: 691 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have used a number of Western Digital over the years, found them very reliable. I usually change computers every 7 years, never had one die on me.



Seagate was one of original makers of hard drives, but their reliability had slipped a few years back. But they may have improved over the years.



Are you sure you don't just need to have it cleaned up good and defraged. This could could help it run better.



It goes places it shouldn't or has a mind of it's own, it may have viruses in it. Easily picked up off the web. You then will need a good virus scanner.



Good Luck!

Experience

<answer>



You will probably find only a few brands to choose from:



Fujitsu
Hitachi
Samsung



They are all pretty much the same.



Concentrate on cache size, (bigger is better), access times - (smaller is better), and drive capacity - oh and price.



I don't think there is a clear market leader. Not significantly anyway.



</answer>

<question>

The reason I want to bring it back is, because the charger outlet is broken it works sometimes. But I have a feeling it's going to stop working all together. <answer from>



Lindsay G
Member since: 14 June 2006
Total points: 48097 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Software



Laptops & Notebooks



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



If it falls under the return policy yes, otherwise the only thing you can do is take it in to repair the charger. In the future it would be wise to research laptop, before you buy them.



UPDATE: to added details.



Since the return is only 15 days, Walmart will not take it back, also for repairs you will have to contact Toshibia. Which the charger should be covered under the warranty.



I know hp has a thing where you can trade in your laptop for another one, so maybe toshibia has that too, but you probably still would have to pay some money towards it.



</answer>

<answer>



I'd say go with the HP.
It has more speed, better graphics, big HDD capacity, and in terms of experience, very good. I own an HP myself and it's been my best laptop yet.



Don't forget, with the HP up there, you can also add on a built-in Verizon EV-DO card, so you can have Internet access anywhere that there's cell phone service. I own one of those, too, and I love it as well. It's just as fast as DSL, and well worth the money.

<answer from>



Brian C
Member since: 15 March 2008
Total points: 285 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I've worked in retail for quite a few years now and our place sells alot of laptops, we have sold Acer in the past, but stopped due to reliability issues, Dell, i can't really talk from experience, but most people who get them seem pretty happy with them, we currently sell HP, Toshiba and Fujitsu-Siemens, i hope to god we stop selling Fujitsu-Siemens they are terribly unreliable, must get about 1 in 30 back as faulty, HP used to be good but seem to be loosing some of their build quality maybe 1 in 50-60 comes back, and Toshiba, well we've sold more than 400 and only had 1 back (that wasn't user error), which speaks volumes.



Anyway, of the list you have there i'd have to go with the "Toshiba u400 Core Duo 1.8"  these little 13" laptops are great, they're powerful and yet due to the small screen size they have pretty impressive battery lifes too



And for all the "MAC RULES" coments, well, the Mac OS is very stable, and has it's uses (mainly business), but if you want to be able to walk into a shop and buy a printer without having to ask if it's Mac compatible, then Mac isn't for you, if you want to be able to buy a game without having to check it works with Mac, then Mac isn't for you, or buy a webcam... the list is endless, and frankly it's a pain in the ***...



however, if you're only going to use it for checking e-mails, listening to music, viewing photos, and doing school/work stuff on it then it might be worth thinking about, but you will have to part with alot of money for such a fashion item...



Oh, and for the ill informed, Intel has been beating everything AMD has to offer for a few years now, the Core 2 Duo blows the AMD processors out of the water, especialy when it comes to games and media
The ranking of processors goes like this (worst performance first)
Intel Celeron
AMD Sempron
Intel Pentium
AMD Athlon
AMD Turion (laptops only, energy efficient chipset and components, paired with an AMD Athlon, for better battery life)
AMD Athlon 64
Intel Centrino Duo (Laptops only, energy efficient chipset and components paired with a Core 2 Duo, for better battery life)
Intel Core 2 Duo



The only test an AMD processor will beat an Intel chip in (the same class) is energy efficiency (by which i mean an AMD Athlon 64 Vs Core 2 Duo, or Centrino Duo Vs AMD Turion)



Source(s):



Been building computers for years now, my current rig is an Intel Core 2 Quad 2.4 Ghz overclocked to 3.6 Ghz, 4GB RAM and 2 X 8800 GTX in SLI, trust me i know my hardware...



</answer>



<answer from>



Ryan S
Member since: 01 October 2008
Total points: 39 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



acer aspire they are brilliant!!!

<answer from>



JustMe
Member since: 19 March 2007
Total points: 251 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The disk is in your drive.



It sounds like the DVD drive opens & closes so there is no need for the paperclip method.



Try this:
open the drive, carefully turn the computer upside down, close the drive, turn in right side up, open the drive & it should be there.



If that doesn't work. unplug the computer, open your computer case, remove the DVD drive from the case, unscrew the drive, carefully open the drive (this will most likely void the warranty by the way), remove the disk & carefully put it all back together.



Source(s):



working on computers for years..



</answer>

<question>



Any precautions for re-soldering power-jack on loptop mobo?



Hi,



My Dell Inspiron laptop’s power jack on the motherboard came out loose so I’m re-soldering it to the motherboard. Is there any precautions before I proceed? I just don’t want to damage any chips with excessive  heat from the soldering iron.



</question>



<answer from>



Bomber
Member since: 13 July 2007
Total points: 8741 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



you should take anti static precautions before starting
for the soldering make sure the joint is clean and free from old solder (you can buy solder braid for this is suck up molten solder) then just apply solder and the iron at the same time let it flow don't over do the solder and everything should be fine



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you very much.



</asker's comment>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



Dell Inspiron 1525, Windows Help ?



My mum has bought me a dell inspiron 1525 for christmas and i wasnt supposed to look at it or go on it until then. But i couldnt help myself being stupid and turned the laptop on and set windows up :( is there any way of getting back to the setup so at christmas i can set it up so my mum doesnt know ?
it has windows vista home premium and ive tried system restore



</question>



<additional details>



I was just planning on taking the laptop upstairs at christmas and saying to my mum that i have just set it up, i set the username as guest. she doesnt really know much about computers



I don't know if i want to risk resetting it, i might lose vista?



Should i do the restore ? will i still have vista ? and will it work



</additional details>



<answer from>



Chris P
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 435 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Using Dell Factory Image Restore in Windows Vista



Notice:



Restoring the original factory image erases ALL existing data. This includes files, folders, programs, drivers, E-mails, photos. Before performing a PC Restore, back up all personal files. If you do not back up your personal files, the data will be lost.



1



Turn on the computer.



--------------------------------------...



2



As the computer starts, press &lt;F8&gt; on the keyboard until the Advanced Boot Options menu appears on the screen.



Note:



You must press &lt;F8&gt; before the Windows logo appears on the screen. If you press &lt;F8&gt; after the Windows logo appears on the screen, the Advanced Boot Options menu will not appear on the screen. If you do not see the Advanced Boot Options menu, restart the computer, and then repeat this step until you see the menu on the screen.



--------------------------------------...



3



Press the &lt;Down Arrow&gt; on the keyboard to select Repair Your Computer on the Advanced Boot Options menu, and then press &lt;Enter&gt;.



--------------------------------------...



4



Specify the language settings that you want, and then click Next.



--------------------------------------...



5



Log in as a user who has administrative credentials, and then click OK.



--------------------------------------...



6



Click Dell Factory Image Restore.



--------------------------------------...



7



In the Dell Factory Image Restore window, click Next.



--------------------------------------...



8



Click to select the Yes, reformat hard drive and restore system software to factory condition check box.



--------------------------------------...



9



Click Next.



The computer is restored to the default factory configuration.



--------------------------------------...



10



When the restore operation is completed, click Finish to restart the computer.



The software is now installed as it was when the computer was first received.



Source(s):



http://support.dell.com/support/topics/g...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I'll try this :)
Thank you x



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Dave
Member since: 27 September 2008
Total points: 719 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Dell laptops come with a restore partition to restore it to factory condition. When you see the dell splashscreen when you turn it on press Ctrl+F11. This will bring up the restore program. Just follow the intructions and when its complete turn off the computer and leave it till christmas.



</answer>

<answer from>



InCiTe
Member since: 07 February 2007
Total points: 2052 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Click on the start button and in the search box type:



c:\windows\system32\sysprep\sysprep
.exe
(type the above without any spaces and exactly as shown)



A box will appear, under system cleanup action choose "Enter system out of box experience"



And on Shutdown options choose "Shutdown"



This will then reset your laptop as new. Do it once to test so you can make sure it works. Be very careful what instructions you follow on this post as you could damage your computer.



Dont open your christmas present again, its not nice your mum has worked hard for this present. Just wait and appreciate it.



Charli - Use my option, its called sysprep. There is no need to do a system restore this can often miss out drivers therefore giving you away. All my option does is tell the setup to run again on the next boot.



</answer>

<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



firmedc
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 96 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



X-box 360 and Laptop. Can I connect them?



I would like to know if I can connect my laptop to my X-box 360? The laptop is connected to a wireless router. I tried to connect the two by using a ethernet from the X-box to the lap top with a usb. My laptop did not recognize the device. And my X-box did not acknowledge the connection. Microsoft support was not supportive. What a surprise! I have Vista home premium as an operating system. Can anyone help me out?



</question>



<answer from>



cooltd82...
Member since: 18 May 2006
Total points: 3014 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



alright, connect the Xbox 360 to the router with an Ethernet.  then make sure the laptop is connected on the wireless.



after that go to Media Center on your laptop.  go to settings, then "add media extender".  after that go to the "media" thing in your home menu on the 360.  follow the instructions on the computer & 360 and you'll be all set.



</answer>



<answer from>



Chris B
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 503 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can use the media center built into Vista to connect the two for media files, but they both have to be on the same network.



They can be connected by any wired/wireless ethernet combination, as long as you're router can handle the bandwidth.  The Media Center Extender will explain the bandwidth during setup.



Open up windows media center on your laptop while both the 360 and the laptop are on.  Scroll to tasks, then add extender.  At this point you will need to get the 360 into the media center mode, by selecting media, then media center (I believe)  You will eventually be given an 8 digit code from the 360 that you need to type into the laptop.  You then have to setup preferences such as allowing the files to be viewed, etc.



After this it should connect.  You may have to try it twice.  When you get into the media center on the xbox you may not see any files.  You can add media to the media center through either the laptop or the xbox.  Entire folders can be added under Tasks, Settings, Library Setup.



</answer>

<question from>



David M

</question from>



<question>



How do i connect to xbox live using my Vista Based laptop?



I have a laptop using windows vista home premium.



I'm using a 3G Modem that plugs into the USB port on my laptop.



I have an ethernet cable connected from my laptop to my xbox360.

<original file>344.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk82155.txt</current file name>




<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



lacretal...
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 99 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Would it REALLY make a difference to switch from 7200rpm to 5400rpm HDD?



Well you see, for details that are quite complicated and are not really needed for this question, I am only able to buy a laptopthat only comes available with a 5400rpm and not 7200rpm, everything else about the laptop is nearly perfect. However, this 5400rpm makes me hesitate to much on whether to buy it or not.



Please help me in this one problem on what would really make a difference and what choice should I make. Thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



GTB
Member since: 24 May 2007
Total points: 13925 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Computer Networking



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Higher speed equates to faster read / write time.



Whether it makes much difference depends upon what you do.  If you do a lot of storage heavy types of applications it can make a difference.  If you do not do storage heavy application, you will not notice it.



Let's say you do typical e mail messages (mainly text), word processor documents, small spread sheet work, little to no photo editing or graphically intense work - then you will not notice the slower rpm hdd.



Even if you do heavy applications, you will not likely see this as a deal breaker.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you ^_^



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Kamil B
Member since: 06 October 2008
Total points: 393 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



RPM means rounds per minute. With 7200 rpm you get faster reading along with faster writing to your hard drive. And yes there are 7200rpm laptops hard drives. I wouldn't worry about that, the difference is almost unnoticeable, then you can always exchange your hard drive later if you won't be happy with it



</answer>



<answer from>



pboltonc...
Member since: 11 July 2006
Total points: 6656 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



The higher speed HDD has a quicker access time, the choice depends on whether a few milliseconds is important to you or not



</answer>



<answer from>



Hajime A
Member since: 28 June 2008
Total points: 2142 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It doesn't make too much difference. 5400rpm is not bad at all from 7200rpm. A little difference in speed. As for battery usage 5400rpm is advantageous because it consume less power than 7200rpm.



</answer>



<answer from>



Marvin
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 543 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think all laptop drives are 5400 to conserve battery life. It takes a lot more power to run the drive spindle motor at the higher speed.



If not all then almost all. I wouldn't worry about it.



</answer>

</question from>



<question>



How do i find out what type of motherboard my inspiron 1525 laptop has?



this would help solve another issue I'm having



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



you laptop should have a 'service tag' it's just a white sticker with a series of number+letters in it. you can use that to find all the parts that has been put into your laptop from the manufacturer, in this case Dell



1st link below shows helps you find your service tag



2nd link is the place you want to type that tag into and find out about your laptop's original configuration



gl



Source(s):



find tag: http://support.euro.dell.com/support/top...



laptop info: http://support.euro.dell.com/support/top...



</answer>

<answer from>

</answer from>



<answer>

<answer from>



mike H
Member since: 10 August 2008
Total points: 6462 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



could be the hard drive has developed an issue - boot from your windows cd - go to the repair / recovery console options, type LOGON to access the Windows installation, type CHKDSK /R to check for disk errors and repair, might take a while depending on the size of the disk - this will confirm if the hard drive has problems and attempt to repair



Source(s):



http://www.computer-adviser.com/windows-...



</answer>

Random Time
Member since: 19 October 2008
Total points: 819 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Question: Why don't you trust online shops, Dell and HP's online stores are secure, unless you have a virus on your computer, there's nothing for you to loose.



Anyway, again, you can't get future proof, there will always be a new machine that's better, processor speed doubles every 18 months.



It's all what you need, if you need email, word processing and web surfing, a cheaper system would be fine. If you are looking for gaming or video encoding, i'd go higher end. It's your personal choice, and as you don't like to buy online (again, I don't see why you should - a Visa card protects you from unauthorised purchases), go to your local PC world and look around. If you need to buy games you will be spending more, but otherwise go and find your deal.



</answer>

<question>



CPU Question...Anybody Got Some Ideas?



I have a Shuttle G30S2 PLUS w/C2D E6600...and I am thinking of upgrading the CPU. I am most interested in the E8400/8500/8600. Do you think the impreovement in speed is worth the extra dollars over the E6600.



</question>



<additional details>



I have 4Gb of RAM...and the Shuttle I have can handle 45nm chips.



I have a PNY 8800GT in that machine.



I only have 2 slots...and I am running an HTOmega Striker sound card, so an 8800/9800GT is about all that will fit.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Mark N
Member since: 19 February 2007
Total points: 13460 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Add-ons



Desktops



Other - Hardware



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Before buying a CPU you need to contact shuttle about wheather a 45nm processor will be recognized with your motherboard.  Also ask if there is a bios update that will let you upgrade to the 45nm processors.  An e6600 would do well in games if you just had an upgraded graphics card.  That would give you the biggest performance gain per dollar, and like the other guy said, if you have at least 2gigs of ram if not 3 or 4 gigs...  http://us.shuttle.com/Scgsupport/Sys_Sup...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Doesn't really answer my question, but helpful never the less. I would still like to know if the CPU upgrade is worth it...and which one of them would be the logical bang for the buck champ.



</asker's comment>

<question>



Computer Keeps shutting off?



Hi,



No this is not a virus question. I have a sager N2090 laptop with 2.4 ghz intel centrino, 2 gig ram, and an Nvidia Geforce 8600M GT video card.



For some reason I can't play any of the new games on medium settings. I tried mass effect(low settings), Fable lost chapters(medium and this is an old game), and red alert 3(medium) and my computer just shuts off literally.



I meet the requirements for those game and the hardware seems adequate. Any suggestions why this is happening or how i can fix this? Or is my computer really too crappy for those games.



Thanks



</question>



<additional details>



The drivers seemed to be all updated and i ran all of the test from 3dmark06. During on of the tests my laptop shut off again. Does that mean I have to change my power supply?



</additional details>



<answer from>



stillfre...
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 131 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You could have a faulty motherboard if it shuts off, faulty psu, gpu, i would guess psu as it happens quickly, put the laptop under stress and see if it does it still like, try running 3dmark06 and benchmark and see if it crashes, if it does it will prop be psu as the card isn't gettign enough power.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



My pc did shut down during on of the tests from 3dmark06. i'm not sure if it's really the psu but i will take a look at it.



</asker's comment>

</question from>



<question>



I Need help picking a good gaming PC?



i need a new pc pretty much just for gaming and im willing to spend around £800 but im not really sure what is good and what is not. i found one on novatech since that is where my friend got his and was hoping someone could tell me if it is any good...



http://www.novatech.co.uk/novatech/range...



Intel Q9450 Core 2 Quad 1066FSB 12MB Cache Quad Core Core 64 Bit Processor.
2GB DDR2 800MHz Dual Channel Ram
Dual Nvidia 9500GT 512MB PCI-E Graphics Running In SLI Mode.
Creative X-Fi PCI-Express 8-channel audio.
MSI P7N Diamond 780i Chipset Motherboard.



well any help would be appreciated or if you know of a better gaming pc for £800 and could give a link that would be nice to :)



</question>



<answer from>



b
Member since: 20 October 2008
Total points: 701 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



the CPU looks good BUT you should NOT get stuck with (2) 9500 GTs & only 2 gb of RAM because those would be your system bottleneck. Having to settle with 2 9500gt is setting yourself up for a bad investment (in a good gaming PC). I suggest you take out the 2x 9500 and aim for 1x 9800gt or gtx (if you are on budget) at least you can always upgrade it later for SLI. Also 2 more gb of RAM is not expensive at all. If you can choose make sure you KNOW for sure your PSU will support SLI so you wont have to buy a new one later.



9500gt is not 'good gaming' it's actually 'very average gaming' and for the sake of future proof and expandability, get 1 single good card instead of trying to get SLI with 2 average cards.



If you ever changed you mind about nvidia there's always the ATi graphic option open for the Intel x38, x48, or p45 chipset mobo with ATi 4850 (very affordable and VERY GOOD IN CROSSFIRE X) or 4870 (even better :)



gl



</answer>



<asker's comment>



helpful



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Lol G
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 230 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



There is no Q9450, just a Q9550, and a Q9400, but i'd go with the Q9550. With good cooling you could over-clock it to 3.8Ghz. The memory is fine. I wouldn't go for a dual 9500GT, i'f go for a XFX GTX260 XXX. It's way better. The soundcard is fine. But the motherboard is absolute crap! Get a Asus P5Q Pro, when doing that you could have 1066mhz RAM memory modules if you wish.



</answer>

M W

<answer>



No. The Windows backup disks are useless. This has been the case since Windows 95. This is because a certain software OEM that starts with Micro chooses to employ people with limited common sense. Furthermore. they choose not to do any real research & development (R&D). The world at large is their beta tester.



Your question needs to be prosed directly to Microxxxx.



The good news is that there are programs that fill this void. They can restore your system back onto a clean hard drive as it was when you ran it. The most notable, and the first, is Ghost. The reality is that most people actually learn this the hard way.



</answer>

<answer from>



Cody A
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 172 (Level 1)

<answer>
