<answer from>



Andrew C
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 1216 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Have you tried to installdrivers for this device? if not this is what you need to do! go to the sony support section and download the drivers for it. Now install them. Your floppy drive should auto detect so check it is set up in the bios to do this.



If this does not work then unplug everything from the back of your computer and unscrew the back keeping one hand on a metal part of the case(this will stop electro static discharge) check all the cabling is fitted properly and has not come loose. If this is all fine then put your machine cover backon and turn it on again. If this dont work you maybe looking at a new dvd and floppy drive.



</answer>

<question from>



djjosh_d...
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How to make pen drive as ram?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Adding system memory (typically referred to as RAM) is often the best way to improve a PC's performance, since more memory means more applications are ready to run without accessing the hard drive. However, upgrading memory can be difficult and costly, and some machines have limited memory expansion capabilities, making it impossible to add RAM.



Windows Vista introduces Windows ReadyBoost, a new concept in adding memory to a system. You can use non-volatile flash memory, such as that on a universal serial bus (USB) flash drive, to improve performance without having to add additional memory "under the hood."



The flash memory device serves as an additional memory cache—that is, memory that the computer can access much more quickly than it can access data on the hard drive. Windows ReadyBoost relies on the intelligent memory management of Windows SuperFetch and can significantly improve system responsiveness.



It's easy to use Windows ReadyBoost. When a removable memory device such as a USB flash drive or a secure digital (SD) memory card is first inserted into a port, Windows Vista checks to see if its performance is fast enough to work with Windows ReadyBoost. If so, you are asked if you want to use this device to speed up system performance. You can choose to allocate part of a USB drive's memory to speed up performance and use the remainder to store files.



Hope that helps, you must be using Windows Vista!



-DareDeval756



Source(s):



http://www.microsoft.com/



</answer>

<question from>



wacespañ...
Member since: 14 August 2008
Total points: 737 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



My friend said i should clean the inside of my computer?



my computer is 3 years old, and i,m having trouble getting it to read my memory card from my camera due to dust i think,
my friend says i should take the cover off and vacum it carefully,
do you agree? should i buy a memory stick?



</question>



<answer from>



get2uday...
Member since: 26 October 2006
Total points: 423 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I dont think so..that's for Dust...!! May be device problem .... If you want clean..ya you can but be very careful....



</answer>



<answer from>



Jim Maryland
Member since: 31 January 2007
Total points: 15018 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I wouldn't use a vacuum, but you can use compressed air.  Computer stores (as well as some non-computer stores) sell compressed air cans for cleaning electronics.  Just follow the directions on the can and  you can blow the dust off components.  If your system is extremely dusty, take it outside so the dust doesn't settle around the room.



For the memory card issue, it could be dirt related but not very likely.  If you can test the card on another system or use another card to test on your system, you can figure out the more likely cause.



</answer>



<answer from>



M W
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 255 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer>



Nothing to do with dust here, yes you can clean it sure..vacuum etc...You have a RAM issue here and nothing else.
1.Upgrade your RAM
2.Defragment your Harddrive to compress files and make more space.
3.Perform Disc clean up (Sytems maintenance) for now until you have your new RAM, the disc clean up will delete temporary files which are stored in a temp folder, but it will not hold for long then you have to do it again.



good luck



Source(s):



own Xperience



</answer>

Could something be wrong with my computer, or have i just had bad luck with older monitors?

<answer from>



Pon
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 120 (Level 1)

<answer from>



KN
Member since: 24 October 2007
Total points: 2483 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



There could be a problem with the video output in the computer. Usually this posed a problem with CRT monitors and trying to make them do things they can't do. If this is an LCD monitor, then I would think it would be harder to damage them. It's difficult for me to believe you are having this much bad luck with monitors. I think there could be a chance that you are having video output problems.

<question>



Intel pentium D or dual core?



I have a compaq sr1250nx and I was wondering what the difference between the two and would they work with my mobo thanks



</question>



<answer from>



IHMA
Member since: 29 November 2007
Total points: 1950 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



ask the manufacturer of your mobo(is it a motherboard?)



</answer>



<answer from>



Steven B
Member since: 14 September 2007
Total points: 2257 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Both are technically the same. Pentium D was the first attempt of The Dual Processor. As it eveolved the Dual Core came into play.



Both are still Dual processors. Just the D is the older child of the Dual core and not as advanced as the Dual core.



as for if it would work with your mother board. Probably yes, since they should be backwards compatible. But your better off getting the newer Dual core rather then the D.



</answer>



<answer from>



get2uday...
Member since: 26 October 2006

<original file>1482.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk88661.txt</current file name>




<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



drezeder
Member since: 09 July 2006
Total points: 321 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Which cpu is better, AMD or Intel?



Can someone please explain which cpu is better and maybe a couple reasons why..  Such as running temp, speed, etc.  Im thinking of getting a new comp, primarily for gaming and media...  Im wanting to spend around 200 on the cpu, and I also want 1 vid card, probably an nVidia 9800, or maybe even an ATI 3870, or even a 4870 if I can afford it.  Please give a reason as to why you think the cpu is better, if possible, other than just "Intel is better!", thanks! Also, is it necessary to stick with ATI if getting an AMD proc?



</question>



<answer from>



Mitch C
Member since: 19 July 2006
Total points: 391 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Ugh, thats like asking which is better, ford or chevy!!



To be honest, it doesn't matter all that much.  Both companies make quality products, and each company has its fan boi's.



I personally prefer the Intel processors, why?  Three reasons, one, I buy retail boxed processors, these come with a intel fan assembly, which is usually high quality, and I won't be replacing it during the life of the computer.  Second, I like the thermal protection that intel processors have built it.  I have yet to fry a intel chip from overheating.  They will turn off the computer if it gets too hot, protecting the CPU from damage.  Most AMD's now have this feature, though I do have a stack of bad AMD chips, as opposed to one bad intel chip sitting next to me.  Third, the 3 year warranty on a retail boxed cpu.  If that chip fails after 3 years, I'm ready for the new computer by then, if it does happen to fail under warranty, no sweat, everything is covered (CPU wise)



As far as sticking with ATI if you go with AMD, it doesn't matter a great deal, but I have found ATI usually works better with AMD, but I have systems with them both. Intel and AMD with ATI video cards.



If you do purchase a NVidia video card, try to find one with a 3 year warranty.  I love NVidia, but at my place, I have had 3 cards fail all in the same amount of time (bout 16-18 months).  From what I can find this is a manufacturing issue, but after 1 year, nobody wants to help since its out of warranty.  Since the video card is usually more then any other part in the computer(for gamers), I'd want to protect that investment.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks.  Almost perfect, except you didn't ever tell me which one YOU thought was better...  hehe...  thanks for your very thorough answer, though...  I definitely will look into getting an extended warranty if the regular one isn't long enough.



</asker's comment>



<comments>



drezeder



askers edit - Whoops, I guess he DID tell me he liked intel better..  hehe, whoops..



</comments>



<answer from>



Jose
Member since: 15 June 2008
Total points: 158 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If tou want the best CPU, choose Intel, if you want a regular use CPU, use AMD. Both companies make excellent CPUs, but actually the faster CPU was made by Intel, and Intel`s Quad Core CPUs are faster. Intel CPU`s are aldo good because produce very low heat compared to AMD`s. AMD coolers are also a lot noisier than Intel. If you want a gaming PC as you said then your best choice is Intel, specially if you want a Quad Core. A good one is the q6600, which i think is like $180



</answer>

<question from>



Fausto
Member since: 29 July 2008
Total points: 124 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Vista not booting most of the time?



My Windows Vista Home Premium has not been booting most of the time whether in safe mode or not.  Sometimes it does though.  On top of that, these wierd images pop up then freeze my computer.  When I ran the boot sequence, it stops while loading crcdisk.sys. I just installed an old usb 2.0 port along with a relatively old disc drive.



I then removed those and it seems to be fine.  Any insight would be extremely welcome!



</question>



<answer from>



Philip T
Member since: 06 September 2006
Total points: 20523 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It's what is trying to load after crcdisk.sys that is causing the problem.
I've seen this issue before & in that case it was also resolved by removing a hard drive.



Seems the problem was that the power supply lacked the juice to feed everything. Max out the power supply and Vista will not run properly.



How many watts is your PSU ?
Have you added any other hardware since originally purchased ?



regards,
Philip T



</answer>



<asker's comment>



The answer hit it right on the "ball".  I had recently installed another usb 2.0 and my 300 watt thing couldn't handle it.  Thanks so much to Philip T.



</asker's comment>

WHEELS =]
Member since: 02 March 2008
Total points: 999 (Level 2)

Good Luck :)

<question>



Problem with my Media Center?



I have a Gateway computer from 2006. It has Windows Media Player on it. I've been burning CDs on it for 2 years and it's never given me trouble. The other day I burned a CD, and it worked just fine. I simply turned off my moniter and went to bed. The next morning I went to burn another CD (using songs I've used before) and it said it was a "data disc" however it was the same brand of CD I'd used the night before. I didn't think much of it but the CD dosn't play on any of my CD players. I thought it was just a dud but it's been a week and I've tried 5 other CDs and the same problem. It's so bizzare. Why all of a sudden is it not working??? It's very frustrating, I need help!



</question>



<answer from>



Peter G
Member since: 10 August 2007
Total points: 27055 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Elections



</answer from>



<answer>



Your otions changed from music disk to data disk. Yoiu can't fix the bad dick but you can coorrect it on future burns.



Peter



</answer>



<answer from>



MCV
Member since: 11 August 2008
Total points: 322 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sounds like a settings has been changed in your burning software.  You need to be sure you are burning an Audio CD and not a Data CD.  This can be changed in various ways depending on your software.



An Audio CD can play music in an conventional CD player, but a Data CD will burn the songs as mp3s that can only be played on computers, DVD players or some CD players.



</answer>

Alex Awesome™

</answer>



<answer from>



Jim Maryland
Member since: 31 January 2007
Total points: 15018 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Given your system is limited to the AGP video interface, it might be time to think about an upgrade.  There are decent AGP video cards for gaming, but most of the newer games will run much better with the newer PCI Express based cards.  For light gaming though, you are in that "tough decision" zone.  Upgrading your video card and memory should get you all but the more graphic intense games.  Unfortunately t his doesn't mean you'll be able to run most games on high or medium settings.  You may find that you are running on low to medium on some games.



** Edit **
Alex - Unless the asker needs a mobile computer, recommending a laptop will only increase their cost compared to an equivalent desktop system.  Laptops are less flexible and often have limited video card options (which is a primary factor in gaming performance).



</answer>

Total points: 515 (Level 2)

<question from>

Total points: 63 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Will 4-pin CPU 12v power connector work in 8-pin?



If i get a motherboard with an 8-pin CPU 12v power connector, will a 4-pin connector from the power supply work correctly if i plug it into the 8-pin only using one side of it? http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.as... (link to motherboard)



</question>



<answer from>



Desslok
Member since: 19 December 2007
Total points: 2762 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Yes, according to your motherboard manual located here http://www.asrock.com/mb/manual.asp?Mode... on page 36 it says the 8-pin cpu connector is backward compatible with the 4-pin power supply connector and shows you how to connect it.



Cheers



Source(s):



I am reading the motherboard manual, page 36 ;)



</answer>



<asker's comment>



can't have a better source than this



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Addressfourth B
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 165 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Reasonable virtual memory settings for virtual memory file,



Windows XP security in order to set the default value is always a great waste of a lot of hard disk space, in fact, we will be able to set its value is small. Method: enter the "Control Panel / System / Advanced / performance / Settings / Advanced / virtual memory / change", came to the virtual memory settings window, first of all be sure that your page document in which drive letter, and then another letter Drive the page file to disable all. It is to suggest that you set up the other divisions, rather than the default system where the sub-district, This will increase the speed of pages of documents to read and write, the system is conducive to fast running. According to Microsoft's proposal, the page file is set to be 1.5 times the memory capacity, but if you have more memory, it is also the space occupied by the significant, therefore, recommends that if the memory capacity of 256MB in the following, is set to 1.5 times Maximum and minimum values, if more than 512MB, is set to half of the amount of memory entirely feasible.
help you solve the problems automaticlly http://www.error-remover.com/



</answer>



<answer from>



Ladron3d...
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 341 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your should really think about upgrading your power supply as the motherboard you link to is very modern. PSUs should run you $30-$50 and will give the appropriate voltage to your CPU, memory, etc. etc. Look for PSUs from Corsair, Antec, PC Power & Cooling and OCZ.



</answer>



<answer from>



ljason8e...
Member since: 30 June 2007
Total points: 5549 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, it will work just fine, just don't expect a good overclock with only 4 pins as opposed to 8. Also make sure to plug the 4 pin into holes 1,2,3 and 4 and not 5,6,7 and 8 or there will be problems lol



</answer>



<answer from>



James B
Member since: 05 May 2008
Total points: 185 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



No, this will NOT work. You are basically reasoning "Hey, this has half as many pins. I could just use half on the board." No. The board was made for all 8 to be used. You risk damaging multiple things if you try this, plus it flat out won't work.



</answer>

<question>



Question about moddding my computer startup?



i would love to know if there is a program out there that would allow my computer upon startup to the windows page or main page to say "welcome back commander" taken from the tiberium wars game. this would be really cool any help would be apreciated



</question>



<answer from>



airdogsp...
Member since: 22 September 2008
Total points: 462 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can change your startup music (sound) to what ever WAV file you want.



In theory I dare to bet this sound from the game is probably in some MP3 type format.  Really all you would have to do is Convert the MP3 to a WAV and then put that as your Startup Sound.



You could search the internet for a wav format of that sound.  I had a bunch of Simpsons sounds that I use to use back in Windows 3.1 days.



</answer>

<question>



Their is no info. on my sound card like who made it help still no sound on my computer?



I tried looking for the device and provider on my computer but their was nothing written next to them so i still have no sound and don't know anything about my sound card my computer is custom made and windows xp home edition and maybe the sound was erased because the icon does not appear on my task bar this problem has been going on for about 1 month please help!



</question>



<answer from>



lancekio...
Member since: 07 July 2008
Total points: 63 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



upgrade or find drivers



</answer>



<answer from>



Jerry J
Member since: 14 May 2007
Total points: 9266 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Go to settings/system/device manager and delete the sound device and shut down. reboot and you will get the message "new device found" with the option to insert disk or install from OS. Select install from OS and see if Windows has the file in the system, if it is you can install from the OS, if not you will need the driver file



</answer>

<answer>



the first link is to your computer it is a pdf file so you will need a program like adobe reader to read it.go to page 31 and it will be page listed as 1-21 on the bottom of the page in adobe reader and the section you want is 10. and that will be the hookups for the front panel.now they had two manuals for your computer.the first link is to version E1869  and im sure they r taking about the motherboard version.you can shine a light on the board and look for the version.the second link is to version E1569.i checked and it doesn't matter which one you use they r they same hookups.hope this helps.need more help email me.

Well between my family, and me. I would have to say XP. My mom uses win 98, my step dad uses linux/unix, my best friend (like a bro to me) uses vista, I use XP, My wife uses millenium, and my wifes dads now ex fiance used Apple, which he used also. That and all the good games aren't compatable for Vista. My friends Vista won't install my Halo and it won't work at all, Neither will the first guild wars. So I would so stick to XP, even if they make new games for vista, their still compatable for XP. At least until Vista updates and the bugs, crashes, glitches are all worked out. My friend is a gamer, and he's had to reformatt his new less than 6 month old Vista about 3 times cause of it's errors. Not worth it to me. I've used the same XP hard drive and never had a problem. <answer>



64bit Vista. It's over 10% faster than 32 bit. XP and DX9 are yesterdays news in extreme gaming. I have 2 extreme gaming rigs, one with XP and one with Vista. My XP gamers colllecting dust as everyone plays Crysis, Lost Planet, Bioshock etc in DX10 on the Vista rig. If someone has an old or wimpy tower XP would be a better choice but you won't have any probs running it on the rig you plan on buying. DX10's where its at in gaming mostly because DX10 runs Shader 4, DX9 only Shader 3.



</answer>

<question>



Which of these desktop computers  is the best ?



http://www.ebuyer.com/product/143132  Price £359



http://www.pricerunner.co.uk/pi/223-1156... £359



Or can you recommend any better



</question>



<additional details>



oops HP pavilion  £309



Acer Aspire M3200 or HP Pavilion a6525?



</additional details>



<answer from>



goshme14...
Member since: 06 January 2008
Total points: 277 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



They are both very good and the specs are similar, processor speed 2.4GH on both and price is ok.



You should compare the main things 1st which is:
-Processor speed 2.4GHZ dual core (both got them)
-RAM on ACER is 2x1GB incl.AND max is 8GB and supports DDR2 ( Fastest)
-RAM on HP 3GB incl.max doesent say and no support for DDR2.
-HardDrive on Acer, 2x500GB ....TOP.
-HP HardDrive only 1x500GB ok.



I personally have had since 7 years Acer computers and they are great, I would go for the Acer one, fast,powerfull,hardware upgrade easy to the latest Technologie so no need to get a new Motherboard which supports DDR2 RAM for Xample.



Hope it makes sence



Source(s):



IT pro.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks for advice



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



DannyBoy
Member since: 14 February 2008
Total points: 191 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on what you want to do.



The Acer has a slightly faster CPU and twice as much storage space which looks like it may be a RAID-0 (makes data transfer on the hard drive fast; ideal for video editing). Both have pretty lame graphics cards tho with neither being significantly better than the other, while they could play a lot of modern games they are far from ideal. However you could always upgrade the card to something better.



</answer>

<answer from>



ddrcasey
Member since: 15 July 2006
Total points: 449 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You question makes no sense. What you should be asking, is it better to dual boot with Boot Camp or as a VM using Parallels or VMware.  VMware and Parallels do the same thing, run it in a Virtual Machine. Your not "dual booting".



That all depends if you want to stay in the OS X operating system while your running.



And if your asking which one you should use. Personal Preference. I have heard good things about VMware Fusion 2 though.



</answer>



<answer from>



John S
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 866 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you just want to tryout Ubuntu then I would recommend using VMware or Parallels. But if you intend to use it on a regular basis then use dual boot option. Hope this helped.



</answer>

<question>



Computer sound - how do I make it better?



That sound that comes with computers is really bad, where can I download better computer sound for free? Or how can I make it better.



</question>



<answer from>



Choix du'Jour
Member since: 04 January 2008
Total points: 3173 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



1. Buy one of these bad boys: http://www.maximumpc.com/article/news/ap... You won't find a better sound card on the face of the planet.
2. Disable your onboard sound on your motherboard bios and take out the old sound card from your PCI slot (if you had one.)
3. Install the symphony to get 64bit input and output sound.
???
4. Profit.



</answer>



<answer from>



kizersos...
Member since: 01 February 2007
Total points: 549 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can try adjusting your ffdshow audio decoder
also, there is a filter that you can use called AC3.



There is a lot of info available on the net to figure out the settings you need.



I can go into more detail if you need



</answer>



<answer from>



bvnseven
Member since: 05 July 2007
Total points: 2567 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You don't download better sound, and it is not Free.  Do what the first answer said  and go into the bios and disable the onboard sound.  It usually isn't all that good, you are right.  Don't forget about your speakers-  the best sound card is worthless with lousy or inadequate speakers.



What he is saying to do is to buy a sound card.  Also understand that you may not want the best there is and/or have the money to spend on it.  Go to a computer store and listen to what they have, but BE CAREFUL and remember that they are out to sell you something and may not care what they have to tell you to do it.  Better yet, find one of your friend's machines and see how it sounds and go from there.  Also get a friend that knows how to install the card do it if you don't know how.  Don't do it by yourself the first time if you can avoid it.  It is not hard at all to do, but if you do it wrong it could cost you more than you were planning on.



</answer>



<answer from>



f22archr...
Member since: 28 September 2007

♥PIXXI♥

<question>



I need computer help?



So, every time i turn on my printer there is like a thump sound it also happens when i plug in my digital camera to import pictures. when i used to plug in the camera this screen came on and i just pressed import pics and my pics would load to my computer know after this thump (might be like an error sound maybe) i have to do it manual. so if any one out there has had the same problem and know what to do please help. thanx so much. by the way my printer does print, it just thumps when i turn it on.



*:o)



xoxoxoxo



</question>



<answer from>



s j
Member since: 13 May 2007
Total points: 23883 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Desktops



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Probably not an issue at all. Whenever you plug in a USB device or turn a printer on the computer makes a noise to notify you of the presence of a "new" USB device. Also makes a sound when you unplug the device or turn the printer off. A "low-high" tone when you plug it in and a "high-low" tone when you unplug it. When you have a USB device like a cam plugged in there is a icon on the right of the toolbar that says "Safely remove hardware" that you are supposed to click on and choose whatever youre going to yank then it gives you a notice that it is safe to remove it. If you haven't done that disconnecting your cam you may need to reinstall the software for it. Could be simply changing the configuration of the software you use for the cam.  I assume the "thump" you're referring to is coming from the tower not the printer as you said it makes the same sound when you plug your cam into the tower?



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanx to every one for the answers, and yes the thump is coming from the tower, but i still dont know what to do, im gonna call the computer company. thanx again you guys.*:o)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



ep_26
Member since: 26 February 2008
Total points: 196 (Level 1)



</answer from>

but the thump isn't anything to be concerned about it may just be the print head hitting the side of the case while it's going through its cleaning process

<original file>5765.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk94729.txt</current file name>




<category>



Computers & Internet



Hardware



</category>



<question from>



soljathu...
Member since: 13 February 2008
Total points: 352 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



My pc drivers are stuffed?



I just got my pc upgraded. I got a new cpu (intel dual core 2.5 ghz), I got my motherboard upgraded, and i got a new graphics card (NVIDIA GTX 280). I got these put in and connected up by a professional. With the graphics card i didnt have the cd, so i think the professional guy installed the correct drivers onto my pc from the internet. I got home, plugged the pc in, it started up fine. But when i play need for speed prostreet i tried to change the graphics settings but then my pc crashed and so i left it. Then 30 minutes later the colours were all messed up and there was a message saying that the display drivers didnt function normally. So i restarted the pc and it started fine.When i played bioshock i played it on highest detail settings and it ran smoothly. But when i paused it and clicked "Exit to windows" the display drivers stuffed up again. So i went to NVIDIA.com and downloaded the latest drivers for the GTX 280, when i installed them correctly it required me to restart the pc. So i restarted it and now everything on the screen is big and zoomed in. When i right click on the screen to go to properties so i can change the resolution it doesnt do anything, then the colours go weird and theres all these massive pixels and weird colours and it just stays freezed like that. So what do i do? I cant contact the professional because hes not available on the weekends. Please help me! Im stuck and my stupid pc wont let me do anything to fix it. Any suggestions?
Thanks any help is greatly apreciated!



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Some "professional"...  Anybody can say they are a professional or an expert and we don't realize to the contrary till after we Pay them.



I don't know everything, but where is the Driver CD that should have come with the Video Card?  Not only that but there are boxes, directions and antistatic bags that come with it too.



If You bought the stuff yourself then it is up to you to make sure the cards and everything else is compatible with the motherboard.  You also need to make sure that the card(s) can handle the software you want to run.  Understand that a computer is a SYSTEM (a group of interrelated parts, and they ALL must be compatible with the motherboard).  Normally a piece of software will tell you the minimum specs your computer needs for it to run right.



IF the Professional bought all the stuff then be aware of the following:



Some "professionals" just keep driver cd's, manuals and other stuff cuz they know most people don't know enough to ask for them.  If they are dishonest they  also do it because your drivers could get whacked for some reason, so you call this professional back and tell them what is going on.  He tells you he needs to see the machine and to bring it in.  Then he says "something broke that was not under warranty" and charges you for it when all they did was to reinstall the drivers from the CD they should have given you in the first place.



I hate to say it but if you don't know how to upgrade a machine then you are at this person's mercy.  There are also a number of reasons you could be having problems:  the card could be bad, either one or both downloads could be corrupt (not very likely but it could happen), you could have a virus.



You can always take it somewhere else and get another opinion.



The bad thing is you will have to pay for it all over again and the second person may not be any better than the first.  Don't tell them that another company did it.  Just tell them you had a friend do it and they are on vacation or something.  IF this second opinion starts bad-mouthing your "friend" then that is a big red flag right there.  Never trust any business that asks you who did the work the first time.  If they are honest they will not ask you that in the first place.



One thing you can do is to turn the machine off and remove the video card.  Put it in an antistatic bag temporarily and turn the machine on.  The pc will beep and complain because a machine will not boot without video.  Turn the machine off and reinstall the card.  When you turn the machine back on windows should see the card and at least install standard vga drivers for it.  Try it like that for a bit just to test basic functionality.  I would find the Driver CD for that card and not use the downloaded ones.  The only other thing to do is to test the card on another machine with the correct drivers.  Before you do that read the motherboard manual for your upgraded machine and make sure you bought the right type of card (some boards require 1.5 Volt cards).



</answer>

<question>



How can I take programs off my old PC and install them on my new PC.?

<answer from>



Colinc
Member since: 15 March 2007
Total points: 74671 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ghosting will just destroy the new system as it will load all the wrong drivers causing blue screen failures. You can not just copy programs over, as they also need several library files and many registry entries to run. This is why they need installers.

<answer from>



John S
Member since: 05 August 2008

<answer from>



ALISON H
Member since: 14 February 2008
Total points: 1580 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Probably in the Control Panel.



Start, programmes, control panel...



</answer>



<answer from>



Just some dude
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 308 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



click on windows explorer,
view your root directory (C:\drive)
There's a folder called Recycler .. that contains the recycle bin (s) for each account on your PC.



Source(s):



Windows XP



</answer>



<answer from>



radicalr...
Member since: 14 January 2008
Total points: 165 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



C:\RECYCLER, but it's a hidden Protected Operating System folder.



Open My Computer and click on Tools | Folder Options. Then open the View tab. UNCHECK 'Hide Protected Operating System Files'. Then open C:\ and you should be able to see C:\RECYCLER.



</answer>



<answer from>



mike h
Member since: 18 August 2008
Total points: 950 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



go to properties,on the left side choose change desktop icons, check recycle bin ,click apply.that will put a shortcut on your desktop.  I'm on vista , by the way.



</answer>



<answer from>



UdovdM
Member since: 25 March 2007
Total points: 605 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Go to Windows Explorer (via Start, (All) Programs, Accessories or press the windows key + E or right click on Start, and choose Explore)
In the folders tree-list, it should be the last item. Under Desktop: My Documents, My Computer, My Network Places, Recycle Bin.



(In Windows 98, it is also in every drive itself (e.g. C:\Recycler) In Windows XP this is a protected operating system file which is are not shown by default.)



If you can't find is, it might have been hidden using the registry.
See http://digi-soft.blogspot.com/2008/01/ho... and http://www.windowsnetworking.com/kbase/W...



The recycler can also be turned off in the Recycle Bin Property dialog-box, but I don't know if it hides the recycle bin, or just not stores deleted items in it.



Source(s):



Windows 98 and XP



</answer>

<question>



Upgrade from AMD athelon 64 x 2?



Can i upgrade my Dell c521 from an AMD Athelon 64 x2 to an AMD athelon 64 x2 black edition 5400+?
if so do i need to upgrade my stock heatsink too?



I also got a lil thermal compound on the am2 cpu socket i tried to clean it with alcohol and toothpicks and q-tips would it still be ok&gt; the computer and motherboard still works...



</question>



<additional details>



I was told to use alcohol it dries quick with no moisture left behind my votech teacher sed that too.



the old cpu is damaged bc the person that owned it before me didnt know how to properlly reinsert it.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Mark N
Member since: 19 February 2007
Total points: 13372 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Add-ons



Desktops



Other - Hardware



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Yes, actually that is the best thing to use for cleaning thermal compound.  Heck I don't know why that other guy is answering in a hardware section if he has never cleaned thermal paste...  The major thing with the thermal paste is to be sure, very sure you do not get any on the pins of the AM2 processor.  If it gets down at the bottom of the chip and makes 2 pins get connection via the thermal compound it will short the cpu forever, because there is no easy way to clean between the pins...  And do not touch the pins with your fingers.
Here is the way I install my CPUs in an AMD machine.  Take your CPU from the AMD package and install it into the socket on your motherboard.  Then butter the die with Artic Silver 5 compound using a razor blade to spread it evenly across the die.  A credit card will work good as well, but need a good hard strait edge.
Forget that 5400 upgrade, go with this
http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.as... AMD 6000 89Watts and 2mb L2 cache.  That is an upgrade if you are going to take the time to change CPU's.  You will tell a differance between the 1mb L2 and the 2mb L2.  Because 3.2 overclock is all you will achieve with any AM2 CPU anyways, that is about the wall for overclocking their CPU's... Not as much overclocking headroom as intel has on their chips...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



that was a good answer



</asker's comment>

<question>



Desktop computer restart by it self after bios loading?



when i boot on my pc, after the screen shows bios, the computer restart by itself. i tried take all parts of the computer and clean it, but the result is still the same.
i need help right now. can somebody help me?



</question>



<answer from>



radicalr...
Member since: 14 January 2008
Total points: 171 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you hear beep sounds (visit below link), probably there is a problem with your hardware, otherwise your system files might be corrupted. Try if you can boot in safe mode and fix anything from there by running your anti-virus, popup/registry cleaner applications, then restart.



Source(s):



http://www.computerhope.com/beep.htm



</answer>



<answer from>



bvnseven
Member since: 05 July 2007
Total points: 2573 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



USUALLY, but not always, a machine that restarts randomly has a bad power supply.



Before I forget, be very careful HOW you clean a machine.  Do NOT use a regular vacuum cleaner; they make antistatic vacs and/or used canned air.



If the machine is plugged into a surge strip then take the surge strip out of the loop and plug the machine into the wall directly.  You could even go so far as to test the outlet with a voltmeter.  If one of those two are bad then you will tear your hair out  if you concentrate on the machine itself.



What you have to do then is to remove each component and replace it with a part that you are sure works.  Do this one at a time, part by part, and restart the machine each time.  IF THERE IS ONLY ONE bad part then this process will help you find it.  Most people assume there is only one bad part and sometimes that gets you in trouble.



You could try each part in another compatible machine as a double check, but go for the power supply being faulty first.



Assume nothing.  Suspect Everything...



</answer>

<answer>



You need to do the following:



1. Disk Cleanup and



2. Disk Defragment.



Go to Start button, Programs, Accessories, System Tools and then you will find Disk Cleanup and Disk Defragment.



After you've done the two above procedures, your computer should be able to run much faster.



</answer>



<answer from>



DevKev81...
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 100 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you have a lot of programs on your computer, chances are there a lot of services running in the background too. Go to Start Menu &gt; Run &gt; (type in) msconfig. A dialogue box will open with some tabs. This is your Microsoft startup program list - all the programs that begin running as you start up Windows. Go to the 'Startup' tab and uncheck all the programs you don't use often, and even programs you use often but can open yourself. After that, open the 'Services' tab and turn off any services that you don't need from YOUR programs, not the Windows programs. Click 'OK' at the bottom and reboot. A message box will open saying you have changed some properties in the Microsoft Config file, just check the box saying not to remind you again and thats it!
Your computer should run a lot faster after this is all said and done.



</answer>



<answer from>



bvnseven
Member since: 05 July 2007
Total points: 2573 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Are your virus definition files CURRENT??  Scans do you no good if your definition files are outdated.



Check your startup programs and programs that run as Services (Start/Run/MSCONFIG...)



If that is not it did you install new software on your machine, do other people use the machine without you knowing it/could they have installed something that you don't want???



Get a Good Registry Cleaner and use it.  FREE software is not always the best answer.  A bloated Registry will slow a machine down fast.  Talk to your friends and see if they have had the problem and what they used before you talk to someone who has something to Sell.  They may tell you anything just to make a sale.  Remember that you cannot return software once it is opened and get your money back.  All they will do is replace it with the same thing and you are out the money.



If that does not do it then Defrag the hard drive.  If you have never done it then do it before you go to bed and it should be done when you wake up.  The first time you do it does take way longer than you expect.  You are not going ot gain a ton of speed from a defrag, but not doing it will definitely slow your machine down.



Did you add any new programs lately?  That includes Windows Updates like Service Pack 3...  You need to know what is running in the background (progams that take up resources and slow your machine down and you may not know they are there).  Certain antivirus programs like Norton really slow a machine down cuz they check and monitor everything...



If you added new software are you sure you have enough RAM?



Try those for starters..



</answer>

bvnseven

<answer>



Did you partition and format your hard drive if it is new?  The don't come preformatted like floppies used to.  I always partition and format my hard drives first so I don't remember if Windows will do it for you.  The other answer is right in that you need to give us more info as to exactly what was on the screen, what the error messages were and what step you were on (what steps completed correctly and when did it screw up)??



The possibility exists that the copies are bad or the windows itself  is no good.  Ideally you need to have another hard drive to test it on, then you can say if it's the drive or the copy.  Remember that certain copies of windows will only install so many times.  People also like to play practical jokes on others thinking they are getting something for free and they purposely disable the software by deleting certain critical files.



Are you sure your CD/DVD drive is reading the media correctly?  If the drive is not working right then it does not matter what you are trying to install..

<question from>



Yggdrasi...
Member since: 15 September 2008

Contributing In:

Desktops



</question from>



<question>



Can Someone Explain Anti-Aliasing To Me? Thanx?



OK, I am hardly a noob, but I am not all that up on graphics. What exactly does anti-aliasing do in gaming?



</question>



<additional details>



Ah, a countermeasure for the dreaded JAGGIES, eh?



</additional details>



<answer from>



oni-kun 卍
Member since: 27 July 2008
Total points: 11705 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Programming & Design



</answer from>



<answer>



Basically imagine an old 3D game, now all the walls will have jagged edges right? Anti Aliasing layers over ALL edges and smooths them out.



This can be a graphics intensive option and usually only higher quality graphics cards can produce flawless AA.



There are different levels of AA such as 2x 4x 8x 16x.



2x/4x are what most games can add on automatically in 'high' settings etc.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mohib
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 236 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



In digital signal processing, anti-aliasing is the technique of minimizing the distortion artifacts known as aliasing when representing a high-resolution signal at a lower resolution. Anti-aliasing is used in digital photography, computer graphics, digital audio, and many other applications.



In the image domain, aliasing artifacts can appear as wavy lines or bands, moiré patterns, popping, strobing, or as unwanted sparkling. In the sound domain they can appear as rough, dissonant, or spurious tones, or as noise.



Anti-aliasing means removing signal components that have a higher frequency than is able to be properly resolved by the recording (or sampling) device.



Source(s):



http://www.widearea.co.uk/designer/anti....



</answer>



<answer from>



Deadralo...
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 105 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Basically it fills in the "jaggies" with different shades of color. In the end you get a smooth edge, but it is very graphical demanding.



</answer>



<answer from>



cypheron
Member since: 26 April 2008
Total points: 13176 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Welcome to ten years ago, noob.  Anti-alising removes alias artifacts from images:



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aliasing



In games, that basically means removing jagged edges.



</answer>

barkn s

<answer>



their is nothing wrong with ME. ME is nothing more then 98 up dated. get yourself another harddrive and load it. it sounds like you picked up a nasty bug. if you still have the problem, it hardware, not the OS. if everything is fine. hook up the other harddrive, drag off what you want to keep. if its hardware you will have to figure out what is causing the problem. the FAT file system is really only good to 30gig's. check out e-bay for a good used drive.



</answer>

Of course you can take out your harddrive and put it in to another pc, just make sure what is the MASTER (main) hdd and the SLAVE (yours) one.
Every PC technician will tell you the same thing what I've written here.

<answer>



In regards to what can cause it to happen.



Could be a virus or some form of spyware infection.



When you go to power it back on, you said you get an orange light & then it goes out.



Assuming that is the Power light on the front of the PC tower, it could be 2 things:



Power Supply or Mother Board.



Which seems that you may already know that.



With the Hard Drive question.  You should be able to move one Hard Drive to another PC.  Just keep in mind, that when you switch that Hard Drive to another PC, you will be hooking up to another Motherboard.



The reason why it may not be Booting off that Hard Drive, is that it is not recognizing the Motherboard it is now hooked up to.



I believe if you reformat the Hard Drive (Reinstall Windows, ect...), that should work.



I ran in to this before & after I reformatted the Hard Drive, it worked.



</answer>

<answer from>



bvnseven
Member since: 05 July 2007
Total points: 2593 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sounds like your power supply.  Realize part of what happens during the Boot Process.  One of the first things that happens is when you turn the power on the power supply checks itself for to see if it is operating correctly.  There is something called a Power Good signal, and that is the power supply's check to see if the electricity is within the proper parameters/boundaries (i.e. is the current good/stable?)  If the power supply does not pass that test within milliseconds the supply automatically shuts down to prevent damage to itself and the computer.



The bad thing is that the last time you started the machine it worked fine at startup but then developed problems, some severe.  The other thing is that there often is no warning when a power supply will fail, and when it does there is no guarantee  that it will shutdown and not ruin anything else.  Whatever is connected to the supply (the motherboard, the ram, any drives, any cards like a network or video card, the cpu) could get fried too.  It all depends on how far the problems progressed before it shut down.



I hate to say it but it could have ruined most of your machine inside.  Hopefully not, but...



The only things you can do is to first have the power supply tested outside the machine, then if it is bad replace the power supply and hope it did not damage anything else.  If it still does the same thing then you need to check each component in your machine in another machine.  I would use a machine that you don't care about if you have one.  It sounds like the power supply failed and took out at least the hard drive, but you have to check each component one by one.  If you don't have a spare compatible machine you can either assume the machine is toast or take it to a reputable tech and let them test it.  All you will want to tell them is "my computer won't start"...  They will know what to look for.



</answer>

<answer from>



bvnseven
Member since: 05 July 2007
Total points: 2593 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Check other answers too.  One thing you need to know is the full capacity of the drive on the drive label.  An OS will only format so much drive space, and 32 GB is one of the limits.  What I am saying is you could have more space available than what your Operating System says you have.  The drive could have room for more partitions to give you more space to store stuff.  You need a utility or OS that can see past the 32GB limit if that is the case.



If your drive is actually 32.5GB then you either need another hard drive in your machine in addition to the one you have or a larger drive to replace the 32.5.  If you get something like an 80gb drive you may have to divide it up into 32, 32 and 16 GB.  It will all still work but you cannot install everything on the C: Drive.  It all depends on how much the Operating System will recognize as far as drive space.



</answer>
